10325||||||false||||||
<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//IETF//DTD HTML 2.0//EN">
<!--Converted with LaTeX2HTML 96.1 (Feb 5, 1996) by Nikos Drakos (nikos@cbl.leeds.ac.uk), CBLU, University of Leeds -->
<HTML>
<HEAD>
<TITLE>The Lottery</TITLE>
</HEAD>
<BODY LANG="EN" BGCOLOR=#FFFFFF>
 <H1><BR CLEAR=ALL><CENTER><TABLE BGCOLOR=#0060F0><TR><TD><B><FONT SIZE=5 COLOR=#C0FFFF>&nbsp;<A NAME="SECTION0001000000000000000000">The Lottery</A></FONT>&nbsp;</B></TABLE></CENTER></H1>
<P>
The Sports Association of Bangladesh is in great problem with their latest lottery 'Jodi laiga Jai'. There are
so many participants this time that they cannot manage all the numbers. In an urgent
meeting they have decided that they will ignore some numbers. But how they
will choose those unlucky numbers!!   Mr. NondoDulal who is very interested about historic problems proposed a scheme to get free from
this problem. <p>

You may be interested to know how he has got this scheme. Recently he has read the
Joseph's  problem.
<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001002000000000000000">The Problem</A></FONT></H2>
There are N tickets which are numbered from 1 to N.  Mr. Nondo will  choose M
random numbers  and then he will select those numbers which is divisible
by at least one of those M numbers. The numbers which are not divisible by any
of those M numbers will be considered for the lottery. <p>

As you know each number is divisible by 1. So Mr. Nondo will never select
1 as one of those M numbers. Now given N,M and M random numbers, you have to
find out the number of tickets which will be considered for the lottery.

<P>
<p>

</U></U><H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001003000000000000000">The Input</A></FONT></H2>
<P>
Each input set starts with two Integers N (10<=N<2^31) and M (1<=M<=15).
The next line will contain M positive integers each of which is not greater than N.
Input is terminated by EOF.
<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001004000000000000000">The Output</A></FONT></H2>
<P>
Just print in a line out of  N tickets how many will be considered for the lottery.
<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001005000000000000000">Sample Input</A></FONT></H2>
<P>
<PRE>
10 2
2 3
20 2
2 4
</PRE>
<P>
<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001006000000000000000">Sample Output</A></FONT></H2>
<P>
<PRE>
3
10
</PRE>
<PRE>
<hr>
<h3><i>Md. Kamruzzaman</i></H3>
</PRE>

</BODY>
</HTML>

______________________________________________________
10326||||||false||||||
<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//IETF//DTD HTML 2.0//EN">
<!--Converted with LaTeX2HTML 96.1 (Feb 5, 1996) by Nikos Drakos (nikos@cbl.leeds.ac.uk), CBLU, University of Leeds -->
<HTML>
<HEAD>
<TITLE>The Polynomial Equation</TITLE>
</HEAD>
<BODY LANG="EN" BGCOLOR=#FFFFFF>
 <H1><BR CLEAR=ALL><CENTER><TABLE BGCOLOR=#0060F0><TR><TD><B><FONT SIZE=5 COLOR=#C0FFFF>&nbsp;<A NAME="SECTION0001000000000000000000">The Polynomial Equation</A></FONT>&nbsp;</B></TABLE></CENTER></H1>
<P>
<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001002000000000000000">The Problem</A></FONT></H2>
<P>
A Polynomial equation of degree n is defined as follows :<p> <xmp>
              C + Sum (Ci*x^i) = 0.  for i=1 to n. </xmp><p> 
A polynomial equation of n degree can have at most n distinct roots
which may be both real or complex. Such as a quadratic equation : <p><xmp>
              x^2 - 5x + 6 = 0 </xmp>
has two roots 2 and 3.  In this problem you have to generate such a polynomial
equation whose roots are already given.

<p>

</U></U><H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001003000000000000000">The Input</A></FONT></H2>
<P>
The input will start with a positive integer N indicating the number of roots of the
polynomial equation. The next line will contain the roots each of which is an integer.
N will not exceed 50. Input is terminated by EOF.
<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001004000000000000000">The Output</A></FONT></H2>
<P>
You have to show the polynomial using x as a variable. If coeffecient of any term x^i (i > 0)
becomes zero then you need not show that term. In case of coeffecient being 1 only
print x^i(i > 0). Again if the constant term is zero always use + 0. See sample output for more clarification. <p>
You can be sure that no coeffecient will exceed 10^15.

<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001005000000000000000">Sample Input</A></FONT></H2>
<P>
<PRE>
2
2 3
2
-2 -3
3
0 1 -1
</PRE>
<P>
<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001006000000000000000">Sample Output</A></FONT></H2>
<P>
<PRE>
x^2 - 5x + 6 = 0
x^2 + 5x + 6 = 0
x^3 - x + 0 = 0
</PRE>
<PRE>
<hr>
<i><H3>Md. Kamruzzaman</H3></i>
</pre>
</BODY>
</HTML>

______________________________________________________
10327||||||false||||||
<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//IETF//DTD HTML 2.0//EN">
<!--Converted with LaTeX2HTML 96.1 (Feb 5, 1996) by Nikos Drakos (nikos@cbl.leeds.ac.uk), CBLU, University of Leeds -->
<HTML>
<HEAD>
<TITLE>Flip Sort </TITLE>
</HEAD>
<BODY LANG="EN" BGCOLOR=#FFFFFF>
 <H1><BR CLEAR=ALL><CENTER><TABLE BGCOLOR=#0060F0><TR><TD><B><FONT SIZE=5 COLOR=#C0FFFF>&nbsp;<A NAME="SECTION0001000000000000000000">Flip Sort</A></FONT>&nbsp;</B></TABLE></CENTER></H1>
<P>
Sorting in computer science is an important part. Almost every problem can be solved
effeciently if sorted data are found. There are some excellent sorting algorithm which 
has already acheived the lower bound nlgn. In this problem we will also discuss about
a new sorting approach. In this approach only one operation ( Flip ) is available and that
is you can exchange two adjacent terms. If you think a while, you will see that it is
always possible to sort a set of numbers in this way.
<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001002000000000000000">The Problem</A></FONT></H2>
<P>
A set of integers will be given. Now using the above approach we want to sort 
the numbers in ascending order. You have to find out the minimum number of
flips required. Such as to sort "1 2 3" we need no flip operation 
whether to sort "2 3 1" we need at least 2 flip operations.
<p>

</U></U><H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001003000000000000000">The Input</A></FONT></H2>
<P>
The input will start with a positive integer N ( N<=1000 ). In next few lines
there will be N integers.
Input will be terminated by EOF.
<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001004000000000000000">The Output</A></FONT></H2>
<P>
For each data set print "Minimum exchange operations : M" where M is the minimum
flip operations required to perform sorting. Use a seperate line for
each case.
<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001005000000000000000">Sample Input</A></FONT></H2>
<P>
<PRE>
3 
1 2 3
3
2 3 1
</PRE>
<P>
<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001006000000000000000">Sample Output</A></FONT></H2>
<P>
<PRE>
Minimum exchange operations : 0
Minimum exchange operations : 2
</PRE>

<PRE>
<hr><i>
<H3>Md. Kamruzzaman</H3></i>
</PRE>
</BODY>
</HTML>

______________________________________________________
10328||||||false||||||
<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//IETF//DTD HTML 2.0//EN">
<!--Converted with LaTeX2HTML 96.1 (Feb 5, 1996) by Nikos Drakos (nikos@cbl.leeds.ac.uk), CBLU, University of Leeds -->
<HTML>
<HEAD>
<TITLE>Coin Toss </TITLE>
</HEAD>
<BODY LANG="EN" BGCOLOR=#FFFFFF>
 <H1><BR CLEAR=ALL><CENTER><TABLE BGCOLOR=#0060F0><TR><TD><B><FONT SIZE=5 COLOR=#C0FFFF>&nbsp;<A NAME="SECTION0001000000000000000000">Coin Toss</A></FONT>&nbsp;</B></TABLE></CENTER></H1>
<P>
Toss is an important part of any event. When everything becomes equal toss is the ultimate decider.
Normally a fair coin is used for Toss. A coin has two sides head(H) and tail(T). Superstition may work
in case of choosing head or tail. If anyone becomes winner choosing head he always wants to choose head. 
Nobody believes that his winning chance is 50-50. However in this problem we will deal
with a fair coin and n times tossing of such a coin. The result of such a tossing can be represented
by a string. Such as if 3 times tossing is used then there are possible 8 outcomes.<center><br>
                             
HHH HHT HTH HTT THH THT TTH TTT </center>
<p>

As  the coin is fair we can consider that the probability of each outcome is also equal. For
simplicity we can consider that if the same thing is repeated 8 times we can expect to get each
possible sequence once. 
<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001002000000000000000">The Problem</A></FONT></H2>
<P>
In the above example we see 1 sequnce has 3 consecutive H, 3 sequence has 2 consecutive H and
7 sequence has at least single H. You have to generalize it. Suppose a coin is tossed n times.
And the same process is repeated 2^n times. How many sequence you will get which contains a consequnce
of H of length at least k.
<p>

</U></U><H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001003000000000000000">The Input</A></FONT></H2>
<P>
The input will start with two positive integer, n and k (1<=k<=n<=100). 
Input is terminated by EOF.
<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001004000000000000000">The Output</A></FONT></H2>
<P>
For each test case show the result in a line as specified in the problem statement.
<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001005000000000000000">Sample Input</A></FONT></H2>
<P>
<PRE>
4 1
4 2
4 3
4 4
6 2
</PRE>
<P>
<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001006000000000000000">Sample Output</A></FONT></H2>
<P>
<PRE>
15
8
3
1
43
</PRE>

<PRE>
<hr><i>
<H3>Md. Kamruzzaman</H3></i>
</PRE>
</BODY>
</HTML>

______________________________________________________
10329||||||false||||||
<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//IETF//DTD HTML 2.0//EN">
<!--Converted with LaTeX2HTML 96.1 (Feb 5, 1996) by Nikos Drakos (nikos@cbl.leeds.ac.uk), CBLU, University of Leeds -->
<HTML>
<HEAD>
<TITLE>Combinatorial Expression </TITLE>
</HEAD>
<BODY LANG="EN" BGCOLOR=#FFFFFF>
 <H1><BR CLEAR=ALL><CENTER><TABLE BGCOLOR=#0060F0><TR><TD><B><FONT SIZE=5 COLOR=#C0FFFF>&nbsp;<A NAME="SECTION0001000000000000000000">Combinatorial Expression</A></FONT>&nbsp;</B></TABLE></CENTER></H1>
<P>
In combinatorics the term mainly used is nCr which literally means the number of ways r things
can be taken from n things. Mathematically nCr is defined as :<p>
<img SRC = "p10329.jpg" > <br>
A combinatorial expression may involve many such terms with arithmatic operators.
In this problem you have to evaluate a combinatorial expression involving only
multiplication and division of nCr.

<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001002000000000000000">The Problem</A></FONT></H2>
<P>
Here a combinatorial expression has two parts. One is numerator and the other
is denominator. Both consist of as a mutiplication of several nCr's or a single nCr. A simple expression
could be : nCr*nCr / nCr.
You have to determine whether the expression produces an integer result ( The numerator is
divisible by the denominator). If so then you have to show the result only when the
number of digits in the result is less than 101 otherwise just print -1 . If not divisible then print zero only.
<p>

</U></U><H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001003000000000000000">The Input</A></FONT></H2>
<P>
The input will start with two positive integer, N and M (N,M<=100). 
Each of the following N+M lines will contain two integers (n and r). The first 2*N integers will 
make the numerator and the next 2*M integers will make the denominator. 
It is guranteed that no invalid
nCr will be present (0<=r<=n<=5000).  Input will be terminated by EOF.
<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001004000000000000000">The Output</A></FONT></H2>
<P>
For each test case show the result in a line as specified in the problem statement.
<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001005000000000000000">Sample Input</A></FONT></H2>
<P>
<PRE>
3 3
10 5 
10 4 
10 3
10 7
10 6
10 5
3 3
10 5
10 4
10 3
10 7
10 6
10 1
3 3
10 5
10 4
10 3
10 7
10 6
10 10
4 1
10 5
10 5
10 5
10 5
100 100
</PRE>
<P>
<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001006000000000000000">Sample Output</A></FONT></H2>
<P>
<PRE>
1
0
252 
4032758016
</PRE>

<PRE>
<hr><i>
<H3>Md. Kamruzzaman</H3></i>
</PRE>
</BODY>
</HTML>

______________________________________________________
10330||||||false||||||
<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//IETF//DTD HTML 2.0//EN">
<!--Converted with LaTeX2HTML 96.1 (Feb 5, 1996) by Nikos Drakos (nikos@cbl.leeds.ac.uk), CBLU, University of Leeds -->
<HTML>
<HEAD>
<TITLE>Power Transmission </TITLE>
</HEAD>
<BODY LANG="EN" BGCOLOR=#FFFFFF>
 <H1><BR CLEAR=ALL><CENTER><TABLE BGCOLOR=#0060F0><TR><TD><B><FONT SIZE=5 COLOR=#C0FFFF>&nbsp;<A NAME="SECTION0001000000000000000000">Power Transmission</A></FONT>&nbsp;</B></TABLE></CENTER></H1>
<P>
<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001002000000000000000">The Problem</A></FONT></H2>
<P>
DESA is taking a new project to transfer power. Power is generated by  the newly established plant in  Barisal. The main aim of this
project is to transfer Power in Dhaka. As Dhaka is a megacity with almost 10 million people DESA
wants to transfer maximum amount of power through the network. But as always occurs in case
of power transmission it is tough to resist loss. So they want to use
some regulators whose main aim are to divert power through several outlets without any loss. <p>Each such regulator
has different capacity. It means if a regulator gets 100 unit power and it's capacity is 80 unit
then remaining 20 unit power will be lost. Moreover each unidirectional link( Connectors among regulators)  has a certain capacity.
A link with capacity 20 unit cannot transfer power more than 20 unit. Each regulator can distribute the input
power among the outgoing links so that no link capacity is overflown. DESA wants to know the maximum amount of
power which can be transmitted throughout the network so that no power loss occurs. That is the job
you have to do. <p>

<center>
<img src = "p10330.jpg">
</center><p>
( Do not try to mix the above description with the real power transmission.)



<p>

</U></U><H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001003000000000000000">The Input</A></FONT></H2>
<P>
The input will start with a postive integer N ( 1<=N<=100 ) indicates the number of regulators. The next few lines
contain N positive integers indicating the capacity of each regulator from 1 to N. The next line contains another positive integer M
which is the number of links available among the regulators. Following M lines contain 3 positive integers ( i j C) each. 
'i' and 'j' is the regulator index ( 1<=i,j<=N) and C is the capacity of the link. Power can transfer from i'th
regulator to j'th regulator.
 The next line contains another two positive integers B and D. B is the number of regulators
which are the entry point of the network. Power generated in Barisal must enter in the network
through these entry points.  Simmilarly D is the number of regulators connected to Dhaka. These links are special and have infinite
capacity. Next line will contain B+D integers each of which is an index 
 of regulator. The first B integers are the index of regulators connected with Barisal. Regulators
connected with Barisal are not connected with Dhaka.<p>
Input is terminated by EOF.


<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001004000000000000000">The Output</A></FONT></H2>
<P>
For each test case show the maximum amount of power which can be transferred to Dhaka from
Barisal. Use a seperate line for each test case.
<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001005000000000000000">Sample Input</A></FONT></H2>
<P>
<PRE>
4
10 20 30 40
6
1 2 5
1 3 10
1 4 13
2 3 5
2 4 7
3 4 20
3 1
1 2 3 4
2
50 100
1
1 2 100
1 1
1 2
</PRE>
<P>
<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001006000000000000000">Sample Output</A></FONT></H2>
<P>
<PRE>
37
50
</PRE>

<PRE>
<hr><i>
<H3>Md. Kamruzzaman</H3></i>
</PRE>
</BODY>
</HTML>

______________________________________________________
10331||||||false||||||
<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//IETF//DTD HTML 2.0//EN">
<!--Converted with LaTeX2HTML 96.1 (Feb 5, 1996) by Nikos Drakos (nikos@cbl.leeds.ac.uk), CBLU, University of Leeds -->
<HTML>
<HEAD>
<TITLE>The Flyover Construction </TITLE>
</HEAD>
<BODY LANG="EN" BGCOLOR=#FFFFFF>
 <H1><BR CLEAR=ALL><CENTER><TABLE BGCOLOR=#0060F0><TR><TD><B><FONT SIZE=5 COLOR=#C0FFFF>&nbsp;<A NAME="SECTION0001000000000000000000">The Flyover Construction</A></FONT>&nbsp;</B></TABLE></CENTER></H1>
<P>
<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001002000000000000000">The Problem</A></FONT></H2>
<P>
The newly elected Mayor of Dhaka is taking a new project to reduce the trafffic jam
of the megacity. In a meeting the engineers have decided to construct the first 
Flyover in Dhaka. As the budget is limited only one flyover can be constructed. Now the
problem faced by them is which road will be selected. As there are so many important
roads in Dhaka, it is not so easy job to find the optimal one. Moreover they have to also
consider about the future.  Finally they have got a new scheme considering the following
assumptions. <p><ul>

<li> Dhaka can be considered as an undirected graph. Several places like Agargaon, Farmget, Motijheel etc are
the nodes of this graph and roads are the edges. Each road is associated with some cost.</li>
<li> A route in Dhaka is a path from one place to another place. Such as Agargaon to
  Motijheel or Motijheel to Agargaon.</li>
<li> People of Dhaka always use the minimum cost Path.  </li>
<li> If there are several minimum paths available for a route then they use each one.
</li>  
</ul>
<p>
Using the above technique it is possible to find out a road which is used for maximum number 
of routes. If several roads satisfy this criteria the Mayor will choose
the final one.<p>
<center><img SRC = "p10331.jpg" > 
</center><p>
In the above graph road AC is used for route AC,AD,AB. Road AB is  used for
AB route only. Road BD is used for route BD,BC,BA. Road CD is used for route AD,AB,BC,CD.
Thus road CD is maximum used.
<p>

</U></U><H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001003000000000000000">The Input</A></FONT></H2>
<P>
The input will start with two postive integer V,E ( 1<=V<=100) indicates the number of
places in Dhaka and number of roads available.  Each place is recognized by a unique
integer from 1 to N. The next M lines contain 3 integers s,t,C (s!=t) each. It means
there is a road between s and t associated with cost C. 
<p>
Input is terminated by EOF.


<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001004000000000000000">The Output</A></FONT></H2>
<P>
For each data set print the road index which is maximum used. If several roads
satisfy the condition show all using sorted order of index. One line is used for
each case.
<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001005000000000000000">Sample Input</A></FONT></H2>
<P>
<PRE>
4 4
1 2 20
1 4 1
2 3 3
3 4 4
4 4
1 2 1
1 4 1
2 3 1
3 4 1
</PRE>
<P>
<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001006000000000000000">Sample Output</A></FONT></H2>
<P>
<PRE>
4
1 2 3 4
</PRE>

<PRE>
<hr><i>
<H3>Md. Kamruzzaman</H3></i>
</PRE>
</BODY>
</HTML>

______________________________________________________
10332||||||false||||||
<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//IETF//DTD HTML 2.0//EN">
<!--Converted with LaTeX2HTML 96.1 (Feb 5, 1996) by Nikos Drakos (nikos@cbl.leeds.ac.uk), CBLU, University of Leeds -->
<HTML>
<HEAD>
<TITLE>The Absent Minded Professor </TITLE>
</HEAD>
<BODY LANG="EN" BGCOLOR=#FFFFFF>
 <H1><BR CLEAR=ALL><CENTER><TABLE BGCOLOR=#0060F0><TR><TD><B><FONT SIZE=5 COLOR=#C0FFFF>&nbsp;<A NAME="SECTION0001000000000000000000">The Absent Minded Professor</A></FONT>&nbsp;</B></TABLE></CENTER></H1>
<P>

<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001002000000000000000">The Problem</A></FONT></H2>
<P>
Professor Xian is working on Balance for quite a few days. The newly invented
balance by him can accurately specify the difference between two weights. As a
result it is possible to weight anything using only one standard weight.<p> 

Professor wants to test the new Balance. So he collected few metallic sphere
of different weight. Now he keeps one sphere on one side of the balance and then one 
by one from other spheres on another side to take the difference of weight between
two spheres. When the difference becomes negative he ignores that otherwise he
writes the difference on a paper. He performs this process with each sphere individually.
Now using the data professor wants to test the correctness of the new Balance. 
His idea is simple. If a,b,c (a < b < c) are three weights then (c-a)-(b-a) = c-b. But Oh!! professor Xian has forgot
the proper order of his weighting scheme. He is seeking your help.<p>
Your task is to find a weight for each sphere such that the all possible weight difference match
with professor's reading.<p>  

</U></U><H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001003000000000000000">The Input</A></FONT></H2>
<P>
The input will start with an integer, N (3<=N<=50). Then in several lines there
will be (N*(N-1))/2 positive integer(less than 10000) indicating the readings of the balance. 
Input will be terminated by EOF.

<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001004000000000000000">The Output</A></FONT></H2>
<P>
If you get a solution then in each case you have to print N integers on a single line which indicates
the weight of each sphere in ascending order of weight. There can be infinite
solutions of the problem because an offset,d if added with each weight then 
the difference of weight will not change. So the first weight should be zero. Another important
thing is each solution has an image which is also a solution. Such as in sample output 1 image
of (0 2 3) is (0 1 3) which is also a solution. You have to show the first one.<p>If no 
solution is found then just print "Incorrect Balance."

<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001005000000000000000">Sample Input</A></FONT></H2>
<P>
<PRE>
3
1 2 3
3
1 2 2
6
1 2 2 2 3 3 3 4 5 5 5 6 7 8 10
</PRE>
<P>
<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001006000000000000000">Sample Output</A></FONT></H2>
<P>
<PRE>
0 2 3
Incorrect Balance.
0 3 5 6 8 10
</PRE>

<PRE>
<hr><i>
<H3>Md. Kamruzzaman</H3></i>
</PRE>
</BODY>
</HTML>

______________________________________________________
10333||||||false||||||
<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//IETF//DTD HTML 2.0//EN">
<!--Converted with LaTeX2HTML 96.1 (Feb 5, 1996) by Nikos Drakos (nikos@cbl.leeds.ac.uk), CBLU, University of Leeds -->
<HTML>
<HEAD>
<TITLE>The Tower of ASCII </TITLE>
</HEAD>
<BODY LANG="EN" BGCOLOR=#FFFFFF>
 <H1><BR CLEAR=ALL><CENTER><TABLE BGCOLOR=#0060F0><TR><TD><B><FONT SIZE=5 COLOR=#C0FFFF>&nbsp;<A NAME="SECTION0001000000000000000000">The Tower of ASCII</A></FONT>&nbsp;</B></TABLE></CENTER></H1>
<P>
The tower of ASCII is a nice tower made of asterisk (*) , hash sign (#) and periods (.)  . A sample
tower could be :
<XMP>
                                       #****#
                                     #**....**#
                                     #........#
                                   #**........**#
                                   #............#
                                   #............#
                                 #**............#
                                 #..............#
                                 #..............#
                                 #..............#
                             Fig : Tower of Height 10 

</XMP><p>
The tower of ASCII (TOA) has the following properties :<p>

1. It has a fixed height, H. <p>
2. Its external architecture is made up of several pieces of different sizes like : <XMP>

              #**     **#    **#  **#       #**
              #         #           #       #
              #                     #       #  
                                    #       #
              1         2      3    4       5

</XMP>
So there are two types of piece. One is T-shape(1,5)  and another is 1-shape(2,3,4).
T-shape pieces construct the Left part of TOA whether 1-shape pieces make the right part. Each piece
width is fixed which is 3. But the height can be any positive integer.
The intermediate spaces is filled with period.<p>

3. The number of pieces in Left part is always 1 more than that of right part. 
   In the example TOA in left part pieces of
   4,3,2,1 height and in right part pieces of 7,2,1 height have been used.<p>

4. The total number of pieces used in a TOA is it's cardinality. In our example
   the cardinality is 4+3=7. A TOA of fixed height also has a fixed cardinality.<p>

5. In each part pieces of greater height will precede pieces of less height. In the
   given example no alternation of ( 4,3,2,1 ) order is possible. And also pieces
   of same height can be used only once in one part.<p>

6. There is one and only one TOA of height H.<p> 
<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001002000000000000000">The Problem</A></FONT></H2>
<P>
As specified in the properties that for a particular height the cardinality is fixed.
To ensure this, the maximum possible cardinality is chosen for a TOA. Thus in our example
7 is the maximum cardinality for height,10.  To make the TOA unique in each part
the pieces of  maximum height are chosen. Such as in case of TOA of height 12 the left part
could be ( 6,3,2,1 ) or ( 5,4,2,1 ). Whether the right part could be ( 9,2,1 )
or ( 8,3,1 ) or ( 7,3,2 ) or ( 7,4,1 ) etc.  But only ( 6,3,2,1 ) and ( 9,2,1 ) will
be considered for the left and right part.<p>
Lets come to your task. You have to build a TOA of given height H using T-shape
and 1-shape piece. You may consider each piece of any height is available.

<p>

</U></U><H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001003000000000000000">The Input</A></FONT></H2>
<P>
The input will contain an integer H (5<=H<=500) per line. Input is terminated by EOF.
<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001004000000000000000">The Output</A></FONT></H2>
<P>
The output specification starts with a line "Tower : #N" where N is the current TOA.
In next H lines you have to draw the TOA of height H. Look in each line the starting
hash sign may contain leading spaces but the ending hash sign should not be 
followed by any space. You have to use a line break after each ending hash sign.
Print a blank line after each TOA.
<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001005000000000000000">Sample Input</A></FONT></H2>
<P>
<PRE>
5
10
</PRE>
<P>
<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001006000000000000000">Sample Output</A></FONT></H2>
<P>
<PRE>
Tower #1
  #****#
#**....#
#......#
#......#
#......#

Tower #2
      #****#
    #**....**#
    #........#
  #**........**#
  #............#
  #............#
#**............#
#..............#
#..............#
#..............#

</PRE>

<PRE>
<hr><i>
<H3>Md. Kamruzzaman</H3></i>
</PRE>
</BODY>
</HTML>

______________________________________________________
10334||||||false||||||
<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 3.2 Final//EN">
<HTML>
<HEAD>
<TITLE>Ray Through Glasses</TITLE>
</HEAD>
<BODY LANG="EN" BGCOLOR=#FFFFFF>

<H1><BR CLEAR=ALL><CENTER><TABLE BGCOLOR=#0060F0><TR><TD><B><FONT SIZE=5 COLOR=#C0FFFF>&nbsp;<A NAME="SECTION0001000000000000000000">
Ray Through Glasses</A>&nbsp;</FONT></B></TABLE></CENTER>
</H1>

<P>
Suppose we put two panes of glass back-to-back. How many ways <img src = "p10334a.jpg"> are there for light rays to pass through or be reflected after changing direction <b>n</b> times ? Following figure shows the situations when the value of <b>n</b> is 0, 1 and 2. <br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<img src = "p10334.jpg">

<P>

<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001001000000000000000">
Input</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>

<P>
It is a set of lines with an integer <B>n</B> where <B>0 <= n <= 1000 </B>
in each of them.

<P>

<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001002000000000000000">
Output</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>

<P>
For every one of these integers a line containing <img src = "p10334a.jpg"> as described above.

<P>

<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001003000000000000000">
Sample Input</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>

<P>
<PRE>
0
1
2
</PRE>

<P>

<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001004000000000000000">
Sample Output</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>

<P>
<PRE>
1
2
3
</PRE>

<P>

<P>
<BR><HR>
<ADDRESS>
<I>Mohammad Sajjad Hossain</I>
<BR><I>2002-06-16</I>
</ADDRESS>
</BODY>
</HTML>
</HTML>

______________________________________________________
10335||||||false||||||
<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 3.2 Final//EN">
<HTML>
<HEAD>
<TITLE>Ray Inside a Polygon</TITLE>
</HEAD>
<BODY LANG="EN" BGCOLOR=#FFFFFF>

<H1><BR CLEAR=ALL><CENTER><TABLE BGCOLOR=#0060F0><TR><TD><B><FONT SIZE=5 COLOR=#C0FFFF>&nbsp;<A NAME="SECTION0001000000000000000000">
Ray Inside a Polygon</A>&nbsp;</FONT></B></TABLE></CENTER>
</H1>

<P>
Suppose we have a convex polygon of <b>n</b> vertices. One of the edges have a light emitting point which emits a ray of light in a known direction. The edges of the polygon are made of mirrors. As a result when a ray falls upon an edge, it is reflected  to another directon according to the laws of reflection. So after a certain number of reflections we can evaluate the point hitted by the ray. Our challenge here is to evaluate that point. By the way, if the ray falls upon a vertex of the polygon, it is lost forever.<br>
<br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<img src = "p10335.jpg">
<br>
The figure may not show the angles properly. But in actual cases, I mean in your program, you should follow the rules of reflection.
<P>

<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001001000000000000000">
Input</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>

<P>
The input session begins with two numbers <b><i>3 <= v <= 10, 0 <= n <= 1000</i></b>, denoting the number of vertices in the polygon and the number of reflections to simulate. After that a line will follow containing <b><i>(x, y)</b></i>, the position of the light emitting point, which will always lie upon an edge(and will never coincide with any vertex) and <b><i>0 <= t < 360</b></i>, the angle in degree between x-axis and the ray, measured in anti-clockwise direction, which is always valid. Next there will be <b>v</b> lines each of which will contain a vertex of the polygon ordered to the anti-clockwise direction. All points will be represented in x, y coordinate system with two digits after the decimal point. A pair of zeros declares the end of the input session.

<P>

<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001002000000000000000">
Output</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>

<P>
For every dataset, output the final point the ray hits after <b>n</b> reflections with two digits after the decimal point. Remember, the point should lie upon an edge of the polygon. If the ray is lost forever within <b>n</b> reflections, output ``<TT>lost forever...</TT>". Output for every dataset should start in a new line. Be extra cautious about precision errors. Because if there is a vertex 4.00 and our ray passes through 4.001, we will count it as ``<TT>lost forever...</TT>", as we are concerned with only two digits after the decimal point.

<P>

<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001003000000000000000">
Sample Input</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>

<P>
<PRE>
4 4
2.00 0.00 0.00
0.00 0.00
4.00 0.00
4.00 4.00
0.00 4.00
4 0
2.00 0.00 45.00
0.00 0.00
4.00 0.00
4.00 4.00
0.00 4.00
0 0
</PRE>

<P>

<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001004000000000000000">
Sample Output</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>

<P>
<PRE>
lost forever...
4.00 2.00
</PRE>

<P>

<P>
<BR><HR>
<ADDRESS>
<I>Mohammad Sajjad Hossain (idea from - Md. Kamruzzaman)</I>
<BR><I>2002-06-16</I>
</ADDRESS>
</BODY>
</HTML>
</HTML>

______________________________________________________

<!--[if gte mso 10]>

	{mso-style-name:"Table Normal";

<![endif]--><!--[if gte mso 9]><xml>
 <o:shapedefaults v:ext="edit" spidmax="3074"/>
</xml><![endif]--><!--[if gte mso 9]><xml>
 <o:shapelayout v:ext="edit">
  <o:idmap v:ext="edit" data="1"/>
 </o:shapelayout></xml><![endif]-->
</head>

<body bgcolor=white lang=EN-US link="#0000CC" vlink="#9999CC" style='tab-interval:
.5in'>

<div class=Section1>

<p class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'><span style='font-size:18.0pt;color:black'>Problem A<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'><span style='font-size:24.0pt;color:black'>Rank the Languages</span></b><b
style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'><span style='mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt;
color:black'><o:p></o:p></span></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center'><b><span
style='color:black'>Input: </span></b><span style='color:black;mso-bidi-font-weight:
bold'>standard input<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center'><b><span
style='color:black'>Output: </span></b><span style='color:black'>standard
output<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center'><b><span
style='color:black'>Time Limit:</span></b><span style='color:black'> 2 seconds<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'><span style='color:black'>Memory Limit: </span></b><span
style='color:black'>32 MB<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p style='margin-right:.5in;text-align:justify'><span style='color:black'>You
might have noticed that English and Spanish are spoken in many areas all over the
world. Now it would be nice to rank all languages according to the number of
states where they are spoken. <o:p></o:p></span></p>

<h2 style='text-align:justify'><span style='color:black'><!-- ===================== PROBLEM ==================================== -->Problem
<o:p></o:p></span></h2>

<p style='margin-right:.5in;text-align:justify'><span style='color:black'>You're
given a map which shows the states and the languages where they are spoken.
Look at the following map: <o:p></o:p></span></p>

<pre style='margin-right:.5in;text-align:justify'><span class=GramE><span
style='color:black'>ttuuttdd</span></span><span style='color:black'><o:p></o:p></span></pre><pre
style='margin-right:.5in;text-align:justify'><span class=GramE><span
style='color:black'>ttuuttdd</span></span><span style='color:black'><o:p></o:p></span></pre><pre
style='margin-right:.5in;text-align:justify'><span class=GramE><span
style='color:black'>uuttuudd</span></span><span style='color:black'><o:p></o:p></span></pre><pre
style='margin-right:.5in;text-align:justify'><span class=GramE><span
style='color:black'>uuttuudd</span></span><span style='color:black'><o:p></o:p></span></pre>

<p style='margin-right:.5in;text-align:justify;tab-stops:45.8pt 91.6pt 137.4pt 183.2pt 229.0pt 274.8pt 320.6pt 366.4pt 412.2pt 458.0pt 503.8pt 549.6pt 595.4pt 641.2pt 687.0pt 732.8pt'><span
style='color:black'>The map is read like this: Every letter stands for a
language and states are defined as connected areas with the same letter. Two
letters are &quot;connected&quot; if one is at left, at right, above or below
the other one. So in the above map, there are three states where the language
&quot;</span><code><span style='font-size:10.0pt;color:black'>t</span></code><span
style='color:black'>&quot; is spoken, three where &quot;</span><code><span
style='font-size:10.0pt;color:black'>u</span></code><span style='color:black'>&quot;
is spoken and one state where people speak &quot;</span><code><span
style='font-size:10.0pt;color:black'>d</span></code><span style='color:black'>&quot;.
<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p style='margin-right:.5in;text-align:justify;tab-stops:45.8pt 91.6pt 137.4pt 183.2pt 229.0pt 274.8pt 320.6pt 366.4pt 412.2pt 458.0pt 503.8pt 549.6pt 595.4pt 641.2pt 687.0pt 732.8pt'><span
style='color:black'>Your job is to determine the number of states for each
language and print the results in a certain order. <o:p></o:p></span></p>

<h2 style='text-align:justify;tab-stops:45.8pt 91.6pt 137.4pt 183.2pt 229.0pt 274.8pt 320.6pt 366.4pt 412.2pt 458.0pt 503.8pt 549.6pt 595.4pt 641.2pt 687.0pt 732.8pt'><span
style='color:black'><!-- ===================== INPUT ====================================== -->Input
<o:p></o:p></span></h2>

<p style='margin-right:.5in;text-align:justify;tab-stops:45.8pt 91.6pt 137.4pt 183.2pt 229.0pt 274.8pt 320.6pt 366.4pt 412.2pt 458.0pt 503.8pt 549.6pt 595.4pt 641.2pt 687.0pt 732.8pt'><span
style='color:black'>The first line contains the number of test cases N. Each
test case consists of a line with two numbers H and W, which are the height and
the width of the map. Then follow H lines with a string of W letters. Those
letters will only be lowercase letters from &quot;</span><code><span
style='font-size:10.0pt;color:black'>a</span></code><span style='color:black'>&quot;
to &quot;</span><code><span style='font-size:10.0pt;color:black'>z</span></code><span
style='color:black'>&quot;. <o:p></o:p></span></p>

<h2 style='text-align:justify;tab-stops:45.8pt 91.6pt 137.4pt 183.2pt 229.0pt 274.8pt 320.6pt 366.4pt 412.2pt 458.0pt 503.8pt 549.6pt 595.4pt 641.2pt 687.0pt 732.8pt'><span
style='color:black'><!-- ===================== OUTPUT ===================================== -->Output
<o:p></o:p></span></h2>

<p style='margin-right:.5in;text-align:justify;tab-stops:45.8pt 91.6pt 137.4pt 183.2pt 229.0pt 274.8pt 320.6pt 366.4pt 412.2pt 458.0pt 503.8pt 549.6pt 595.4pt 641.2pt 687.0pt 732.8pt'><span
style='color:black'>For each test case print &quot;</span><code><span
style='font-size:10.0pt;color:black'>World&nbsp;#n</span></code><span
style='color:black'>&quot;, where n is the number of the test case. After that
print a line for each language that appears in the test case, which contains
the language, a colon, a space and the number of states, where that language is
spoken. These lines have to be ordered decreasingly by the number of states. If
two languages are spoken in the same number of states, they have to appear
alphabetically, which means language &quot;</span><code><span style='font-size:
10.0pt;color:black'>i</span></code><span style='color:black'>&quot; comes
before language &quot;</span><code><span style='font-size:10.0pt;color:black'>q</span></code><span
style='color:black'>&quot;, for example. <o:p></o:p></span></p>

<h2 style='text-align:justify;tab-stops:45.8pt 91.6pt 137.4pt 183.2pt 229.0pt 274.8pt 320.6pt 366.4pt 412.2pt 458.0pt 503.8pt 549.6pt 595.4pt 641.2pt 687.0pt 732.8pt'><span
style='color:black'><!-- ===================== SAMPLE INPUT =============================== -->Sample
Input <o:p></o:p></span></h2>

<pre style='margin-right:.5in;text-align:justify'><span style='color:black'>2<o:p></o:p></span></pre><pre
style='margin-right:.5in;text-align:justify'><span style='color:black'>4 8<o:p></o:p></span></pre><pre
style='margin-right:.5in;text-align:justify'><span class=GramE><span
style='color:black'>ttuuttdd</span></span><span style='color:black'><o:p></o:p></span></pre><pre
style='margin-right:.5in;text-align:justify'><span class=GramE><span
style='color:black'>ttuuttdd</span></span><span style='color:black'><o:p></o:p></span></pre><pre
style='margin-right:.5in;text-align:justify'><span class=GramE><span
style='color:black'>uuttuudd</span></span><span style='color:black'><o:p></o:p></span></pre><pre
style='margin-right:.5in;text-align:justify'><span class=GramE><span
style='color:black'>uuttuudd</span></span><span style='color:black'><o:p></o:p></span></pre><pre
style='margin-right:.5in;text-align:justify'><span style='color:black'>9 9<o:p></o:p></span></pre><pre
style='margin-right:.5in;text-align:justify'><span class=GramE><span
style='color:black'>bbbbbbbbb</span></span><span style='color:black'><o:p></o:p></span></pre><pre
style='margin-right:.5in;text-align:justify'><span class=GramE><span
style='color:black'>aaaaaaaab</span></span><span style='color:black'><o:p></o:p></span></pre><pre
style='margin-right:.5in;text-align:justify'><span class=GramE><span
style='color:black'>bbbbbbbab</span></span><span style='color:black'><o:p></o:p></span></pre><pre
style='margin-right:.5in;text-align:justify'><span class=GramE><span
style='color:black'>baaaaacab</span></span><span style='color:black'><o:p></o:p></span></pre><pre
style='margin-right:.5in;text-align:justify'><span class=GramE><span
style='color:black'>bacccccab</span></span><span style='color:black'><o:p></o:p></span></pre><pre
style='margin-right:.5in;text-align:justify'><span class=GramE><span
style='color:black'>bacbbbcab</span></span><span style='color:black'><o:p></o:p></span></pre><pre
style='margin-right:.5in;text-align:justify'><span class=GramE><span
style='color:black'>bacccccab</span></span><span style='color:black'><o:p></o:p></span></pre><pre
style='margin-right:.5in;text-align:justify'><span class=GramE><span
style='color:black'>baaaaaaab</span></span><span style='color:black'><o:p></o:p></span></pre><pre
style='margin-right:.5in;text-align:justify'><span class=GramE><span
style='color:black'>bbbbbbbbb</span></span><span style='color:black'><o:p></o:p></span></pre>

<h2 style='text-align:justify;tab-stops:45.8pt 91.6pt 137.4pt 183.2pt 229.0pt 274.8pt 320.6pt 366.4pt 412.2pt 458.0pt 503.8pt 549.6pt 595.4pt 641.2pt 687.0pt 732.8pt'><span
style='color:black'><!-- ===================== SAMPLE OUTPUT ============================== -->Sample
Output <o:p></o:p></span></h2>

<pre style='margin-right:.5in;text-align:justify'><span style='color:black'>World #1<o:p></o:p></span></pre><pre
style='margin-right:.5in;text-align:justify'><span class=GramE><span
style='color:black'>t</span></span><span style='color:black'>: 3<o:p></o:p></span></pre><pre
style='margin-right:.5in;text-align:justify'><span class=GramE><span
style='color:black'>u</span></span><span style='color:black'>: 3<o:p></o:p></span></pre><pre
style='margin-right:.5in;text-align:justify'><span class=GramE><span
style='color:black'>d</span></span><span style='color:black'>: 1<o:p></o:p></span></pre><pre
style='margin-right:.5in;text-align:justify'><span style='color:black'>World #2<o:p></o:p></span></pre><pre
style='margin-right:.5in;text-align:justify'><span class=GramE><span
style='color:black'>b</span></span><span style='color:black'>: 2<o:p></o:p></span></pre><pre
style='margin-right:.5in;text-align:justify'><span class=GramE><span
style='color:black'>a</span></span><span style='color:black'>: 1<o:p></o:p></span></pre><pre
style='margin-right:.5in;text-align:justify'><span class=GramE>c</span>: 1 </pre>

<div class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center;tab-stops:45.8pt 91.6pt 137.4pt 183.2pt 229.0pt 274.8pt 320.6pt 366.4pt 412.2pt 458.0pt 503.8pt 549.6pt 595.4pt 641.2pt 687.0pt 732.8pt'>

<hr size=2 width="100%" align=center>

</div>

<p class=MsoNormal style='tab-stops:45.8pt 91.6pt 137.4pt 183.2pt 229.0pt 274.8pt 320.6pt 366.4pt 412.2pt 458.0pt 503.8pt 549.6pt 595.4pt 641.2pt 687.0pt 732.8pt'><b
style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>Stefan Pochmann<o:p></o:p></b></p>

<pre style='margin-right:.5in;text-align:justify'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></pre></div>

<body bgcolor=white lang=EN-US style='tab-interval:.5in'>

<div class=Section1>

<p class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'><span style='font-size:18.0pt;color:black'>Problem B<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'><span style='font-size:24.0pt;color:black'>Flight Planner</span></b><b
style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'><span style='mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt;
color:black'><o:p></o:p></span></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center'><b><span
style='color:black'>Input: </span></b><span style='color:black;mso-bidi-font-weight:
bold'>standard input<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center'><b><span
style='color:black'>Output: </span></b><span style='color:black'>standard
output<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center'><b><span
style='color:black'>Time Limit:</span></b><span style='color:black'> 1 second<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'><span style='color:black'>Memory Limit: </span></b><span
style='color:black'>32 MB<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p style='text-align:justify'><span lang=EN style='color:black;mso-ansi-language:
EN'>Calculating the minimal cost for a flight involves calculating an optimal flight-altitude
depending on wind-strengths changing with different altitudes. It's not enough
just to ask for the route with optimal wind-strength, because due to the mass
of a plane you need a certain amount of fuel to rise. Moreover due to safety
regulations it's forbidden to fly above a certain altitude and you can't fly
under zero-level. <o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p style='text-align:justify'><span lang=EN style='color:black;mso-ansi-language:
EN'>In order to simplify the problem for now, we assume that for each 100 miles
of flight you have only three possiblities: to climb one mile, to hold your
altitude or to sink one mile. <o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p style='text-align:justify'><span lang=EN style='color:black;mso-ansi-language:
EN'>Climb flight requires 60 units of fuel, holding your altitude requires 30
units and sinking requires 20 units. <o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p style='text-align:justify'><span lang=EN style='color:black;mso-ansi-language:
EN'>In the case of headwind you need more fuel while you can save fuel flying
with tailwind. Windstrength w will satisfy the condition -10 &lt;= w &lt;= 10,
where negative windstrength is meant to be headwind and positive windstrength
is tailwind.<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p style='text-align:justify'><span lang=EN style='color:black;mso-ansi-language:
EN'>For one unit of tailwind you can save one unit of fuel each 100 miles; each
unit of headwind will cost an extra unit of fuel. <o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p style='text-align:justify'><span lang=EN style='color:black;mso-ansi-language:
EN'>For example to climb under conditions of windstrength w = -5, you need 65
units of fuel for this 100 miles.<br>
Given the windstrengths on different altitudes for a way from here to X,
calculate the minimal amount of fuel you need to fly to X. <o:p></o:p></span></p>

<h2 style='text-align:justify'><a name=SECTION0001001000000000000000><span
lang=EN style='color:black;mso-ansi-language:EN'>&nbsp;Input</span></a><span
lang=EN style='color:black;mso-ansi-language:EN'><o:p></o:p></span></h2>

<p style='text-align:justify'><span lang=EN style='color:black;mso-ansi-language:
EN'>The first line of the input file contains the number N of test cases in the
file. The first line of each test case contains a single integer X, the
distance to fly, with 1 &lt;= X &lt;= 100000 miles and X is a multiple of 100.
Notice that it's not allowed to fly higher than 9 miles over zero and that you
have to decide whether to climb, hold your altitude or to sink only for every
100 miles.<br>
For every mile of allowed altitude (starting at altitude 9 down to altitude 0)
there follow X/100 windstrengths, starting with the windstrength at your
current position up to the windstrength at position X-100 in steps of 100
miles. Test cases are separated by one or more blank lines. <o:p></o:p></span></p>

<h2 style='text-align:justify'><a name=SECTION0001002000000000000000><span
lang=EN style='color:black;mso-ansi-language:EN'>Output</span></a><span
lang=EN style='color:black;mso-ansi-language:EN'><o:p></o:p></span></h2>

<p style='text-align:justify'><span lang=EN style='color:black;mso-ansi-language:
EN'>For each test case output the minimal amount of fuel used flying from your
current position (at altitude 0) to X (also at altitude 0), followed by a blank
line. <o:p></o:p></span></p>

<h2 style='text-align:justify'><a name=SECTION0001003000000000000000><span
lang=EN style='color:black;mso-ansi-language:EN'>Sample Input</span></a><span
lang=EN style='color:black;mso-ansi-language:EN'><o:p></o:p></span></h2>

<pre style='text-align:justify'><span lang=EN style='color:black;mso-ansi-language:
EN'>2<o:p></o:p></span></pre><pre style='text-align:justify'><span lang=EN
style='color:black;mso-ansi-language:EN'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></span></pre><pre
style='text-align:justify'><span lang=EN style='color:black;mso-ansi-language:
EN'>400<o:p></o:p></span></pre><pre style='text-align:justify'><span lang=EN
style='color:black;mso-ansi-language:EN'>1 1 1 1<o:p></o:p></span></pre><pre
style='text-align:justify'><span lang=EN style='color:black;mso-ansi-language:
EN'>1 1 1 1<o:p></o:p></span></pre><pre style='text-align:justify'><span
lang=EN style='color:black;mso-ansi-language:EN'>1 1 1 1<o:p></o:p></span></pre><pre
style='text-align:justify'><span lang=EN style='color:black;mso-ansi-language:
EN'>1 1 1 1<o:p></o:p></span></pre><pre style='text-align:justify'><span
lang=EN style='color:black;mso-ansi-language:EN'>1 1 1 1<o:p></o:p></span></pre><pre
style='text-align:justify'><span lang=EN style='color:black;mso-ansi-language:
EN'>1 1 1 1<o:p></o:p></span></pre><pre style='text-align:justify'><span
lang=EN style='color:black;mso-ansi-language:EN'>1 1 1 1<o:p></o:p></span></pre><pre
style='text-align:justify'><span lang=EN style='color:black;mso-ansi-language:
EN'>1 1 1 1<o:p></o:p></span></pre><pre style='text-align:justify'><span
lang=EN style='color:black;mso-ansi-language:EN'>1 9 9 1<o:p></o:p></span></pre><pre
style='text-align:justify'><span lang=EN style='color:black;mso-ansi-language:
EN'>1 -9 -9 1<o:p></o:p></span></pre><pre style='text-align:justify'><span
lang=EN style='color:black;mso-ansi-language:EN'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></span></pre><pre
style='text-align:justify'><span lang=EN style='color:black;mso-ansi-language:
EN'>1000<o:p></o:p></span></pre><pre style='text-align:justify'><span lang=EN
style='color:black;mso-ansi-language:EN'> 9<span style='mso-spacerun:yes'>  </span>9<span style='mso-spacerun:yes'>  </span>9<span style='mso-spacerun:yes'>  </span>9<span style='mso-spacerun:yes'>  </span>9<span style='mso-spacerun:yes'>  </span>9<span style='mso-spacerun:yes'>  </span>9<span style='mso-spacerun:yes'>  </span>9<span style='mso-spacerun:yes'>  </span>9<span style='mso-spacerun:yes'>  </span>9<o:p></o:p></span></pre><pre
style='text-align:justify'><span lang=EN style='color:black;mso-ansi-language:
EN'> 9<span style='mso-spacerun:yes'>  </span>9<span style='mso-spacerun:yes'>  </span>9<span style='mso-spacerun:yes'>  </span>9<span style='mso-spacerun:yes'>  </span>9<span style='mso-spacerun:yes'>  </span>9<span style='mso-spacerun:yes'>  </span>9<span style='mso-spacerun:yes'>  </span>9<span style='mso-spacerun:yes'>  </span>9<span style='mso-spacerun:yes'>  </span>9<o:p></o:p></span></pre><pre
style='text-align:justify'><span lang=EN style='color:black;mso-ansi-language:

<body lang=EN-US style='tab-interval:.5in'>

<div class=Section1>

<p class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'><span style='font-size:18.0pt;color:black'>Problem C<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'><span style='font-size:24.0pt;color:black'>Mischievous Children</span></b><b
style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:
10.0pt;color:black'><o:p></o:p></span></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center'><b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;color:black'>Input: </span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;color:black;mso-bidi-font-weight:bold'>standard input<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center'><b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;color:black'>Output: </span></b><span style='font-size:
12.0pt;color:black'>standard output<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center'><b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;color:black'>Time Limit:</span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;color:black'> 1 second<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;color:black'>Memory Limit: </span></b><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;color:black'>32 MB<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt'>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt'>Adams
parents put up a sign that says CONGRATULATIONS. The sign is so big that
exactly one letter fits on each panel. Some of Adams younger cousins got bored
during the reception and decided to rearrange the panels. How many unique ways
can the panels be arranged (counting the original arrangement)?</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt'>&nbsp;</span></p>

<h1>Input / Output</h1>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt'>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt'>The
first line of input is a single non-negative integer. It indicates the number
of data sets to follow. Its value will be less than 30001.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt'>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt'>Each
data set consists of a single word, in all capital letters. For each word,
output the number of unique ways that the letters can be rearranged (counting
the original arrangement). Use the format shown in Sample Output, below.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt'>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt'>Each
word will have at most 20 letters. There will be no spaces or other
punctuation.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt'>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt'>The
number of arrangements will always be able to fit into an </span><span
style='font-family:"Courier New"'>unsigned long int</span><span
style='font-size:12.0pt'>. Note that 12! <span class=GramE>is</span> the
largest factorial that can fit into an </span><span style='font-family:"Courier New"'>unsigned
long int</span><span style='font-size:12.0pt'>.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt'>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt'>&nbsp;</span></p>

<h2>Sample</h2>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt'>&nbsp;</span></p>

<h1>Sample Input</h1>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt'>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='font-family:"Courier New"'>3</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='font-family:"Courier New"'>HAPPY</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='font-family:"Courier New"'>WEDDING</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='font-family:"Courier New"'>ADAM</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt'>&nbsp;</span></p>

<h1>Sample Output</h1>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:12.0pt'>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:.5in;text-align:justify;text-indent:-.5in'><span
style='font-family:"Courier New"'>Data set 1: 60</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:.5in;text-align:justify;text-indent:-.5in'><span
style='font-family:"Courier New"'>Data set 2: 2520</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:.5in;text-align:justify;text-indent:-.5in'><span
style='font-family:"Courier New"'>Data set </span><st1:time Minute="12"
Hour="15"><span style='font-family:"Courier New"'>3: 12</span></st1:time></p>

<div class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center;tab-stops:45.8pt 91.6pt 137.4pt 183.2pt 229.0pt 274.8pt 320.6pt 366.4pt 412.2pt 458.0pt 503.8pt 549.6pt 595.4pt 641.2pt 687.0pt 732.8pt'><span
style='font-size:12.0pt'>

<hr size=2 width="100%" align=center>

</span></div>

<p class=MsoNormal style='tab-stops:45.8pt 91.6pt 137.4pt 183.2pt 229.0pt 274.8pt 320.6pt 366.4pt 412.2pt 458.0pt 503.8pt 549.6pt 595.4pt 641.2pt 687.0pt 732.8pt'><b
style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'><span style='font-size:12.0pt'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></span></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></p>

</div>

</body>

</html>

<!--[if gte mso 10]>

	mso-para-margin:0in;
	mso-para-margin-bottom:.0001pt;

	font-family:"Times New Roman";}

<![endif]-->

<body lang=EN-US style='tab-interval:.5in'>

<div class=Section1>

<p class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'><span style='font-size:18.0pt;color:black'>Problem D<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'><span style='font-size:24.0pt;color:black'>Watching Watches</span></b><b
style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'><span style='mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt;
color:black'><o:p></o:p></span></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center'><b><span
style='color:black'>Input: </span></b><span style='color:black;mso-bidi-font-weight:
bold'>standard input<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center'><b><span
style='color:black'>Output: </span></b><span style='color:black'>standard
output<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center'><b><span
style='color:black'>Time Limit:</span></b><span style='color:black'> 10 seconds<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'><span style='color:black'>Memory Limit: </span></b><span
style='color:black'>32 MB<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'>It has been said that a watch
that is stopped keeps better time than one that loses 1 second per day. The one
that is stopped reads the correct time twice a day while the one that loses 1
second per day is correct only once every 43,200 days. This maxim applies to
old fashioned 12-hour analog watches, whose hands move continuously (most digital
watches would display nothing at all if stopped). </p>

<p style='text-align:justify'>Given two such analog watches, both synchronized
to midnight, that keep time at a constant rate but run slow by k and m seconds
per day respectively, what time will the watches show when next they have
exactly the same time? </p>

<h3 style='text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:18.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:
13.5pt'>The Input<o:p></o:p></span></h3>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'>Input consists of a number of
lines, each with two distinct non-negative <span class=GramE>integers</span> k
and m between 0 and 256, indicating the number of seconds per day that each
watch loses. </p>

<h3 style='text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:18.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:
13.5pt'>The Output<o:p></o:p></span></h3>

<p class=MsoBodyText>For each line of input, print k, m, and the time displayed
on each watch, rounded to the nearest minute. Valid times range from <st1:time
Hour="13" Minute="0">01:00</st1:time> to <st1:time Hour="12" Minute="59">12:59</st1:time>
</p>

<h3><span style='font-size:18.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:13.5pt'>Sample Input<o:p></o:p></span></h3>

<pre>1 2</pre><pre>0 7</pre>

<h3 style='tab-stops:45.8pt 91.6pt 137.4pt 183.2pt 229.0pt 274.8pt 320.6pt 366.4pt 412.2pt 458.0pt 503.8pt 549.6pt 595.4pt 641.2pt 687.0pt 732.8pt'><span
style='font-size:18.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:13.5pt'>Output for Sample Input<o:p></o:p></span></h3>

<pre>1 2 <st1:time Hour="12" Minute="0">12:00</st1:time></pre><pre>0 7 <st1:time
Minute="17" Hour="10">10:17</st1:time></pre>

<div class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center;tab-stops:45.8pt 91.6pt 137.4pt 183.2pt 229.0pt 274.8pt 320.6pt 366.4pt 412.2pt 458.0pt 503.8pt 549.6pt 595.4pt 641.2pt 687.0pt 732.8pt'>

<hr size=2 width="100%" align=center>

</div>

<p class=MsoNormal style='tab-stops:45.8pt 91.6pt 137.4pt 183.2pt 229.0pt 274.8pt 320.6pt 366.4pt 412.2pt 458.0pt 503.8pt 549.6pt 595.4pt 641.2pt 687.0pt 732.8pt'><b
style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>Source: Waterloo ACM Programming Contest<o:p></o:p></b></p>

<pre><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></pre></div>

</body>

</html>

<title>Problem A: All in All</title>
<!--[if gte mso 9]><xml>

<body lang=EN-US style='tab-interval:.5in'>

<div class=Section1>

<p class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'><span style='font-size:18.0pt;color:black'>Problem E<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'><span style='font-size:24.0pt;color:black'>All in All</span></b><b
style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'><span style='mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt;
color:black'><o:p></o:p></span></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center'><b><span
style='color:black'>Input: </span></b><span style='color:black;mso-bidi-font-weight:
bold'>standard input<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center'><b><span
style='color:black'>Output: </span></b><span style='color:black'>standard output<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center'><b><span
style='color:black'>Time Limit:</span></b><span style='color:black'> 2 seconds<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'><span style='color:black'>Memory Limit: </span></b><span
style='color:black'>32 MB<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p style='text-align:justify'>You have devised a new encryption technique which
encodes a message by inserting between its characters randomly generated
strings in a clever way. Because of pending patent issues we will not discuss
in detail how the strings are generated and inserted into the original message.
To validate your method, however, it is necessary to write a program that
checks if the message is really encoded in the final string. </p>

<p style='text-align:justify'>Given two strings <i>s</i> and <i>t</i>, you have
to decide whether <i>s</i> is a subsequence of <i>t</i>, i.e. if you can remove
characters from <i>t</i> such that the concatenation of the remaining
characters is <i>s</i>. </p>

<p style='text-align:justify'><b>Input Specification</b> </p>

<p style='text-align:justify'>The input contains several testcases. Each is
specified by two strings <i>s, t</i> of alphanumeric ASCII characters separated
by whitespace. Input is terminated by EOF. </p>

<p style='text-align:justify'><b>Output Specification</b> </p>

<p style='text-align:justify'>For each test case output, if <i>s</i> is a
subsequence of <i>t</i>. </p>

<p style='text-align:justify'><b>Sample Input</b> </p>

<pre style='text-align:justify'><span class=GramE>sequence</span> subsequence</pre><pre
style='text-align:justify'><span class=GramE>person</span> compression</pre><pre
style='text-align:justify'>VERDI vivaVittorioEmanueleReDiItalia</pre><pre
style='text-align:justify'><span class=GramE>caseDoesMatter</span> CaseDoesMatter</pre>

<p style='text-align:justify;tab-stops:45.8pt 91.6pt 137.4pt 183.2pt 229.0pt 274.8pt 320.6pt 366.4pt 412.2pt 458.0pt 503.8pt 549.6pt 595.4pt 641.2pt 687.0pt 732.8pt'><b>Sample
Output</b> </p>

<pre style='text-align:justify'>Yes</pre><pre style='text-align:justify'>No</pre><pre
style='text-align:justify'>Yes</pre><pre style='text-align:justify'>No</pre>

<div class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center;tab-stops:45.8pt 91.6pt 137.4pt 183.2pt 229.0pt 274.8pt 320.6pt 366.4pt 412.2pt 458.0pt 503.8pt 549.6pt 595.4pt 641.2pt 687.0pt 732.8pt'>

<hr size=2 width="100%" align=center>

</div>

<p class=MsoNormal style='tab-stops:45.8pt 91.6pt 137.4pt 183.2pt 229.0pt 274.8pt 320.6pt 366.4pt 412.2pt 458.0pt 503.8pt 549.6pt 595.4pt 641.2pt 687.0pt 732.8pt'><b
style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>Source: ULM Local Contest<o:p></o:p></b></p>

<pre style='text-align:justify'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></pre></div>

</body>

</html>

</head>

<body lang=EN-US style='tab-interval:.5in'>

<div class=Section1>

<p class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'><span style='font-size:18.0pt;color:black'>Problem F<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'><span style='font-size:24.0pt;color:black'>Solve It</span></b><b
style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'><span style='mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt;
color:black'><o:p></o:p></span></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center'><b><span
style='color:black'>Input: </span></b><span style='color:black;mso-bidi-font-weight:
bold'>standard input<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center'><b><span
style='color:black'>Output: </span></b><span style='color:black'>standard
output<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center'><b><span
style='color:black'>Time Limit:</span></b><span style='color:black'> 1 second<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center'>Memory Limit: 32 MB<span
style='color:black'><o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p>Solve the equation:<br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<i><span style='font-family:
"Courier New"'>p</span></i><span style='font-family:"Courier New"'>*e<sup>-<i>x</i>
</sup>+ <i>q</i>*sin(<i>x</i>) + <i>r</i>*cos(<i>x</i>) + <i>s</i>*tan(<i>x</i>)
+ <i>t</i>*<i>x</i><sup>2</sup> + <i>u</i> = 0<br>
</span>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;where <span
style='font-family:"Courier New"'>0 &lt;= <i>x</i> &lt;= 1</span>.</p>

<h3><span style='font-size:18.0pt'>Input<o:p></o:p></span></h3>

<p>Input consists of multiple test cases and terminated by an EOF. Each test
case consists of 6 integers in a single line: <i><span style='font-family:"Courier New"'>p</span></i>,
<i><span style='font-family:"Courier New"'>q</span></i>, <i><span
style='font-family:"Courier New"'>r</span></i>, <i><span style='font-family:
"Courier New"'>s</span></i>, <i><span style='font-family:"Courier New"'>t</span></i>
and <i><span style='font-family:"Courier New"'>u</span></i> (where <span
style='font-family:"Courier New"'>0 &lt;= <i>p</i></span><span class=GramE>,<i><span
style='font-family:"Courier New"'>r</span></i></span><span style='font-family:
"Courier New"'> &lt;= 20</span> and <span style='font-family:"Courier New"'>-20
&lt;= <i>q</i></span>,<i><span style='font-family:"Courier New"'>s</span></i>,<i><span
style='font-family:"Courier New"'>t</span></i><span style='font-family:"Courier New"'>
&lt;= 0</span>). There will be maximum 2100 lines in the input file.</p>

<h3><span style='font-size:18.0pt'>Output<o:p></o:p></span></h3>

<p>For each set of input, there should be a line containing the value of <i><span
style='font-family:"Courier New"'>x</span></i>, correct upto 4 decimal places,
or the string &quot;<span style='font-family:"Courier New"'>No solution</span>&quot;,
whichever is applicable. </p>

<h3><span style='font-size:18.0pt'>Sample Input<o:p></o:p></span></h3>

<pre>0 0 0 0 -2 1</pre><pre>1 0 0 0 -1 2</pre><pre>1 -1 1 -1 -1 1</pre>

<h3 style='tab-stops:45.8pt 91.6pt 137.4pt 183.2pt 229.0pt 274.8pt 320.6pt 366.4pt 412.2pt 458.0pt 503.8pt 549.6pt 595.4pt 641.2pt 687.0pt 732.8pt'><span
style='font-size:18.0pt'>Sample Output<o:p></o:p></span></h3>

<pre>0.7071</pre><pre>No solution</pre><pre>0.7554</pre>

<div class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center;tab-stops:45.8pt 91.6pt 137.4pt 183.2pt 229.0pt 274.8pt 320.6pt 366.4pt 412.2pt 458.0pt 503.8pt 549.6pt 595.4pt 641.2pt 687.0pt 732.8pt'>

<hr size=2 width="100%" align=center>

</div>

<p class=MsoNormal style='tab-stops:45.8pt 91.6pt 137.4pt 183.2pt 229.0pt 274.8pt 320.6pt 366.4pt 412.2pt 458.0pt 503.8pt 549.6pt 595.4pt 641.2pt 687.0pt 732.8pt'><b
style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>Mustaq Ahmed<i style='mso-bidi-font-style:
normal'><o:p></o:p></i></b></p>

</div>

</body>

</html>

______________________________________________________
10342||||||false||||||
<html>
<head>
	<title>Always Late</title>
</head>

<body>
<div align="center">
<h1>Always Late</h1>
</div>

<table>

<tr><td valign="top">Ajmat:</td><td align="justify" valign="top">
Have you noticed one member of team 13 comes late in almost every contest?
</td></tr>

<tr><td valign="top">Nejhum:&nbsp;&nbsp;</td><td align="justify" valign="top">
You mean the team of Mahbub, Moazzem and Yeamin? What's the problem with them?
</td></tr>

<tr><td valign="top">Ajmat:</td><td align="justify" valign="top">
All of them lives far away from BUET, and they always avoid the shortest path to BUET.
</td></tr>

<tr><td valign="top">Nejhum:</td><td align="justify" valign="top">
Are you kidding? Why would they do so? A computer science student won't ever do that.
</td></tr>

<tr><td valign="top">Ajmat:</td><td align="justify" valign="top">
They <i>always</i> avoids the shortest path. They believe that they always face the worst traffic jam on their shortest way to BUET.
</td></tr>

<tr><td valign="top">Nejhum:</td><td align="justify" valign="top">
That sounds crazy!
</td></tr>

<tr><td valign="top">Ajmat:</td><td align="justify" valign="top">
They are more crazy than you think they are. They always try to use the path whose length is smaller than or equal to that of any path to BUET except the shortest one. And for that, they sometimes visit the same junction more than once.
</td></tr>

<tr><td valign="top">Nejhum:</td><td align="justify" valign="top">
But they are not using the longest path. Then why are they late almost everyday?
</td></tr>

<tr><td valign="top">Ajmat:</td><td align="justify" valign="top">
That's because they have to spend a lot of time to find out which of the paths meet their criteria. Perhaps they don't know how to find out the second-shortest path.
</td></tr>

<tr><td valign="top">Nejhum:</td><td align="justify" valign="top">
I think we should solve this <i>real</i> problem in today's contest, instead of solving imaginary ones.
</td></tr>

<tr><td valign="top">Ajmat:</td><td align="justify" valign="top">
Let's try.
</td></tr>

</table>

<h3>Input</h3>

<div align="justify">
The first line of each test case contains two integers: <i>n</i> (the number of junctions, 1 &lt; <i>n</i> &lt; 100) and <i>r</i> (the number of bi-directional roads connecting these junctions). The junctions are numbered with 0, 1, ..., <i>n</i>-1. Each of the next <i>r</i> lines (one for each road) contains three integers: two junction-numbers that the corresponding road connects and the length of the road in kilometers. The next line contains an integer <i>q</i>, the number of queries. Each of the next <i>q</i> lines contains two junction-numbers. There is a blank line after the <i>q</i> queries. There is at most 1 road between each junction pair. A road always connects two different junctions. Length of a road is not less than 1km and not more than 100km.<br>
&nbsp;<br>
</div>

<div align="justify">
Input is terminated by EOF.<br>
&nbsp;<br>
</div>


<h3>Output</h3>

<div align="justify">
For each set of output, print the set # (1, 2, 
 ) followed by <i>q</i> lines, one for each query, each containing the length of the second-shortest path between the corresponding junctions. However, for the unsolvable queries, print a '?'.<br>
&nbsp;<br>
</div>

<div align="center">
<table width="60%"><tr>
<td valign="top">
<h3>Sample Input</h3>
<pre>
4 3
0 1 12
0 2 20
1 2 15
3
0 1
0 2
0 3

4 3
0 1 11
0 2 20
1 2 15
3
0 1
0 2
0 3</pre>
</td>
<td valign="top">
<h3>Sample Output</h3>
<pre>
Set #1
35
27
?
Set #2
33
26
?</pre></td>
</tr>
</table>
</div>

<hr>
<i>Mustaq Ahmed. 12-07-2002.</i>
</body>
</html>

______________________________________________________
10343||||||false||||||

xmlns:o="urn:schemas-microsoft-com:office:office"
xmlns:w="urn:schemas-microsoft-com:office:word"
xmlns="http://www.w3.org/TR/REC-html40">

<head>
<meta http-equiv=Content-Type content="text/html; charset=us-ascii">

<!--[if !mso]>
<style>
v\:* {behavior:url(#default#VML);}
o\:* {behavior:url(#default#VML);}
w\:* {behavior:url(#default#VML);}
.shape {behavior:url(#default#VML);}
</style>
<![endif]--><!--[if gte mso 9]><xml>
 <o:DocumentProperties>

  <o:Revision>9</o:Revision>
  <o:TotalTime>3</o:TotalTime>
  <o:Created>2002-07-24T06:18:00Z</o:Created>

  <o:Pages>1</o:Pages>

 </o:DocumentProperties>

<style>
<!--
 /* Style Definitions */
 p.MsoNormal, li.MsoNormal, div.MsoNormal
	{mso-style-parent:" ;
	margin:0in;
	margin-bottom:.0001pt;
	mso-pagination:widow-orphan;
	font-size:12.0pt;
	font-family:"Times New Roman";
	mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman";}

	{margin:0in;
	margin-bottom:.0001pt;
	mso-pagination:widow-orphan;
	font-size:10.0pt;
	font-family:"Courier New";
	mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman";}
span.GramE
	{mso-style-name:" ;
	mso-gram-e:yes;}
