<body lang=EN-US style='tab-interval:.5in'>

<div class=Section1>

<p class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center'><b><span
style='font-size:18.0pt;color:black'>Problem F</span></b><span
style='color:black'><br>
</span><b><span style='font-size:24.0pt;color:black'>Love Calculator </span></b><span
style='color:black'><br>
<b>Input:</b> standard input<br>
<b>Output:</b> standard output<br>
<b>Time Limit:</b> 2 seconds<br style='mso-special-character:line-break'>
<![if !supportLineBreakNewLine]><br style='mso-special-character:line-break'>
<![endif]></span></p>

<u7:p></u7:p>

<p class=MsoNormal><b><span style='font-size:18.0pt;mso-bidi-font-family:Arial;
color:black'>Background<u7:p></u7:p></span></b></p>

<p class=MsoBodyText2><span style='color:black'>One day I asked Saima that how much
she loves me. Her answer was &quot;71.43 %&quot;. I was surprised as well as
shocked by her answer. I could not understand why she didn't tell 100% and why
she told a particular and peculiar fraction like 71.43. Looking at my
surprised, shocked and nervous face she burst out laughing and told that she
loves me more than any thing in this universe and it was nothing but a silly
and funny love calculation. Then she described me the calculation. In this
problem you will have to write a program so that any one can calculate love
between any two persons very quickly (of course a very silly game).<span
style='mso-spacerun:yes'>   </span><span style='mso-spacerun:yes'> </span><u7:p></u7:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bidi-font-family:Arial;color:black'>&nbsp;<u7:p></u7:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><b><span style='font-size:18.0pt;mso-bidi-font-family:Arial;
color:black'>Rules<u7:p></u7:p></span></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='mso-bidi-font-family:
Arial;color:black'>You will be given two names. These two names can have white
space or some other non-alphabetical characters like $ @ &amp; % etc. But only
the alphabets from a to z or A to Z will participate in love calculation. Each
alphabet has a particular value. The values are from 1 to 26 in ascending order
of the alphabets. Its like this, a = 1, b = 2, c = 3........ z = 26. Both upper
case and lower case holds the same values. Then make the sum of these numbers
until it comes in one digit.[ For example, consider a name 'bcz'. Here, b = 2,
c = 3 &amp; z = 26. So, the sum is (2+3+26) = 31 = (3+1) = 4.] Then the ratio
of these two numbers in percentage will be the result.<u7:p></u7:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='mso-bidi-font-family:
Arial;color:black'>&nbsp;<u7:p></u7:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoBodyText3>Remember : Result can not be more than 100 % . Take the
ratio carefully to avoid this problem. </p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-bidi-font-family:Arial;color:black'><span
style='mso-spacerun:yes'> </span><u7:p></u7:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><b><span style='font-size:18.0pt;mso-bidi-font-family:Arial;
color:black'>Input<u7:p></u7:p></span></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='mso-bidi-font-family:
Arial;color:black'>Your input will be two names. Each name holds not more than
25 characters. End of file will indicate the end of input.<u7:p></u7:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><b><span style='font-size:18.0pt;mso-bidi-font-family:Arial;
color:black'>&nbsp;<u7:p></u7:p></span></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><b><span style='font-size:18.0pt;mso-bidi-font-family:Arial;
color:black'>Output<u7:p></u7:p></span></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='mso-bidi-font-family:
Arial;color:black'>For each pair of names your program will have to calculate
the love between those two persons and give the result as output. In result two
digits to be displayed after the decimal point. All the results must be in new
lines.<u7:p></u7:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='mso-bidi-font-family:
Arial;color:black'><span style='mso-spacerun:yes'> </span><span
style='mso-spacerun:yes'> </span><u7:p></u7:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><b><span style='font-size:18.0pt;mso-bidi-font-family:Arial;
color:black'>Sample input<u7:p></u7:p></span></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span style='font-size:11.0pt;font-family:"Courier New";
color:black'>saima<u7:p></u7:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span style='font-size:11.0pt;font-family:"Courier New";
color:black'>shanto<u7:p></u7:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><st1:country-region><st1:place><span style='font-size:11.0pt;
  font-family:"Courier New";color:black'>Pakistan<u7:p></u7:p></span></st1:place></st1:country-region></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><st1:country-region><st1:place><span style='font-size:11.0pt;
  font-family:"Courier New";color:black'>India<u7:p></u7:p></span></st1:place></st1:country-region></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><st1:country-region><st1:place><span style='font-size:11.0pt;
  font-family:"Courier New";color:black'>USA<u7:p></u7:p></span></st1:place></st1:country-region></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><st1:country-region><st1:place><span style='font-size:11.0pt;
  font-family:"Courier New";color:black'>USSR<u7:p></u7:p></span></st1:place></st1:country-region><o:p></o:p></p>

<h1><u7:p></u7:p>Sample output</h1>

<p class=MsoNormal style='tab-stops:31.0pt 77.0pt 122.0pt 168.0pt 214.0pt 260.0pt 305.0pt 351.0pt 397.0pt 443.0pt 488.0pt 534.0pt 580.0pt 626.0pt 672.0pt 718.0pt'><span
style='font-size:11.0pt;font-family:"Courier New";color:black'>71.43 %<u7:p></u7:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='tab-stops:31.0pt 77.0pt 122.0pt 168.0pt 214.0pt 260.0pt 305.0pt 351.0pt 397.0pt 443.0pt 488.0pt 534.0pt 580.0pt 626.0pt 672.0pt 718.0pt'><span
style='font-size:11.0pt;font-family:"Courier New";color:black'>100.00 %<u7:p></u7:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span style='font-size:11.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:12.0pt;
font-family:"Courier New";color:black'>100.00 %<u7:p></u7:p></span></p>

<div class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center'><span
style='color:black'>

<hr size=2 width="100%" align=center>

</span></div>

<p class=MsoCaption><span style='color:black'>Problem setter: Niaz Morshed
Chowdhury (Shanto), East West University, Dhaka<u7:p></u7:p><o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></p>

<p class=MsoBodyText style='mso-layout-grid-align:auto'><b><span
style='mso-bidi-font-size:12.0pt'>Hmm! Even love calculators have floating
point variables!! Strange!!!<u7:p></u7:p></span></b></p>

<p class=MsoBodyText style='mso-layout-grid-align:auto'><b><span
style='mso-bidi-font-size:12.0pt'>Should we really try to calculate love? Someone
(or two) may become <u7:p></u7:p></span></b></p>

<p class=MsoBodyText style='mso-layout-grid-align:auto'><b><span
style='mso-bidi-font-size:12.0pt'>happy to get a score of 100%. But when one
sees the second and <u7:p></u7:p></span></b></p>

<p class=MsoBodyText style='mso-layout-grid-align:auto'><b><span
style='mso-bidi-font-size:12.0pt'>third sample input and the corresponding
output one must <u7:p></u7:p></span></b></p>

<p class=MsoBodyText style='mso-layout-grid-align:auto'><b><span
style='mso-bidi-font-size:12.0pt'>think the less the better :-)<u7:p></u7:p></span></b></p>

</div>

</body>

<title>Problem G - Mobile Destroyer</title>

<body lang=EN-US style='tab-interval:.5in'>

<div class=Section1>

<p class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center'><b><span
style='font-size:18.0pt;color:black'>Problem G</span></b><span
style='color:black'><br>
</span><b><span style='font-size:24.0pt;mso-font-kerning:18.0pt'>Mobile
Destroyer</span></b><b><span style='font-size:24.0pt;color:black'><o:p></o:p></span></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center;mso-layout-grid-align:
none;text-autospace:none'><b><span style='color:black'>Input:</span></b><span
style='color:black'> standard input<br>
<b>Output:</b> standard output<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center;mso-layout-grid-align:
none;text-autospace:none'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'><span
style='color:black'>Time Limit: </span></b><span style='color:black;mso-bidi-font-weight:
bold'>2</span><span style='color:black'> seconds</span><span style='font-size:
10.0pt;font-family:"Courier New";color:black'><o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p style='text-align:justify'>Year 2020.</p>

<p style='text-align:justify'>In order to reduce the use of stolen mobile sets
in Dhaka city, DMP is planning to place two Advanced Mobile Destroyers (AMDs)
on two tall towers of the city. Each AMD has a sphere of action. If a stolen
mobile set is found within this sphere (even on the boundary), the AMD erases
the mobile set's flash memory, making the set useless.</p>

<p style='text-align:justify'>But there is a bug in the program of the AMD itself:
If a stolen set is on the plane passing through the common points of the
boundaries of the spheres of two AMDs, no AMD takes any action at all!</p>

<p style='text-align:justify'>Given the position &amp; the radius of the sphere
of two AMDs and the position of a stolen set, you are to determine the fate of
the set.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='mso-layout-grid-align:none;text-autospace:none'><b
style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'><span style='font-size:18.0pt;color:black'>Input<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>

<p style='text-align:justify'>Input consists of several test cases.</p>

<p style='text-align:justify'>Each case consists of case name followed by 11
integers on the same line. The case name contains exactly 5 alphanumeric characters.
The first 4 integers are the position <span style='font-family:Courier'>(x,y,z)</span>
and the radius <span style='font-family:Courier'>r</span> of the sphere of
AMD#1. Next 4 integers are the position <span style='font-family:Courier'>(x,y,z)</span>
and the radius <span style='font-family:Courier'>r</span> of the sphere of
AMD#2. The last 3 integers are the position <span style='font-family:Courier'>(x,y,z)</span>
of the stolen set. Each integer in the input is smaller than <span
style='font-family:Courier'>32000</span> in absolute value. The two spheres of
action always intersect each other.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='mso-layout-grid-align:none;text-autospace:none'><b
style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'><span style='font-size:18.0pt;color:black'>Output<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>

<p>For each data set, print 4 lines.</p>

<p>The first line gives the case name. The second line &amp; third line
indicates whether the stolen set is within the range of AMD#1 &amp; AMD#2
respectively (<span style='font-family:Courier'>'y'</span> if within range, <span
style='font-family:Courier'>'n'</span> otherwise). The fourth line is <span
style='font-family:Courier'>'y'</span> if the stolen set has been made useless,
<span style='font-family:Courier'>'n'</span> otherwise.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='mso-layout-grid-align:none;text-autospace:none'><b
style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'><span style='font-size:18.0pt;color:black'>Sample
Input<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>

<pre>Dhk01 0 0 0 8 10 0 0 8 5 5 5</pre><pre>Dhk02 0 0 0 8 10 0 0 8 5 0 0</pre><pre>Dhk03 0 0 0 8 10 0 0 8 0 8 0</pre>

<p class=MsoNormal style='tab-stops:45.8pt 91.6pt 137.4pt 183.2pt 229.0pt 274.8pt 320.6pt 366.4pt 412.2pt 458.0pt 503.8pt 549.6pt 595.4pt 641.2pt 687.0pt 732.8pt;
mso-layout-grid-align:none;text-autospace:none'><span style='font-size:11.0pt;
font-family:"Courier New";color:black'><![if !supportEmptyParas]>&nbsp;<![endif]><o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='tab-stops:45.8pt 91.6pt 137.4pt 183.2pt 229.0pt 274.8pt 320.6pt 366.4pt 412.2pt 458.0pt 503.8pt 549.6pt 595.4pt 641.2pt 687.0pt 732.8pt;
mso-layout-grid-align:none;text-autospace:none'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'><span style='font-size:18.0pt;color:black'>Sample Output<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>

<pre>Dhk01</pre><pre>n</pre><pre>n</pre><pre>n</pre><pre>Dhk02</pre><pre>y</pre><pre>y</pre><pre>n</pre><pre>Dhk03</pre><pre>y</pre><pre>n</pre><pre>y</pre>

<div class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center;tab-stops:45.8pt 91.6pt 137.4pt 183.2pt 229.0pt 274.8pt 320.6pt 366.4pt 412.2pt 458.0pt 503.8pt 549.6pt 595.4pt 641.2pt 687.0pt 732.8pt'><span
style='color:black'>

<hr size=2 width="100%" align=center>

</span></div>


<p class=MsoNormal style='tab-stops:45.8pt 91.6pt 137.4pt 183.2pt 229.0pt 274.8pt 320.6pt 366.4pt 412.2pt 458.0pt 503.8pt 549.6pt 595.4pt 641.2pt 687.0pt 732.8pt'><b
style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'><span style='color:black'>Problem setter:
Mustaq Ahmed, University of Waterloo, Canada<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='tab-stops:45.8pt 91.6pt 137.4pt 183.2pt 229.0pt 274.8pt 320.6pt 366.4pt 412.2pt 458.0pt 503.8pt 549.6pt 595.4pt 641.2pt 687.0pt 732.8pt;
mso-layout-grid-align:none;text-autospace:none'><span style='font-size:11.0pt;
font-family:"Courier New";color:black'><![if !supportEmptyParas]>&nbsp;<![endif]><o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='tab-stops:45.8pt 91.6pt 137.4pt 183.2pt 229.0pt 274.8pt 320.6pt 366.4pt 412.2pt 458.0pt 503.8pt 549.6pt 595.4pt 641.2pt 687.0pt 732.8pt;
mso-layout-grid-align:none;text-autospace:none'><span style='font-size:10.0pt;
font-family:"Courier New";color:black'><![if !supportEmptyParas]>&nbsp;<![endif]><o:p></o:p></span></p>

<h1>All the mobile thieves of Dhaka and Waterloo are now spending</h1>

<p class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center;tab-stops:45.8pt 91.6pt 137.4pt 183.2pt 229.0pt 274.8pt 320.6pt 366.4pt 412.2pt 458.0pt 503.8pt 549.6pt 595.4pt 641.2pt 687.0pt 732.8pt'><b><span
style='color:black'>a lot of time in reading coordinate geometry and vectors
:-)<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center;tab-stops:45.8pt 91.6pt 137.4pt 183.2pt 229.0pt 274.8pt 320.6pt 366.4pt 412.2pt 458.0pt 503.8pt 549.6pt 595.4pt 641.2pt 687.0pt 732.8pt'><b><span
style='color:black'>but I hope the vice versa is not true :-)))<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>

</div>

</body>

</html>

<!--[if gte mso 9]><xml>
 <o:shapedefaults v:ext="edit" spidmax="1027">
  <o:colormru v:ext="edit" colors="#602000"/>
 </o:shapedefaults></xml><![endif]--><!--[if gte mso 9]><xml>
 <o:shapelayout v:ext="edit">
  <o:idmap v:ext="edit" data="1"/>
 </o:shapelayout></xml><![endif]--><o:SmartTagType namespaceuri="urn:schemas-microsoft-com:office:smarttags" name="country-region"/><o:SmartTagType namespaceuri="urn:schemas-microsoft-com:office:smarttags" name="place"/>

<body lang=EN-US link="#6633cc" vlink=purple style='tab-interval:.5in'>

<div class=Section1>

<p class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center'><b><span
style='font-size:18.0pt;color:windowtext'>Problem H</span></b><span
style='color:windowtext'><br>
</span><b><span style='font-size:24.0pt;mso-font-kerning:18.0pt'>Knights'
Nightmare</span></b><span style='color:windowtext'><br>
<b>Input:</b> standard input<br>
<b>Output:</b> standard output<br>
<b>Time Limit:</b> 5 seconds<br style='mso-special-character:line-break'>
<![if !supportLineBreakNewLine]><br style='mso-special-character:line-break'>
<![endif]><o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoBodyText2><span style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>The people of
the remote country KnightLand are crazy about chess. They play chess whenever they
get some free time. They have even divided their land into adjacent equal sized
squares just like a chessboard. They like the knight of chess so much that they
always go from one place to another following a knight's trail, even if it
takes a lot of time and energy. In a minute, a KnightLander can make only one
jump from one square to another like a knight. <o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p style='text-align:justify'>For the past few years, the people of KnightLand
are facing a serious problem. A monster has appeared in one of the squares of
KnightLand. When it is awake, it eats anyone who enters its square. The good
thing is, the monster doesn't move from one square to another and loves to
sleep. If one enters its square while it is sleeping, it wakes up and forgets
for a year how to sleep. It is remains sleepy for a minute and cannot do any
harm to anyone in this time. It then starts eating anyone it gets in its
square. Therefore, the person who makes it awake can escape safely from it. But
if one comes to that square later, he dies a terrible death. </p>

<p style='text-align:justify'>In order to solve the problem, the 4 leaders of
KnightLand are planning to meet together. They want to find a square that can
be reached safely and as quickly as possible from the squares where they line
in. To be extra careful, they decided that there should not be more than 1 jump
in a minute in the whole KnightLand. Now, they want to find out if it is at all
possible to meet at any square, and the minimum time required to get there. </p>

<p style='text-align:justify'>Can you help them? </p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:18.0pt;
color:windowtext'>Input</span></b><span style='mso-bidi-font-size:12.0pt;
color:windowtext'><o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'>Input consists of multiple test
cases and terminated by an EOF. Each test case consists of 4 lines. The first
line contains the string &quot;Set#<i>n</i>&quot;, where <i>n</i> is the set
number. The second line contains number of rows <i>r</i> and number of columns <i>c</i>
of squares in KnightLand's map (where 3 &lt;= <i>r</i> &lt;= 16 and 3 &lt;= <i>c</i>
&lt;= 16). The third line contains position of each leader in the map, in terms
of row# and column# of each. The fourth line gives the position of the monster.
Note that the square at the upper left corner of the map has (row#,column#) =
(1,1). You may assume that no leader resides in the same square as the monster.
</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]>&nbsp;<![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:18.0pt;
color:windowtext'>Output</span></b><span style='mso-bidi-font-size:12.0pt;
color:windowtext'><o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'>For each set of input, there
should be 2 lines of output. The first line should contain the string
&quot;Set#<i>n</i>&quot;, where <i>n</i> is the set number. The second line
should give the minimum time in minutes needed to reach a square (in format
shown below), or the string &quot;Meeting is impossible.&quot;, whichever is
applicable.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'>&nbsp;</p>

<pre><b><span style='font-size:18.0pt;font-family:"Times New Roman"'>Sample Input</span></b><span
style='mso-bidi-font-size:12.0pt;font-family:"Times New Roman"'></span></pre><pre><span style='mso-bidi-font-size:12.0pt;
font-family:"Times New Roman"'><![if !supportEmptyParas]>&nbsp;<![endif]><o:p></o:p></span></pre><pre><span
style='mso-bidi-font-size:12.0pt;font-family:"Times New Roman"'><![if !supportEmptyParas]>&nbsp;<![endif]><o:p></o:p></span></pre><pre><span
style='font-size:11.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt'>Set#1<o:p></o:p></span></pre><pre><span
style='font-size:11.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt'>5 5<o:p></o:p></span></pre><pre><span
style='font-size:11.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt'>1 1 1 5 5 1 4 4<o:p></o:p></span></pre><pre><span
style='font-size:11.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt'>3 3<o:p></o:p></span></pre><pre><span
style='font-size:11.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt'>Set#2<o:p></o:p></span></pre><pre><span
style='font-size:11.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt'>3 3<o:p></o:p></span></pre><pre><span
style='font-size:11.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt'>1 1 1 2 1 3 2 2<o:p></o:p></span></pre><pre><span
style='font-size:11.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt'>3 2</span><span lang=EN
style='font-size:11.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt;mso-ansi-language:EN'><o:p></o:p></span></pre><pre><span
style='font-size:12.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:18.0pt;font-family:"Times New Roman"'><![if !supportEmptyParas]>&nbsp;<![endif]><o:p></o:p></span></pre><pre><b><span
style='font-size:18.0pt;font-family:"Times New Roman"'>Sample Output</span></b><span
style='mso-bidi-font-size:12.0pt'><br>
</span><span style='font-size:11.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt'>Set#1<o:p></o:p></span></pre><pre><span
style='font-size:11.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt'>Minimum time required is 6 minutes.<o:p></o:p></span></pre><pre><span
style='font-size:11.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt'>Set#2<o:p></o:p></span></pre>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:12.0pt;tab-stops:45.8pt 91.6pt 137.4pt 183.2pt 229.0pt 274.8pt 320.6pt 366.4pt 412.2pt 458.0pt 503.8pt 549.6pt 595.4pt 641.2pt 687.0pt 732.8pt'><span
style='font-size:11.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt;font-family:"Courier New"'>Meeting
is impossible.</span><span style='mso-bidi-font-size:12.0pt;font-family:Courier;
color:windowtext'><o:p></o:p></span></p>

<div class=MsoNormal align=center style='margin-bottom:12.0pt;text-align:center;
tab-stops:45.8pt 91.6pt 137.4pt 183.2pt 229.0pt 274.8pt 320.6pt 366.4pt 412.2pt 458.0pt 503.8pt 549.6pt 595.4pt 641.2pt 687.0pt 732.8pt'><span
style='mso-bidi-font-size:12.0pt;font-family:Courier;color:windowtext'>

<hr size=2 width="100%" align=center>

</span></div>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:12.0pt;tab-stops:45.8pt 91.6pt 137.4pt 183.2pt 229.0pt 274.8pt 320.6pt 366.4pt 412.2pt 458.0pt 503.8pt 549.6pt 595.4pt 641.2pt 687.0pt 732.8pt'><b>Problem
setter: Mustaq Ahmed, University of Waterloo, Canada<o:p></o:p></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-bottom:12.0pt;tab-stops:45.8pt 91.6pt 137.4pt 183.2pt 229.0pt 274.8pt 320.6pt 366.4pt 412.2pt 458.0pt 503.8pt 549.6pt 595.4pt 641.2pt 687.0pt 732.8pt'><b><![if !supportEmptyParas]>&nbsp;<![endif]><o:p></o:p></b></p>

<h2>To make a very good problem (To generate a good idea, writing an error
free</h2>

<h2>statement and solution) one needs at least 3/4 days of time. The situation</h2>

<h2>gets even worse when one is asked to set problem from a particular</h2>

<h2>field. I hope the non-problem setters will understand it soon.<span
style='mso-bidi-font-size:12.0pt;font-family:Courier;color:windowtext'><o:p></o:p></span></h2>

</div>

</body>

</html>

______________________________________________________

<title>Problem I - Naughty Sleepy Boys</title>

<style>

<!--[if gte mso 9]><xml>
 <o:shapedefaults v:ext="edit" spidmax="1027"/>
</xml><![endif]--><!--[if gte mso 9]><xml>
 <o:shapelayout v:ext="edit">
  <o:idmap v:ext="edit" data="1"/>
 </o:shapelayout></xml><![endif]-->
</head>

<body lang=EN-US style='tab-interval:.5in'>

<div class=Section1>

<p class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center'><b><span
style='font-size:18.0pt'>Problem I</span></b><br>
<b><span style='font-size:24.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:12.0pt'>Naughty Sleepy Boys</span></b><b><span
style='font-size:24.0pt'><o:p></o:p></span></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center'><b>Input:</b>
standard input<br>
<b>Output:</b> standard output<br>
<b>Time Limit:</b> 2 seconds<br style='mso-special-character:line-break'>
<![if !supportLineBreakNewLine]><br style='mso-special-character:line-break'>
<![endif]></p>

<p class=MsoBodyText>Hasan and Tanveer are two naughty boys of the class. They
spent most of their class time playing `Tic Tac Toe' whenever they get a chance
to sit in back bench. But their teacher doesn't think that playing cross and
naught is a way of making a class enjoyable. So, whenever she sees them playing
she brings them to the front seat and makes them hear what she says. And you
know listening to the teacher is not as enjoyable as playing `Tic Tac Toe'. So,
within a couple of minutes, their eyes become dizzy and they fall into sleep
resting their heads on the table. The teacher notices that and exclaims, ``You
two naughty boys! Come over here.'' and she gives them some problem to solve
which is lengthy and cumbersome. They try all the time not to get caught by the
teacher while playing, or, for the least, not to get sleepy. But, pity for
them, they hardly escapes the eagle eye of the teacher. Now, they are again
caught red handed, brought to front bench, and as you know the usual case, they
become sleepy. (poor Hasan and Tanveer! Couldn't the teacher be a little bit
sympathetic to them?) This time the teacher is very angry and gives them a
problem which is really too much for them. She asks them if she writes down the
numbers from 1 to 1000 one after another what will be the 1000-th digit. You
see what a tough problem for two little boys. Alam and Dalim start thinking
that if they write down all the numbers like 1234567891011121314 ... ... it
will take many hours for them. Moreover, the answer will possibly be incorrect
because they can easily lose track of the numbers written. So, they are trying
to find out a way to fool the teacher with the right answer. Can you find a way
out for them?</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><b><span style='font-size:18.0pt'>&nbsp;<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><b><span style='font-size:18.0pt'>Input</span></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'>The input will contain one or
more line each containing a positive integer N (N&lt;100000000). Total line of
the input file will not exceed 11000.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal><b><span style='mso-bidi-font-size:18.0pt'>&nbsp;<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><b><span style='font-size:18.0pt'>Output</span></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'>For every N, you should calculate
the N-th digit of the number 123456789101112 ... ... and print it on a line
itself.<span style='color:black;mso-bidi-font-weight:bold'><o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'>&nbsp;</p>

<pre><b><span style='font-size:18.0pt;font-family:"Times New Roman"'>Sample Input</span></b><br
style='mso-special-character:line-break'>
</pre><pre><span style='font-size:11.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt'>3<o:p></o:p></span></pre><pre><span
style='font-size:11.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt'>9<o:p></o:p></span></pre><pre><span
style='font-size:11.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt'>10<o:p></o:p></span></pre><pre><span
style='font-size:11.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt'>11<o:p></o:p></span></pre><pre><span
style='font-size:11.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt'>10000<o:p></o:p></span></pre><pre><span
style='font-size:11.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt'>50000</span></pre>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'>&nbsp;<span style='font-size:
18.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:12.0pt'><o:p></o:p></span></p>

<pre><b><span style='font-size:18.0pt;font-family:"Times New Roman"'>Sample Output</span></b><br
style='mso-special-character:line-break'>
</pre><pre><span style='font-size:11.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt'>3<o:p></o:p></span></pre><pre><span
style='font-size:11.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt'>9<o:p></o:p></span></pre><pre><span
style='font-size:11.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt'>1<o:p></o:p></span></pre><pre><span
style='font-size:11.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt'>0<o:p></o:p></span></pre><pre><span
style='font-size:11.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt'>7<o:p></o:p></span></pre>

<p class=MsoNormal><span style='font-size:11.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:12.0pt'>1</span>&nbsp;</p>


<div class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center'>

<hr size=2 width="100%" align=center>

</div>


<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify;tab-stops:45.8pt 91.6pt 137.4pt 183.2pt 229.0pt 274.8pt 320.6pt 366.4pt 412.2pt 458.0pt 503.8pt 549.6pt 595.4pt 641.2pt 687.0pt 732.8pt'><b
style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>Problem-setter: Tanveer &amp; Tahseen, <ST1:PLACE><ST1:PLACETYPE>Eastwest
University, Dhaka<o:p></o:p></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify;tab-stops:45.8pt 91.6pt 137.4pt 183.2pt 229.0pt 274.8pt 320.6pt 366.4pt 412.2pt 458.0pt 503.8pt 549.6pt 595.4pt 641.2pt 687.0pt 732.8pt'><b
style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'><![if !supportEmptyParas]>&nbsp;<![endif]><o:p></o:p></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify;tab-stops:45.8pt 91.6pt 137.4pt 183.2pt 229.0pt 274.8pt 320.6pt 366.4pt 412.2pt 458.0pt 503.8pt 549.6pt 595.4pt 641.2pt 687.0pt 732.8pt'><b
style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'><![if !supportEmptyParas]>&nbsp;<![endif]><o:p></o:p></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify;tab-stops:45.8pt 91.6pt 137.4pt 183.2pt 229.0pt 274.8pt 320.6pt 366.4pt 412.2pt 458.0pt 503.8pt 549.6pt 595.4pt 641.2pt 687.0pt 732.8pt'><b
style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'><![if !supportEmptyParas]>&nbsp;<![endif]><o:p></o:p></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center;tab-stops:45.8pt 91.6pt 137.4pt 183.2pt 229.0pt 274.8pt 320.6pt 366.4pt 412.2pt 458.0pt 503.8pt 549.6pt 595.4pt 641.2pt 687.0pt 732.8pt'><b
style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>Playing tic-tac-toe is not that bad
actually. It helps you <o:p></o:p></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center;tab-stops:45.8pt 91.6pt 137.4pt 183.2pt 229.0pt 274.8pt 320.6pt 366.4pt 412.2pt 458.0pt 503.8pt 549.6pt 595.4pt 641.2pt 687.0pt 732.8pt'><b
style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>to understand game trees :-)</b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal>&nbsp;</p>

</div>

</body>

  <o:idmap v:ext="edit" data="1"/>
 </o:shapelayout></xml><![endif]-->

<body lang=EN-US style='tab-interval:.5in'>

<div class=Section1>

<p class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center'><b><span
style='font-size:18.0pt'>Problem J</span></b><br>
<b><span style='font-size:24.0pt'>The Roots</span></b><br>
<b>Input:</b> standard input<br>
<b>Output:</b> standard output<br>
<b>Time Limit:</b> 15 seconds<span style='color:blue'><o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='mso-bidi-font-size:
10.0pt;color:black'>A polynomial equation has the following form:<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:16.0pt;
color:black'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:16.0pt;
color:black'><span style='mso-spacerun:yes'>                 </span>a<sub>n</sub>x<sup>n</sup>
+ a<sub>n-1</sub>x<sup>n-1</sup> + a<sub>n-2</sub>x<sup>n-2</sup> + 
 + a<sub>1</sub>x<sup>1</sup>+
a<sub>0</sub> = 0<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='color:black'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='color:black'>Here X
is variable and a<sub>n</sub>, a<sub>n-1</sub></span><sub><span
style='font-size:16.0pt;color:black'> 
</span></sub><span style='color:black'>
etc are known as coefficient.<span style='mso-spacerun:yes'>  </span>So to
specify a polynomial equation we need the values of the coefficients only. The
roots of a polynomial equation are the values of X for which the value of LHS
is zero. In this problem you will have to find the roots of a polynomial
equation. You can assume that a polynomial equation of degree n should have n
real roots and all the roots are strictly different.<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><b><span style='mso-bidi-font-size:18.0pt'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></span></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><b><span style='font-size:18.0pt'>Input</span></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
bold'>The input file contains less than 5001 lines of input. <o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
bold'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
bold'>Each line contains an integer N (N&lt;=5) followed by (N+1) floating
point numbers. Here N is the order of the polynomial equation. The next (N+1)
numbers denote the values of </span><span style='font-size:14.0pt;color:black'>a<sub>n</sub>,
a<sub>n-1</sub>, a<sub>n-2</sub><span style='mso-spacerun:yes'>  </span>
, a<sub>1</sub>
</span><span style='color:black'>and </span><span style='font-size:14.0pt;
color:black'>a<sub>0</sub></span><span style='font-size:14.0pt;mso-bidi-font-weight:
bold'>. </span><span style='mso-bidi-font-weight:bold'>These absolute values of
these coefficients will be less than 1e9 or 1000000000 and the absolute values
of the roots will be less than 25.<span style='mso-spacerun:yes'>  </span>So
each line contains information about one polynomial equation.<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
bold'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
bold'>Input is terminated by a line where N=0.<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
bold'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><b><span style='font-size:18.0pt'>Output</span></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify;mso-layout-grid-align:none;
text-autospace:none'><span style='mso-bidi-font-weight:bold'>For each line of
input produce one line of output. This line starts with the string Equation S:
here S is the output serial number as shown in the sample output. This string
is followed by N floating point numbers, which are the roots of the
corresponding input equation. The roots should be printed in ascending order of
their values and rounded up to four digits after the decimal point. All the
root values are preceded by a single space. The judge input is designed in such
a way that if your precision is relatively low (values less than 1e-10 are
considered as zero) you will face no precision errors. Of course your solution
must be correct and you must be well aware of the limitations of different root
finding methods.<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='mso-layout-grid-align:none;text-autospace:none'><b><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='mso-layout-grid-align:none;text-autospace:none'><b><span
style='font-size:18.0pt'>Sample Input</span></b><span style='font-size:11.0pt;
font-family:"Courier New"'><br>
2 1 -9.5750000000 -179.5585140000<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='mso-layout-grid-align:none;text-autospace:none'><span
style='font-size:11.0pt;font-family:"Courier New"'>4 1 53.3120000000
958.2510390000 6677.1763593480 15733.6254955064<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='mso-layout-grid-align:none;text-autospace:none'><span
style='font-size:11.0pt;font-family:"Courier New"'>0<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><b><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><b><span style='font-size:18.0pt'>Sample Output<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span style='font-size:11.0pt;font-family:"Courier New"'>Equation
1: -9.4420 19.0170<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span style='font-size:11.0pt;font-family:"Courier New"'>Equation
2: -22.8060 -18.1170 -6.7350 -5.6540<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<div class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center'>

<hr size=2 width="100%" align=center>

</div>

<p class=MsoCaption>Problem setter: Shahriar Manzoor, ACM Valladolid Online
Judge Team</p>

<p class=MsoNormal><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></b></p>

<h2>We often say that life is not a fairy tale and so we must be realistic.</h2>

<h2>But have we ever tried to be as innocent as those in fairy tales?</h2>

<h2>Are the villains of our daily life in non-disguised form like</h2>

<h2>those of fairy tales? We cannot change everyone but we </h2>

<h2>must change ourselves to live a fairy tale like life.</h2>

<p class=MsoNormal><o:p>&nbsp;</o:p></p>

</div>

</body>

</html>

______________________________________________________
10429||||||false||||||
<!doctype html public "-//w3c//dtd html 4.0 transitional//en">
<html>
<head>
   <meta http-equiv="Content-Type" content="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">
   <meta name="GENERATOR" content="Microsoft FrontPage 5.0">
   <meta name="Author" content="S. M. Mahbub Murshed">
   <meta name="Description" content="Mohr's Circle">
   <title>Mohr's Circle</title>
<!--Converted with LaTeX2HTML 96.1 (Feb 5, 1996) by Nikos Drakos (nikos@cbl.leeds.ac.uk), CBLU, University of Leeds -->
</head>
<body bgcolor="#FFFFFF" LANG="EN">
<div align="center">
  <center>
  <table BGCOLOR="#CCCCFF" style="border-collapse: collapse" bordercolor="#111111" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" >
<tr>
<td align="center"><font size="+2" color="#000099"><b>Brightness of Brain
Contest </b></font><br><font size="+2" color="#000099">
Problem A</font><br>
<font size="4" color="#000099">Time limit: 1 second Memory: 16 MB</font></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td align="center" bgcolor="#0070E8">
<p align="center"><a NAME="SECTION0001000000000000000000"></a><b>
<font size=+2 color="#C0FFFF">Mohr's Circle</font></b></td>
</tr>
</table></center>
</div>

<h2>
<a NAME="SECTION0001002000000000000000"></a><font color="#0070E8">The Problem</font></h2>
<p>An approach of representing the stresses (force per unit area) on a body is 
the Mohr's Circle - devised by Otto Mohr in 1882. It's a very nice method of 
representing the stresses and analyze where they occur, so it's used widely.</font> 
In this problem we are not concerned with the details of the theory, we will 
just know how to use this device at work.</p>

<h2>
<font color="#0070E8">Drawing Mohr's Circle</font></h2>
<p>Let a stress state is
described by two principle stresses (Load which tries to compress or elongate)
<img border="0" src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/104/p10429a.jpg"  width="22" height="24" align="middle">,
<img border="0" src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/104/p10429a.jpg"  width="20" height="27" align="middle"> and two torsional
stresses (Load which tries to twist)
<img border="0" src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/104/p10429a.jpg"  width="23" height="27" align="middle">,<img border="0" src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/104/p10429a.jpg"  width="24" height="28" align="middle">
as shown in the example below, <i>Figure a</i>.</font> As
<img border="0" src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/104/p10429a.jpg"  width="23" height="27" align="middle">is 
always equal to<img border="0" src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/104/p10429a.jpg"  width="24" height="28" align="middle"> 
but in reverse direction, in the input these will be given as
<img border="0" src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/104/p10429a.jpg"  width="22" height="24" align="middle">,
<img border="0" src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/104/p10429a.jpg"  width="20" height="27" align="middle"> and<img border="0" src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/104/p10429a.jpg"  width="23" height="27" align="middle">.&nbsp; 
Thus input for the following condition is (32, -10, 20, CCW).</p>
<p>
<img border="0" src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/104/p10429a.jpg"  width="350" height="286" hspace="150"></p>
<p><b>Step 1 :</b> Draw two perpendicular line indicating
horizontal line as
<img border="0" src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/104/p10429a.jpg"  width="12" height="14" align="middle">
axis and the vertical line as
<img border="0" src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/104/p10429a.jpg"  width="12" height="14" align="middle">axis. The point of
intersection is the center point (0,0) and both the stresses is zero there. See <i>Figure 
b</i> below.</font></p>
<p><b>Step 2 :</b> Locate points (<img border="0" src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/104/p10429a.jpg"  width="22" height="24" align="middle">,<img border="0" src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/104/p10429a.jpg"  width="23" height="27" align="middle">)
and (<img border="0" src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/104/p10429a.jpg"  width="20" height="27" align="middle">,<img border="0" src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/104/p10429a.jpg"  width="24" height="28" align="middle">)
and connect them with a straight line. Indicated by point <i><b>A</b></i> (32, 
-20) and <i>
<b>B</b></i> (-10, 20) respectively in <i>Figure b</i>.</font></p>
<p><b>Step 3 :</b> Draw a circle with the line <i>
<b>AB</b></i> as the
diameter and the intersection of the line <i><b>AB</b></i> and
<i><b>DE</b></i> (<img border="0" src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/104/p10429a.jpg"  width="12" height="14" align="middle"> axis) as the center 
(point <b> <i>C</i></b>).</p>
<p><img border="0" src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/104/p10429a.jpg"  width="417" height="288" hspace="150"></p>
<p>Now for maximum normal stress condition:</p>
<p><b>&gt;&gt;</b> Maximum normal stress angle = half of angle ACD = 43.6 / 2 = 21.8 
degree. Angle ACD will not be greater than 90 degree only for current problem.</p>
<p><b>&gt;&gt;</b> Maximum and minimum normal stress = OD and OE respectively = 40 &amp; 
-18 respectively.</p>
<p>For maximum shear stress condition</p>
<p><b>&gt;&gt;</b> Maximum shear stress angle = half of angle ACD + 45 = 21.8 + 45 = 
66.8 degree</p>
<p><b>&gt;&gt;</b> Maximum shear stress = CF = 29</p>
<p><b>&gt;&gt;</b> Normal stress at this condition = OC = 11</p>
<p>Remember, on the ordinate
clockwise (<b>CW</b>) shear stresses are plotted up; counterclockwise (<b>CCW</b>) shear
stresses are plotted down. Moreover
<img border="0" src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/104/p10429a.jpg"  width="24" height="28" align="middle"> always has the same
value as
<img border="0" src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/104/p10429a.jpg"  width="23" height="27" align="middle"> but
inverse in direction, <br><i>i.e. </i>
<img border="0" src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/104/p10429a.jpg"  width="24" height="28" align="middle"><i>=
<b>-</b></i><img border="0" src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/104/p10429a.jpg"  width="23" height="27" align="top"><i>.</font></i> </p>
<h2>
<a NAME="SECTION0001003000000000000000"></a><font color="#0070E8">The Input</font></h2>
First line of input will contain a stress state with three numbers
<img border="0" src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/104/p10429a.jpg"  width="22" height="24" align="middle">,<img border="0" src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/104/p10429a.jpg"  width="20" height="27" align="middle">
and
<img border="0" src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/104/p10429a.jpg"  width="23" height="27" align="middle">(all 
in the range of -1000 MPa to 1000 MPa) followed by a string
(<b>&quot;<tt>CW</tt>&quot;</b> or <b>&quot;<tt>CCW</tt>&quot;</b>) stating the direction of the torsional stress
if not zero (<i>i.e.</i> The string will not appear if
<img border="0" src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/104/p10429a.jpg"  width="23" height="27" align="middle"> is 
zero). <h2>
<a NAME="SECTION0001004000000000000000"></a><font color="#0070E8">The Output</font></h2>
For each system  , First of all output angle ACD, then the value OD &amp; OE on the next line. Then 
print a blank line.<p>After that print maximum shear stress angle as stated in the example above 
(angle ACD + 45). On the next line print the value of CF, followed by the value 
of CO.</p>
<p>Each real number must be 
rounded to the nearest 2 digits after the decimal point. Consider the format of 
the sample output below while printing the values. Output a blank line between 
two consecutive output set.</p>
<h2>
<a NAME="SECTION0001005000000000000000"></a><font color="#0070E8">Sample
Input</font></h2>
<pre>32 -10 20 CCW
80 -40 0</pre>

<h2>
<a NAME="SECTION0001006000000000000000"></a><font color="#0070E8">Sample
Output</font></h2>

<pre>Element : 1
Position of maximum normal stresses : 21.80 deg
Maximum normal stresses : 40.00 MPa and -18.00 MPa

Position of maximum shear stresses : 66.80 deg
Maximum shear stress (xy plane) : 29.00 MPa
Normal stress at this condition : 11.00 MPa

Element : 2
Position of maximum normal stresses : 0.00 deg
Maximum normal stresses : 80.00 MPa and -40.00 MPa

Position of maximum shear stresses : 45.00 deg
Maximum shear stress (xy plane) : 60.00 MPa
Normal stress at this condition : 20.00 MPa
</pre>

<hr><i>Suman Mahbub</i>
<br><i>Created: 24-01-2002</i>
<br><i>Updated: 14-12-2002, 27-01-2003, 09-02-2003</i>
</body>
</html>

10430||||||false||||||
<!doctype html public "-//w3c//dtd html 4.0 transitional//en">
<html>
<head>
   <meta http-equiv="Content-Type" content="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">
   <meta name="GENERATOR" content="Microsoft FrontPage 5.0">
   <meta name="Author" content="S. M. Mahbub Murshed">
   <meta name="Description" content="Dear GOD, Pardon Me">
   <title>Dear GOD, Pardon Me</title>
<!--Converted with LaTeX2HTML 96.1 (Feb 5, 1996) by Nikos Drakos (nikos@cbl.leeds.ac.uk), CBLU, University of Leeds -->
</head>
<div align="center">
  <center>
  <table BGCOLOR="#CCCCFF" style="border-collapse: collapse" bordercolor="#111111" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" >
<tr>
<td align="center"><font size="+2" color="#000099"><b>Brightness of Brain
Contest </b></font><br><font size="+2" color="#000099">
Problem B</font><br>
<font size="4" color="#000099">Time limit: 1 second Memory: 16 MB</font></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td align="center" bgcolor="#0070E8">
<p align="center"><a NAME="SECTION0001000000000000000000"></a><b>
<font size=+2 color="#C0FFFF">Dear GOD, Pardon Me</font></b></td>
</tr>
</table></center>
</div>

<body bgcolor="#FFFFFF" LANG="EN">
<h2>
<a NAME="SECTION0001002000000000000000"></a><font color="#0070E8">The Problem</font></h2>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
This is the judgment day. All people are standing in front of the GOD. The GOD has the book of deeds for all people.
He is calling one after one and punishing them or giving gift
 according to their deeds on earth. Unfortunately the situation become quiet
confusing
with the people who have equal number of good deeds and misdeeds, and most of the people are of this kind.<br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; The
GOD has taken a policy for this kind of peoples. HE has kept some cards all of them
numbered less then 10 in a
basket (basket <b>T</b>). Another basket (basket <b>N</b>) contains cards which are numbered
by numbers less then 100. Each people with equal deeds and misdeeds will choose randomly a
card from each basket. Then he has to collect some flowers, say <b>X</b> from 
trees located there (flowers are huge, he can take as many as he want). Then he 
has to go to the pond of reconciliation. Keeping those flowers beside the pond 
he has to sink into the pond. When he will come up the number of flowers will be 
changed to <b>T</b> times the number of flowers that he had before sinking into 
the pond (the number <b>T</b> is the number written in the card chosen from basket <b>`T'</b>). He must take some flowers, say <b>K</b>
from those and dedicate them to the temple nearby. This amount <b>K</b> is fixed by him, but once fixed can't be changed. He is permitted
to sink <b>N</b> times, the number chosen from basket <b>`N'</b>. If after <b>N</b>'th sink and dedication
to the temple there is no flowers left then he will have to stay <b>X</b> days in the Hell and then
he will be shifted to heaven. Otherwise if there is any flower left or the flower was finished before <b>N</b>'th
sink
he will be thrown to the hell.<br>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
You, some how managed to take your pocket computer there. After knowing about the policy, you
noticed that you are of the same
category of equal_good_deeds &amp; equal_bad_deeds. Now quickly write a program to make sure that you can go to the heaven without staying in the
hell for any given
<b>T</b> and <b>N</b>. &nbsp;
<h2>
<a NAME="SECTION0001003000000000000000"></a><font color="#0070E8">The Input</font></h2>
The input is two integer indicating <b>T</b> and <b>N</b>. Input is terminated 
by EOF.
<h2>
<a NAME="SECTION0001004000000000000000"></a><font color="#0070E8">The Output</font></h2>
Output a line <b>"<tt>Dear GOD, Pardon Me</tt>"</b> at first. Then output <b>X</b> and <b>K</b> 
each in a new line in the format shown below. No invalid input will be present. Print a blank line between two set of output except the last
one.
<h2>
<a NAME="SECTION0001005000000000000000"></a><font color="#0070E8">Sample
Input</font></h2>

<pre>7 4
3 7
</pre>

<h2>
<a NAME="SECTION0001006000000000000000"></a><font color="#0070E8">Sample
Output</font></h2>

<pre>Dear GOD, Pardon Me
X = 400
K = 2401

X = 1093
K = 2187
</pre>

<hr><i>Suman Mahbub</i>
<br><i>Created: 28-04-2001</i>
<br><i>Updated: 14-12-2002, 26-01-2003, 07-02-2003</i>
<br><i>Idea: Ashraful Alam Joy</i>
</body>
</html>
______________________________________________________
10431||||||false||||||
<!doctype html public "-//w3c//dtd html 4.0 transitional//en">
<html>
<head>
   <meta http-equiv="Content-Type" content="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">
   <meta name="GENERATOR" content="Microsoft FrontPage 5.0">
   <meta name="Author" content="S. M. Mahbub Murshed">
   <meta name="Description" content="Normal Distribution">
   <title>Normal Distribution</title>
<!--Converted with LaTeX2HTML 96.1 (Feb 5, 1996) by Nikos Drakos (nikos@cbl.leeds.ac.uk), CBLU, University of Leeds -->
</head>
<body bgcolor="#FFFFFF" LANG="EN">
<div align="center">
  <center>
  <table BGCOLOR="#CCCCFF" style="border-collapse: collapse" bordercolor="#111111" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" >
<tr>
<td align="center"><font size="+2" color="#000099"><b>Brightness of Brain 
Contest</b></font><br><font size="+2" color="#000099">Problem C</font><br>
<font size="4" color="#000099">Time limit: 5 second Memory: 1 MB</font></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td align="center" bgcolor="#0070E8">
<p align="center"><a NAME="SECTION0001000000000000000000"></a><b>
<font size=+2 color="#C0FFFF">Normal Distribution</font></b></td>
</tr>
</table></center>
</div>
<h2>
<a NAME="SECTION0001002000000000000000"></a><font color="#0070E8">The Problem</font></h2>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; One of the most important of the many distributions which
occur in the study of statistics is the <i>normal</i>, or <i>Gaussian
distribution</i>. The equation of the normal curve is<p>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<img border="0" src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/104/p10431a.jpg"  width="147" height="44" align="middle">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; -------------------------&nbsp;
<b>[1]</b><br>where <b> <i>f(x)</i></b>
is the <i>frequency function</i>. The total area under this curve, from
<img border="0" src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/104/p10431a.jpg"  width="50" height="14" align="middle">to
<img border="0" src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/104/p10431a.jpg"  width="49" height="16" align="middle">, is one square
unit. Therefore the area between any two points, say from x=a to x=b, is the
proportion of cases which lie between the two points. A plot of Eq. 1 yields a
bell-shaped curve having a maximum ordinate at
<img border="0" src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/104/p10431a.jpg"  width="40" height="17" align="middle"> and decreasing to
zero at both 
<img border="0" src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/104/p10431a.jpg"  width="28" height="14" align="middle"> and<img border="0" src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/104/p10431a.jpg"  width="28" height="14" align="middle">.
If the standard deviation
<img border="0" src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/104/p10431a.jpg"  width="16" height="14" align="middle">is small, the
curve is tall and thin; if
<img border="0" src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/104/p10431a.jpg"  width="16" height="14" align="middle">is large, the
curve is short and broad; see the <i><b>Figure 1</b></i> below-</p>
<p align="center">
<img border="0" src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/104/p10431a.jpg"  width="590" height="216" align="middle" hspace="50"></p>
<p align="center">
<i><b>Figure 1 : The Shape of the normal distribution curve (a) Small (b) Large</b></i></p>
<p>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; In order to analyze different statistical cases, it is
convenient to replace x in Eq. 1 with the <i>standard variable z</i> defined as</p>
<p>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; <img border="0" src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/104/p10431a.jpg"  width="64" height="41" align="middle">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 
-------------------------&nbsp;
<b>[2]</b></p>
<p>where now x is to be normally distributed with a mean of zero. <b><i>Equation 1</i></b>
then becomes a <i>unit normal distribution</i> and is written as</p>
<p>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<img border="0" src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/104/p10431a.jpg"  width="119" height="44" align="middle">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
-------------------------&nbsp;
<b>[3]</b></p>
<p>The distribution is illustrated in the following figure, <i><b>Figure 2</b></i>.</p>
<p align="center"><img border="0" src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/104/p10431a.jpg"  width="477" height="169" hspace="100"></p>
<p align="center"><i><b>Figure 2 : The standard normal distribution</b></i></p>
<p>The ordinate at <i>z</i> is <b> <i>f(z)</i></b>, obtained using Eq 3. The areas
<b> <i>
Q(z)</i></b> and <b> <i>P(z)</i></b> under the curve can be found in statistical tables or
approximated. Since the total area under the curve is unity</p>
<p>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; <i>P(z)&nbsp; =&nbsp; 1&nbsp; -&nbsp;
Q(z)&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;  </i>
-------------------------&nbsp;
<b>[4]</b></p>
<p>The term <b> <i>Q(z)</i></b> is obtained by integrating the area under the curve. It
can be approximated and then programmed for calculation using a polynomial
expansion (Hewlett-Packard <i>Applications Book</i>, op. cit., p. 107). The
results area found to be</p>
<p>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<img border="0" src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/104/p10431a.jpg"  width="302" height="25" align="middle">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
-------------------------&nbsp;
<b>[5]</b></p>
<p>where</p>
<p>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<img border="0" src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/104/p10431a.jpg"  width="80" height="44" align="middle">,&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<img border="0" src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/104/p10431a.jpg"  width="93" height="24" align="middle"></p>
<p>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
p = 0.2316419&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
b<sub>1 </sub>= 0.319381530</p>
<p>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
b<sub>2 </sub>= -0.356563782&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; b<sub>3</sub>
= 1.781477937</p>
<p>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
b<sub>4</sub> = -1.821255978&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; b<sub>5</sub>
= 1.330274429</p>
<p>&nbsp;From the above equation we can calculate <b> <i>Q(z)</i></b> for any
distribution.</p>
<p>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; In this problem you have to determine the standard
deviation and mean of some given data. Then for some given value find the number
of population falling in the region <b> <i>Q(z)</i></b> and <b> <i>P(z)</i></b>.</p>
<h2>
<a NAME="SECTION0001003000000000000000"></a><font color="#0070E8">The Input</font></h2>
The input consists of several segments. The first line of input of each segment
is an integer <b>'<i>N</i>'</b> (0&lt;<b>N</b>&lt;2^31) indicating the population. The next line contains
<b>'<i>N</i>'</b> 
real numbers describing the population data (such as age of people, length of
shaft or diameter of bearing etc.). The following line contains an integer <b>'<i>Q</i>'</b> 
(0&lt;<b>Q</b>&lt;1000)
number of query. And the next line similarly contains <b>'<i>Q</i>'</b> number
describing the query.<h2>
<a NAME="SECTION0001004000000000000000"></a><font color="#0070E8">The Output</font></h2>
For each set of input output the data set number followed by mean, standard
deviation, then <b>3<i>Q</i></b> numbers answering the queries. Each answer to query
describes <b>P(z)</b> then <b>Q(z)</b> and then percentage of population `<b>T</b>' falling in
<b>Q(z)</b> area.
Every number must be rounded to the nearest fourth digit after the decimal 
point.<h2>
<a NAME="SECTION0001005000000000000000"></a><font color="#0070E8">Sample
Input</font></h2>
<pre>11
96 93 90 86 86 80 78 76 68 84 100
2
60 100
13
78 60 74 82 96 68 94 86 78 90 87 56 88
3
100 30 59
</pre>

<h2>
<a NAME="SECTION0001006000000000000000"></a><font color="#0070E8">Sample
Output</font></h2>

<pre>Data Set #1
Mean = 85.1818
Standard Deviation = 9.3895
P(z) = 0.9963, Q(z) = 0.0037, T = 0.0403
P(z) = 0.9427, Q(z) = 0.0573, T = 0.6299

Data Set #2
Mean = 79.7692
Standard Deviation = 12.4777
P(z) = 0.9475, Q(z) = 0.0525, T = 0.6821
P(z) = 1.0000, Q(z) = 0.0000, T = 0.0004
P(z) = 0.9520, Q(z) = 0.0480, T = 0.6241
</pre>

<hr><i>Suman Mahbub</i>
<br><i>Created: 30-01-2002</i>
<br><i>Updated: 14-12-2002</i>
</body>
</html>
______________________________________________________
10432||||||false||||||
<!doctype html public "-//w3c//dtd html 4.0 transitional//en">
<html>
<head>
   <meta http-equiv="Content-Type" content="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">
   <meta name="GENERATOR" content="Microsoft FrontPage 5.0">
   <meta name="Author" content="S. M. Mahbub Murshed">
   <meta name="Description" content="Polygon Inside A Circle">
   <title>Polygon Inside A Circle</title>
<!--Converted with LaTeX2HTML 96.1 (Feb 5, 1996) by Nikos Drakos (nikos@cbl.leeds.ac.uk), CBLU, University of Leeds -->
</head>
<body bgcolor="#FFFFFF" LANG="EN">
<div align="center">
  <center>
  <table BGCOLOR="#CCCCFF" style="border-collapse: collapse" bordercolor="#111111" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" >
<tr>
<td align="center"><font size="+2" color="#000099"><b>Brightness of Brain 
Contest </b></font><br><font size="+2" color="#000099">
Problem D</font><br>
<font size="4" color="#000099">Time limit: 1 second Memory: 16 MB</font></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td align="center" bgcolor="#0070E8">
<p align="center"><a NAME="SECTION0001000000000000000000"></a><font size="+2" color="#C0FFFF">
<b>Polygon Inside A Circle</b></font></td>
</tr>
</table></center>
</div>

<h2>
<a NAME="SECTION0001002000000000000000"></a><font color="#0070E8">The Problem</font></h2>
<p align="left">Consider a polygon of equal sides inside a circle as shown in 
the figure below. </p>
<p align="center">
<img border="0" src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/104/p10432.jpg"  width="338" height="336"></p>
<p align="center"><b>Figure: The regular polygon inside a circle</b></p>
<p align="left">Given the radius of the circle and number of sides. You have to 
find the area of the polygon.</p>
<h2>
<a NAME="SECTION0001003000000000000000"></a><font color="#0070E8">The Input</font></h2>
In each line there will be two numbers indicating the radius <b>`r'</b> (0&lt;<b>r</b>&lt;20000) and the number 
of sides of the polygon <b>`n'</b> (2&lt;<b>n</b>&lt;20000) respectively. Input is terminated by `EOF'.<h2>
<a NAME="SECTION0001004000000000000000"></a><font color="#0070E8">The Output</font></h2>
Output the area in each line. The number must be rounded to the third digit after the 
decimal point.<h2>
<a NAME="SECTION0001005000000000000000"></a><font color="#0070E8">Sample
Input</font></h2>
<pre>2 2000
10 3000
</pre>

<h2>
<a NAME="SECTION0001006000000000000000"></a><font color="#0070E8">Sample
Output</font></h2>

<pre>12.566
314.159
</pre>

<hr><i>Suman Mahbub</i>
<br><i>Created: 12-09-2002</i>
<br><i>Updated: 14-12-2002</i>
<br><i>Idea: mAruf Hasan</i></body></html>
______________________________________________________
10433||||||false||||||
<!doctype html public "-//w3c//dtd html 4.0 transitional//en">
<html>
<head>
   <meta http-equiv="Content-Type" content="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">
   <meta name="GENERATOR" content="Microsoft FrontPage 5.0">
   <meta name="Author" content="S. M. Mahbub Murshed">
   <meta name="Description" content="Automorphic Numbers">
   <title>Automorphic Numbers</title>
<!--Converted with LaTeX2HTML 96.1 (Feb 5, 1996) by Nikos Drakos (nikos@cbl.leeds.ac.uk), CBLU, University of Leeds -->
</head>
<body bgcolor="#FFFFFF" LANG="EN">
<div align="center">
  <center>
  <table BGCOLOR="#CCCCFF" style="border-collapse: collapse" bordercolor="#111111" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" >
<tr>
<td align="center"><font size="+2" color="#000099"><b>Brightness of Brain 
Contest </b></font><br><font size="+2" color="#000099">
Problem E</font><br>
<font size="4" color="#000099">Time limit: 1 second Memory: 32 MB</font></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td align="center" bgcolor="#0070E8">
<p align="center"><a NAME="SECTION0001000000000000000000"></a><b>
<font size=+2 color="#C0FFFF">Automorphic Numbers</font></b></td>
</tr>
</table></center>
</div>

<h2>
<a NAME="SECTION0001002000000000000000"></a><font color="#0070E8">The Problem</font></h2>
<p align="left"><b>Recreational mathematics</b> is mathematics that is fun and 
used as either as a diversion from serious mathematics or as a way of making 
serious mathematics understandable or palatable.&nbsp; These are the pedagogic 
uses of recreational mathematics.&nbsp; They are already present in the oldest 
known mathematics and continue to the present day. One of the topic of the 
recreational mathematics is the <b>Automorphic numbers</b>&nbsp; 
which have many use in different&nbsp; fields.</p>
<p align="justify"><b>Automorphic numbers</b> are those numbers whose <b>square 
ends with the number itself</b>: </p>
<table align="center">
  <tr align="right">
    <td>5<sup>2</sup></td>
    <td>=</td>
    <td>25,</td>
  </tr>
  <tr align="right">
    <td>25<sup>2</sup></td>
    <td>=</td>
    <td>625,</td>
  </tr>
  <tr align="right">
    <td>76<sup>2</sup></td>
    <td>=</td>
    <td>5776.</td>
  </tr>
</table>
<p align="justify">The first automorphic numbers are 1, 5, 6, 25, 76,&nbsp; ... 
By definition 0 is not an Automorphic Number and for this particular problem we 
will not consider 1 as an Automorphic Number.</p>
<p align="justify">Automorphic numbers have enormous application in mathematics. 
In this problem you are to determine whether a given number is Automorphic or 
not.</p>
<h2>
<a NAME="SECTION0001003000000000000000"></a><font color="#0070E8">The Input</font></h2>
Each line containing a arbitrarily big integer. Some Automorphic number have 
leading zeros. So leading zeros must be considered as significant. Input is terminated by end of 
file.<h2>
<a NAME="SECTION0001004000000000000000"></a><font color="#0070E8">The Output</font></h2>
If the input is an Automorphic number print <b>``<tt>Automorphic number of n-digit.</tt>''</b>, 
where <b>n</b> is the number of digit of the integer which will not be greater then 
2000. 
Otherwise print <b>``<tt>Not an Automorphic number.</tt>''</b>.<h2>
<a NAME="SECTION0001005000000000000000"></a><font color="#0070E8">Sample
Input</font></h2>
<pre>5
76
34
</pre>

<h2>
<a NAME="SECTION0001006000000000000000"></a><font color="#0070E8">Sample
Output</font></h2>

<pre>Automorphic number of 1-digit.
Automorphic number of 2-digit.
Not an Automorphic number.
</pre>

<hr><i>Suman Mahbub</i>
<br><i>Created: 01-09-2002</i>
<br><i>Updated: 14-12-2002</i>
</body>
</html>
______________________________________________________
10434||||||false||||||
<!doctype html public "-//w3c//dtd html 4.0 transitional//en">
<html>
<head>
   <meta http-equiv="Content-Type" content="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">
   <meta name="GENERATOR" content="Microsoft FrontPage 5.0">
   <meta name="Author" content="S. M. Mahbub Murshed">
   <meta name="Description" content="Processing Thermocouple System">
   <title>Working With Specific Gravity</title>
<!--Converted with LaTeX2HTML 96.1 (Feb 5, 1996) by Nikos Drakos (nikos@cbl.leeds.ac.uk), CBLU, University of Leeds -->
</head>
<body bgcolor="#FFFFFF" LANG="EN">
<div align="center">
  <center>
  <table BGCOLOR="#CCCCFF" style="border-collapse: collapse" bordercolor="#111111" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" >
<tr>
<td align="center"><font size="+2" color="#000099"><b>Brightness of Brain Contest</b></font><br><font size="+2" color="#000099">Problem 
F</font><br>
<font size="4" color="#000099">Time limit: 1 second Memory: 16 MB</font></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td align="center" bgcolor="#0070E8">
<p align="center"><a NAME="SECTION0001000000000000000000"></a><b>
<font size=+2 color="#C0FFFF">Working With Specific Gravity</font></b></td>
</tr>
</table></center>
</div>
<h2>
<a NAME="SECTION0001002000000000000000"></a><font color="#0070E8">The Problem</font></h2>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; You may have heard the name of <i>Archimedes</i>. It is 
said that, <i>Archimedes</i> discovered the buoyancy laws when asked by the King 
Hiero of Syracuse to determine whether his new crown was pure gold or not. <i>
Archimedes</i> was threatened to be punished if he was unable to do so. One day 
he was 
bathing and thinking about the way to solve the problem. When he immersed 
himself into 
a fully poured bath tub, some water overflowed. Then suddenly he started shouting 
&quot;Eureka, Eureka&quot;&nbsp; and ran out nude to the king, because he solved the problem 
from that event. Since then the law of 
buoyancy was established.
<br><br>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; The laws of buoyancy that was discovered by <i>Archimedes</i> 
in the third century B.C., which are :
<ul type="square">
  <li><i>A body immersed in a fluid experiences a vertical buoyant force equal 
  to the weight of the fluid is displaces. </i></li>
  <li><i>A floating body displaces its own weight in the fluid 
in which it floats. </i></li>
</ul>
<p>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Many complex analysis became possible after the discovery of these buoyancy laws.
In this problem we are considering a hydrometer, which is used to measure the specific
gravity of any fluid using the simple approach  offered by the buoyancy laws.
<br><br>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; A <i>hydrometer </i>floats at a level which is a measure 
of the specific gravity of the liquid. The stem is of constant diameter <b> <i>`D'</i></b>, 
and a weight in the bottom stabilizes the body to float vertically, as shown in 
the figure. If the position <b> <i>h</i></b> = 0 is pure water (<i>SG</i> = 1.0), find 
<b>'<i>h</i>'</b> 
or&nbsp; <b>'<i>SG</i>'</b> whichever is not given in the input. </p>
<p align="center"><img border="0" src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/104/p10434c.jpg"  hspace="200" width="202" height="394"></p>
<p align="center"><i><b>Figure 1 : A Hydrometer</b></i></p>
<h2>
<a NAME="SECTION0001003000000000000000"></a><font color="#0070E8">The Input</font></h2>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Input consists of three line, each for any of the given four constants. Input 
must have the value of <b>'<i>W</i>'</b> in gram (0&lt;<b>W</b>&lt;=5000) and <b>'<i>D</i>'</b> in 
millimeter (0&lt;<b>D</b>&lt;=100). Along with these <b>'<i>h</i>'</b> in centimeter 
(0&lt;<b>h</b>&lt;=50) or <b>'<i>SG</i>'</b> (0&lt;<b>SG</b>&lt;=25) may appear. Use 
specific weight of water,<img border="0" src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/104/p10434c.jpg"  align="middle" width="20" height="23"> = 
9806.65 N/m<sup>3</sup>, Gravitational Acceleration g = 9.80665 m/s<sup>2</sup>, density of water,<img border="0" src="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/104/p10434c.jpg"  align="middle" width="12" height="16"> 
= 1000 kg/m<sup>3</sup>.<h2>
<a NAME="SECTION0001004000000000000000"></a><font color="#0070E8">The Output</font></h2>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
For each set of input process the value of the variable (<b>'<i>h</i>'</b> or <b>'<i>SG</i>'</b>) 
not present in the input. Output of <b>'<i>h</i>'</b> should be in centimeter (cm). 
Round each floating point value to two digit after the decimal place.<h2>
<a NAME="SECTION0001005000000000000000"></a><font color="#0070E8">Sample
Input</font></h2>
<pre>W=3307.00
D=81.00
h=32.00
W=3665.00
D=74.00
SG=1.29</pre>

<h2>
<a NAME="SECTION0001006000000000000000"></a><font color="#0070E8">Sample
Output</font></h2>

<pre>SG=1.99
h=19.16</pre>

<hr><i>Suman Mahbub</i>
<br><i>Created: 16-03-2002</i>
<br><i>Updated: 14-12-2002</i>
</body>
</html>
______________________________________________________
10435||||||false||||||
<!doctype html public "-//w3c//dtd html 4.0 transitional//en">
<html>
<head>
   <meta http-equiv="Content-Type" content="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">
   <meta name="GENERATOR" content="Microsoft FrontPage 5.0">
   <meta name="Author" content="S. M. Mahbub Murshed">
   <meta name="Description" content="Compare Directories">
   <title>Compare Directories</title>
<!--Converted with LaTeX2HTML 96.1 (Feb 5, 1996) by Nikos Drakos (nikos@cbl.leeds.ac.uk), CBLU, University of Leeds -->
</head>
<body bgcolor="#FFFFFF" LANG="EN">
&nbsp;<center><table BGCOLOR="#0060F0" >
<div align="center">
  <table BGCOLOR="#CCCCFF" style="border-collapse: collapse" bordercolor="#111111" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" >
<tr>
<td align="center"><font size="+2" color="#000099"><b>Brightness of Brain
Contest </b></font><br><font size="+2" color="#000099">
Problem G</font><br>
<font size="4" color="#000099">Time limit: 15 second Memory: 64 MB</font></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td align="center" bgcolor="#0070E8">
<p align="center"><a NAME="SECTION0001000000000000000000"></a><b>
<font size=+2 color="#C0FFFF">Compare Directories</font></b></td>
</tr>
</table></center>
</div>

<h2>
<a NAME="SECTION0001002000000000000000"></a><font color="#0070E8">The Problem</font></h2>
There are situations when you may want to check whether two directories are same or not.
(i.e. Whether they contain same file structure and files inside it.) Although there are 
several
utilities to perform such comparison, you as a programmer of the BDUX project (A Bangla Linux Platform)
is required to develop another such utility, to check whether two directories contain same content or not.
This may enable the recovery of the broken transaction of files over the network.
<br>&nbsp;
<h2>
<a NAME="SECTION0001003000000000000000"></a><font color="#0070E8">The Input</font></h2>
The input part is quit complex. Input contains several transactions of
directories.
<p>Let us first define <b>``File Object''</b> - A file object can be a directory or a
general file.</p>
<p>File object of type directory occur in a format : <b>&quot;<tt>DIRECTORY_NAME &lt;DIR&gt; FN</tt>"</b> , where
<b>&quot;<tt>DIRECTORY_NAME</tt>&quot;</b> is any valid directory
name (at most 255 character) and <b>&quot;<tt>&lt;DIR&gt;</tt>&quot;</b> indicating that this is
a directory. The integer <b>&quot;<tt>FN</tt>&quot;</b> (at most 65 thousand) indicates
the number of files and folders contained in that directory. The next <b>'<tt>FN</tt>'</b> line
contains descriptions of <b>'<tt>FN</tt>'</b> number of file object. </p>
<p>File object of type general file occur in a format : <b>&nbsp; &quot;<tt>FILE_NAME NByte</tt>&quot;</b>.
File names are all valid names and the size of the files are in bytes. No file
can be greater than 2 Giga byte. </p>
<p>Each transactions have the following format :</p>
<ul>
  <li>The first line contains the date for the transaction.</li>
  <li>Root directory of the first directory to compare</li>
  <li>Description of the first directory</li>
  <li>Root directory of the second directory to compare</li>
  <li>Description of the second directory</li>
</ul>
<h2>
<a NAME="SECTION0001004000000000000000"></a><font color="#0070E8">The Output</font></h2>
The output should be properly formatted using <b>``tabs''</b>. A <b>``Tab''</b> for current problem is
defined as four (4) spaces (<b>&quot;<tt>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</tt>&quot;</b>) .
<p>A file object should be printed, if required according to the situation described
later, using the following conditions :</p>
<ul>
  <li>If it is directory print as <b>&quot;<tt>DIRECTORY_NAME &lt;DIR&gt; N object(s)</tt>&quot;</b>
  , where <b>`<tt>DIRECTORY_NAME</tt>'</b> is the name of the directory and <b>`<tt>N</tt>'</b>
  is the number of objects present in that directory.</li>
  <li>If it is a general file print as <b>&quot;<tt>FILE_NAME N byte(s)</tt>&quot;</b> , where
  <b>&quot;<tt>FILE_NAME</tt>&quot;</b>
  is the name of the file and <b>`<tt>N</tt>'</b> is the size of the file in bytes.</li>
</ul>
<p>At first print <b>"<tt>==== Begin of Comparison ====</tt>"</b> in a single line.</p>
<p>For each transaction
print <b>"<tt>Transaction #</tt>"</b> followed by the transaction number, then the date.</p>
<p>Then generate report for each set of directories, start with a <b>`tab'</b> value 0 :</p>
<ul>
  <li> Print <b>`tab'</b>s. i.e. 4*<b>`tab'</b> number of spaces.</li>
  <li> Print <b>`<tt>Comparing "</tt>path1<tt>" with "</tt>path2<tt>".</tt>'</b> Replace <b>`path1'</b> with the first directory, and <b>`path2'</b> with the second directory. </li>
  <li>For each file object
      <ul>
        <li>If they have totally different content, print <b>`tab'</b> number of tabs
        and report <b>&quot;<tt>Totally different.</tt>&quot;</b>, then return.</li>
        <li>If both have a common directory descend in that directory, with <b>`tab'</b>+1 and start comparing.</li>
        <li>If both have a file name in common but different file size, print
        tabs of <b>`tab'</b>+1 amount, report it immediately, in the format : <b>``<tt>File
        size mismatch : &quot;PATH_1/FILE_NAME_1 (FILE_SIZE_1)&quot; and
        &quot;PATH_2/FILE_NAME_2 (FILE_SIZE_2)&quot;.</tt>''</b>.</li>
        <li>Report the file that is in <b>`path2'</b> but not in <b>`path1'</b>
        <ul>
            <li>Print <b>`tab'</b>+1 tabs.</li>
            <li>For each object print <b>`tab'</b>+2 tabs and this file object
            according to the rule described previously.</li>
        </ul>
        </li>
        <li>Report the file that is in <b>`path1'</b> but not in <b>`path2'</b>
        <ul>
            <li>Print <b>`tab'</b>+1 tabs.</li>
            <li>For each object print <b>`tab'</b>+2 tabs and this file object
            according to the rule described previously.</li>
        </ul>
        </li>
     </ul>
  </li>
  <li>If each file object in <b>`path1'</b> equals to each file object in <b>`path2'</b>,
  print <b>`tab'</b>s, print <b>&quot;<tt>No
  difference.</tt>&quot;</b>. </li>
  <li>Otherwise print <b>`tab'</b>s, print <b>&quot;<tt>Difference(s) encountered.</tt>&quot;</b>.</li>
</ul>
<p>Print a blank line after each transaction except the last one. Output should 
be sorted according to the input. The common File Objects of any two directories 
to compare are in the same order. You must use longest common subsequences of 
the file names in the two directory content to get common file names.</p>
<p>At the end print <b>"<tt>==== End of Comparison ====</tt>"</b> in a single line. See
the sample output below.</p>
<h2>
<a NAME="SECTION0001005000000000000000"></a><font color="#0070E8">Sample
Input</font></h2>
<pre>12/23/2001
/usr/bin
suman &lt;DIR&gt; 7
    BigBro &lt;DIR&gt; 2
        1.exe 987
        2.exe 987
    NewFile 109
    directory &lt;DIR&gt; 3
        hi 108
        thisFile 203
        xlog &lt;DIR&gt; 1
            xlog.log 111
    extra 1029
    underConstruction &lt;DIR&gt; 3
        index.html 12395
        p0.html 1333
        p1.html 2287
    wrt.doc 1987
    zlib &lt;DIR&gt; 0
/home
suman &lt;DIR&gt; 8
    AAA.dat 60000
    BigBro &lt;DIR&gt; 2
        3.exe 387
        4.exe 223
    NewFile 109
    directory &lt;DIR&gt; 3
        hi 108
        thisFile 203
        xlog &lt;DIR&gt; 1
            xlog.log 111
    extra 1029
    underConstruction &lt;DIR&gt; 3
        index.html 11005
        p0.htm 1333
        p1.htm 2287
    wrt.doc 1987
    zLib &lt;DIR&gt; 2
        bin &lt;DIR&gt; 2
            gzip 299
            gzip.log 300
        zlib.so 23098
10/3/2002
/CDrive
ACMHelper &lt;DIR&gt; 1
    acmhelper.exe 100
/tmp
Helper &lt;DIR&gt; 1
    acmhelper.exe 100
11/2/2000
/CDrive
Prog &lt;DIR&gt; 2
    ACMHelper &lt;DIR&gt; 1
        acmhelper.exe 100
    newDoc.rtf 2024
/tmp
CopyProg &lt;DIR&gt; 2
    Helper &lt;DIR&gt; 1
        acmhelper.exe 100
    noname.c 1002
</pre>

<h2>
<a NAME="SECTION0001006000000000000000"></a><font color="#0070E8">Sample
Output</font></h2>
<pre>==== Begin of Comparison ====
Transaction #1 : Date 12/23/2001
Comparing "/usr/bin/suman" with "/home/suman".
    Comparing "/usr/bin/suman/BigBro" with "/home/suman/BigBro".
    Totally different.
    Comparing "/usr/bin/suman/directory" with "/home/suman/directory".
        Comparing "/usr/bin/suman/directory/xlog" with "/home/suman/directory/xlog".
        No difference.
    No difference.
    Comparing "/usr/bin/suman/underConstruction" with "/home/suman/underConstruction".
        File size mismatch : "/usr/bin/suman/underConstruction/index.html (12395)" and "/home/suman/underConstruction/index.html (11005)".
        "/usr/bin/suman/underConstruction" lacks of following file(s)
            p0.htm 1333 byte(s)
            p1.htm 2287 byte(s)
        "/home/suman/underConstruction" lacks of following file(s)
            p0.html 1333 byte(s)
            p1.html 2287 byte(s)
    Difference(s) encountered.
    "/usr/bin/suman" lacks of following file(s)
        AAA.dat 60000 byte(s)
        zLib &lt;DIR&gt; 2 object(s)
    "/home/suman" lacks of following file(s)
        zlib &lt;DIR&gt; 0 object(s)
Difference(s) encountered.

Transaction #2 : Date 10/3/2002
Comparing "/CDrive/ACMHelper" with "/tmp/Helper".
No difference.

Transaction #3 : Date 11/2/2000
Comparing "/CDrive/Prog" with "/tmp/CopyProg".
Totally different.
==== End of Comparison ====
</pre>

<hr>
<i>Suman Mahbub<br>
Created: 17-01-2002<br>
Updated: 14-12-2002, 10-02-2003
</i>
</body>
</html>
