<HTML>
<HEAD>
<TITLE>Simple Base Conversion</TITLE>
<META NAME="description" CONTENT="Simple Base Conversion">
<META NAME="keywords" CONTENT="htmlatex">
<META NAME="resource-type" CONTENT="document">
<META NAME="distribution" CONTENT="global">

<META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">
<META NAME="Generator" CONTENT="LaTeX2HTML v2K.1beta">
<META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Style-Type" CONTENT="text/css">

<LINK REL="STYLESHEET" HREF="htmlatex.css">

</HEAD>

<BODY LANG="EN" BGCOLOR=#FFFFFF>

<H1><BR CLEAR=ALL><CENTER><TABLE BGCOLOR=#0060F0><TR><TD><B><FONT SIZE=5 COLOR=#C0FFFF>&nbsp;<A NAME="SECTION0001000000000000000000">
Simple Base Conversion</A>&nbsp;</FONT></B></TABLE></CENTER>
</H1>

<P>
In this problem you are asked to write a
simple base conversion program. You will be 
given a hexadecimal or decimal integer 
number as input. You will have to output the 
corresponding decimal or hexadecimal 
number. Hexadecimal numbers always starts
with a `<TT>0x</TT>' and all other numbers are to be
considered as decimal numbers. There will be
no invalid numbers in the input.

<P>
<DIV ALIGN="CENTER">
<!-- MATH
 $\epsfbox{p10473.eps}$
 -->
<IMG
 WIDTH="469" HEIGHT="263" ALIGN="BOTTOM" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/104/p10473.gif" 
 ALT="\epsfbox{p10473.eps}">
</DIV>

<P>

<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001001000000000000000">
Input</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>

<P>
The input file contains several lines of input. Each line contains a single non-negative number,
which may be a decimal or hexadecimal number as explained in the problem statement. The
decimal value of this number will be less than <SPAN CLASS="MATH">2<SUP>31</SUP></SPAN>. A line containing a negative decimal
number terminates input. This number should not be processed. Input numbers will contain no
space within them.

<P>

<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001002000000000000000">
Output</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>

<P>
For each line of input (Except the last one) produce one line of output. This line should contain
the decimal or hexadecimal representation of the corresponding hexadecimal or decimal number.
Like the input, the hexadecimal numbers in the output should be preceded by a `<TT>0x</TT>'.

<P>

<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001003000000000000000">
Sample Input</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>
<PRE>
4
7
44
0x80685
-1
</PRE>

<P>

<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001004000000000000000">
Sample Output</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>
<PRE>
0x4
0x7
0x2C
525957
</PRE>

<P>


<P>
<BR><HR>
<ADDRESS>
Problem-setter: Shahriar Manzoor, ACM Valladolid Online Judge
</ADDRESS>
</BODY>
</HTML>
</HTML>

______________________________________________________
10474||||||false||||||

<!--Converted with LaTeX2HTML 2K.1beta (1.47)
original version by:  Nikos Drakos, CBLU, University of Leeds
* revised and updated by:  Marcus Hennecke, Ross Moore, Herb Swan
* with significant contributions from:
  Jens Lippmann, Marek Rouchal, Martin Wilck and others -->
<HTML>
<HEAD>
<TITLE>Where is the Marble?</TITLE>
<META NAME="description" CONTENT="Where is the Marble?">
<META NAME="keywords" CONTENT="htmlatex">
<META NAME="resource-type" CONTENT="document">
<META NAME="distribution" CONTENT="global">

<META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">
<META NAME="Generator" CONTENT="LaTeX2HTML v2K.1beta">
<META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Style-Type" CONTENT="text/css">

<LINK REL="STYLESHEET" HREF="htmlatex.css">

</HEAD>

<BODY LANG="EN" BGCOLOR=#FFFFFF>

<H1><BR CLEAR=ALL><CENTER><TABLE BGCOLOR=#0060F0><TR><TD><B><FONT SIZE=5 COLOR=#C0FFFF>&nbsp;<A NAME="SECTION0001000000000000000000">
Where is the Marble?</A>&nbsp;</FONT></B></TABLE></CENTER>
</H1>

<P>
Raju and Meena love to play with Marbles. They have got a lot
of marbles with numbers written on them. At the beginning, Raju
would place the marbles one after another in ascending order of
the numbers written on them. Then Meena would ask Raju to
find the first marble with a certain number. She would count
1...2...3. Raju gets one point for correct answer, and Meena gets
the point if Raju fails. After some fixed number of trials the
game ends and the player with maximum points wins. Today it's
your chance to play as Raju. Being the smart kid, you'd be taking
the favor of a computer. But don't underestimate Meena, she had
written a program to keep track how much time you're taking to
give all the answers. So now you have to write a program, which
will help you in your role as Raju.

<P>

<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001001000000000000000">
Input</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>

<P>
There can be multiple test cases. Total no of test cases is less than 65. Each test case consists
begins with 2 integers: <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>N</I></SPAN> the number of marbles and <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>Q</I></SPAN> the number of queries Mina would
make. The next <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>N</I></SPAN> lines would contain the numbers written on the <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>N</I></SPAN> marbles. These marble
numbers will not come in any particular order. Following <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>Q</I></SPAN> lines will have <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>Q</I></SPAN> queries. Be
assured, none of the input numbers are greater than 10000 and none of them are negative.

<P>
Input is terminated by a test case where <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>N</I> = 0</SPAN> and <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>Q</I> = 0</SPAN>.

<P>

<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001002000000000000000">
Output</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>

<P>
For each test case output the serial number of the case.

<P>
For each of the queries, print one line of output. The format of this line will depend upon
whether or not the query number is written upon any of the marbles. The two different formats
are described below:

<P>

<UL>
<LI>`<TT><SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>x</I></SPAN> found at <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>y</I></SPAN></TT>', if the first marble with number <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>x</I></SPAN> was found at position <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>y</I></SPAN>.
Positions are numbered <!-- MATH
 $1, 2, \dots, N$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH">1, 2,..., <I>N</I></SPAN>.
</LI>
<LI>`<TT><SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>x</I></SPAN> not found</TT>', if the marble with number <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>x</I></SPAN> is not present.
</LI>
</UL>

<P>
Look at the output for sample input for details.

<P>

<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001003000000000000000">
Sample Input</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>
<PRE>
4 1
2
3
5
1
5
5 2
1
3
3
3
1
2
3
0 0
</PRE>

<P>

<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001004000000000000000">
Sample Output</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>
<PRE>
CASE# 1:
5 found at 4
CASE# 2:
2 not found
3 found at 3
</PRE>

<P>


<P>
<BR><HR>
<ADDRESS>
Problem-setter: Monirul Hasan Tomal, Southeast University
</ADDRESS>
</BODY>
</HTML>
</HTML>

______________________________________________________
10475||||||false||||||

<!--Converted with LaTeX2HTML 2K.1beta (1.47)
original version by:  Nikos Drakos, CBLU, University of Leeds
* revised and updated by:  Marcus Hennecke, Ross Moore, Herb Swan
* with significant contributions from:
  Jens Lippmann, Marek Rouchal, Martin Wilck and others -->
<HTML>
<HEAD>
<TITLE>Help the Leaders</TITLE>
<META NAME="description" CONTENT="Help the Leaders">
<META NAME="keywords" CONTENT="htmlatex">
<META NAME="resource-type" CONTENT="document">
<META NAME="distribution" CONTENT="global">

<META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">
<META NAME="Generator" CONTENT="LaTeX2HTML v2K.1beta">
<META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Style-Type" CONTENT="text/css">

<LINK REL="STYLESHEET" HREF="htmlatex.css">

</HEAD>

<BODY LANG="EN" BGCOLOR=#FFFFFF>

<H1><BR CLEAR=ALL><CENTER><TABLE BGCOLOR=#0060F0><TR><TD><B><FONT SIZE=5 COLOR=#C0FFFF>&nbsp;<A NAME="SECTION0001000000000000000000">
Help the Leaders</A>&nbsp;</FONT></B></TABLE></CENTER>
</H1>

<P>
Have you ever listened to the speeches of leaders (Political or non-political)?
People often find these speeches monotonous and hopeless. The leaders also
sometimes feel very embarrassed about their speeches and they are often afraid of
covering the same topics in two different speeches. You can save our intelligent
leaders from these kinds of embarrassments. For example, let's consider that a
leader has the following topics in his mind
<DL COMPACT>
<DT>a)</DT>
<DD>War
</DD>
<DT>b)</DT>
<DD>Terror
</DD>
<DT>c)</DT>
<DD>Peace
</DD>
<DT>d)</DT>
<DD>Nuclear-Bomb
</DD>
<DT>e)</DT>
<DD>Human-Right
</DD>
<DT>f)</DT>
<DD>Food
</DD>
<DT>g)</DT>
<DD>Oil-Crisis
</DD>
<DT>h)</DT>
<DD>Equal-Right
</DD>
</DL>

<P>
He delivers speeches on any two of these topics at once but never wants to cover the topics ``Oil-
Crisis" and ``War" in the same speech. The same thing applies for the topics ``Nuclear-Bomb"
and ``Equal-Right". You can help him by making all possible combinations of topics (Of course
considering the restrictions supplied by him) so that he can choose any one from them according
to his convenience and can avoid any blunders. The specific details are given in the input and
output specifications.

<P>

<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001001000000000000000">
Input</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>

<P>
The first line of the input file contains an integer <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>n</I></SPAN>(<SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>n</I><IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="30" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/104/10475img1.png" 
 ALT="$ \le$">100</SPAN>), which indicates how
many sets of inputs are there. The description of each set is given in the paragraph below:

<P>
The first line of each set has three integers <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>t</I></SPAN>(<!-- MATH
 $0 < t < 16$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH">0 &lt; <I>t</I> &lt; 16</SPAN>), <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>p</I></SPAN>(<!-- MATH
 $0 \le p < t(t-1)/2$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH">0<IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="30" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/104/10475img1.png" 
 ALT="$ \le$"><I>p</I> &lt; <I>t</I>(<I>t</I> - 1)/2</SPAN>),
<SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>s</I></SPAN>(<!-- MATH
 $0 < s \le 5$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH">0 &lt; <I>s</I><IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="30" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/104/10475img1.png" 
 ALT="$ \le$">5</SPAN>). Here <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>t</I></SPAN> denotes the number of topics in the leader's mind, <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>p</I></SPAN> denotes
the number of prohibited pairs and <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>s</I></SPAN> is the
total number of topics the leader wants to cover in a single speech. The next <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>t</I></SPAN> lines contain <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>t</I></SPAN>
topics of the leader's mind. The topics are all different. Each topic will contain only
alphanumeric characters and hyphens. Each of the next <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>p</I></SPAN> lines contains two different topics in
each line separated by a single space. These pairs of topics should not come in the same speech.
Same pair of topics may appear more than once in the input. Each topic has a maximum length
of 15.

<P>

<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001002000000000000000">
Output</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>

<P>
For each set you should first print the serial of that set. Each of the next lines should contain all
the possible topic groups. The topics in each group should be separated by a single space. Print a
blank line after the output for each set of input. In a group the topics should be printed in the
descending order of their lengths. If lengths of two topics are same the lexicographically smaller
one should come first. This order should also be maintained in the printing order of the groups.

<P>
Topics should be considered case insensitive. While printing the topics print all the characters as
uppercase. Print a blank line after the output for each case.

<P>

<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001003000000000000000">
Sample Input</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>
<PRE>
2
8 2 2
WAR
TERROR
PEACE
NUCLEAR-BOMB
HUMAN-RIGHT
FOOD
OIL-CRISIS
EQUAL-RIGHT
WAR OIL-CRISIS
EQUAL-RIGHT NUCLEAR-BOMB
8 0 1
WAR
TERROR
PEACE
NUCLEAR-BOMB
HUMAN-RIGHT
FOOD
OIL-CRISIS
EQUAL-RIGHT
</PRE>

<P>

<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001004000000000000000">
Output for Sample Input</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>
<PRE>
Set 1:
NUCLEAR-BOMB HUMAN-RIGHT
NUCLEAR-BOMB OIL-CRISIS
NUCLEAR-BOMB TERROR
NUCLEAR-BOMB PEACE
NUCLEAR-BOMB FOOD
NUCLEAR-BOMB WAR
EQUAL-RIGHT HUMAN-RIGHT
EQUAL-RIGHT OIL-CRISIS
EQUAL-RIGHT TERROR
EQUAL-RIGHT PEACE
EQUAL-RIGHT FOOD
EQUAL-RIGHT WAR
HUMAN-RIGHT OIL-CRISIS
HUMAN-RIGHT TERROR
HUMAN-RIGHT PEACE
HUMAN-RIGHT FOOD
HUMAN-RIGHT WAR
OIL-CRISIS TERROR
OIL-CRISIS PEACE
OIL-CRISIS FOOD
TERROR PEACE
TERROR FOOD
TERROR WAR
PEACE FOOD
PEACE WAR
FOOD WAR

Set 2:
NUCLEAR-BOMB
EQUAL-RIGHT
HUMAN-RIGHT
OIL-CRISIS
TERROR
PEACE
FOOD
WAR
</PRE>

<P>


<P>
<BR><HR>
<ADDRESS>
Problem-setter: Shahriar Manzoor, ACM Valladolid Online Judge
</ADDRESS>
</BODY>
</HTML>
</HTML>

______________________________________________________
10476||||||false||||||

<!--Converted with LaTeX2HTML 2K.1beta (1.47)
original version by:  Nikos Drakos, CBLU, University of Leeds
* revised and updated by:  Marcus Hennecke, Ross Moore, Herb Swan
* with significant contributions from:
  Jens Lippmann, Marek Rouchal, Martin Wilck and others -->
<HTML>
<HEAD>
<TITLE>Spam or Not Spam</TITLE>
<META NAME="description" CONTENT="Spam or Not Spam">
<META NAME="keywords" CONTENT="htmlatex">
<META NAME="resource-type" CONTENT="document">
<META NAME="distribution" CONTENT="global">

<META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">
<META NAME="Generator" CONTENT="LaTeX2HTML v2K.1beta">
<META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Style-Type" CONTENT="text/css">

<LINK REL="STYLESHEET" HREF="htmlatex.css">

</HEAD>

<BODY LANG="EN" BGCOLOR=#FFFFFF>

<H1><BR CLEAR=ALL><CENTER><TABLE BGCOLOR=#0060F0><TR><TD><B><FONT SIZE=5 COLOR=#C0FFFF>&nbsp;<A NAME="SECTION0001000000000000000000">
Spam or Not Spam</A>&nbsp;</FONT></B></TABLE></CENTER>
</H1>

<P>
Unsolicited email (spam) is annoying and clutters your mailbox. You are to write a
<EM>spam filter</EM> -
a program that reads email messages of regular ASCII  characters (32-127) and tries to
determine whether or not each message is spam.

<P>
How can we determine whether or not a message is spam? Spam contains words and phrases
that are not common in genuine email messages. For example, the phrase

<P>
<PRE>
MAKE MONEY FAST, HONEY!!
</PRE>

<P>
is in all-uppercase, contains the word "money" and ends with a double exclamation mark.

<P>
One way to create a spam filter is to read through many spam and non-spam messages and to
come up with a set of rules that will classify any particular message as spam or not. This process
can be tedious and error prone to do manually. Instead you will write a program to automate the
process.

<P>
A useful step in automatic classification is to split the text up into set of <EM>trigrams</EM>.
A trigram is a
sequence of three adjacent characters that appear in the message. A trigram is case sensitive. The
example above is composed of the trigrams:

<P>
<PRE>
MAK
AKE
KE
E M
MO
MON
ONE
NEY
EY
Y F
FA
FAS
AST
ST,
T,
, H
HO
HON
ONE
NEY
EY!
Y!!
</PRE>

<P>
If we examine a sample of spam and non-spam messages we find that some trigrams are more
common in spam; whereas others are more common in non-spam. This observation leads to a
classification method:

<P>

<UL>
<LI>Examine a sample consisting of a large number of spam messages. Count the number of
times that each trigram occurs. In the example above, there are 20 distinct trigrams; the
trigrams <TT>ONE</TT> and <TT>NEY</TT> occur twice each and the remaining 18 trigrams occur once
each. (Trigrams that do not occur are considered to occur 0 times.) More formally, for
each trigram <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>t</I></SPAN> we compute the frequency <!-- MATH
 $f_{spam}(t)$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>f</I><SUB>spam</SUB>(<I>t</I>)</SPAN> with which it occurs in the sample of
spam.
</LI>
<LI>Examine a sample consisting of a large number of non-spam messages. Compute <!-- MATH
 $f_{non-spam}(t)$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>f</I><SUB>non - spam</SUB>(<I>t</I>)</SPAN>,
the frequency with which each trigram <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>t</I></SPAN> appears in the sample of non-spam.
</LI>
<LI>For each message to be filtered, compute <!-- MATH
 $f_{message}(t)$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>f</I><SUB>message</SUB>(<I>t</I>)</SPAN> for each trigram <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>t</I></SPAN>.
</LI>
<LI>If  <!-- MATH
 $f_{message}$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>f</I><SUB>message</SUB></SPAN> resembles <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>f</I><SUB>spam</SUB></SPAN> more closely than it resembles
<!-- MATH
 $f_{non-spam}$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>f</I><SUB>non - spam</SUB></SPAN> it is determined to be spam; otherwise it is determined to be non-spam.
</LI>
<LI>A similarity measure determines how closely <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>f</I><SUB>1</SUB></SPAN> and <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>f</I><SUB>2</SUB></SPAN> resemble one another. One of the
simplest measures is the cosine measure:
<!-- MATH
 \begin{displaymath}
similarity (f_1,f_2) = {{\sum_t f_1(t) \cdot f_2(t)} \over {{\sqrt {\sum_t [f_1(t)]^2}} \cdot
{\sqrt {\sum_t [f_2(t)]^2}}}}
\end{displaymath}
 -->
<P></P>
<DIV ALIGN="CENTER" CLASS="mathdisplay">
<I>similarity</I>(<I>f</I><SUB>1</SUB>, <I>f</I><SUB>2</SUB>) = <IMG
 WIDTH="204" HEIGHT="57" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/104/10476img1.png" 
 ALT="$\displaystyle {{\sum_t f_1(t) \cdot f_2(t)} \over {{\sqrt {\sum_t [f_1(t)]^2}} \cdot
{\sqrt {\sum_t [f_2(t)]^2}}}}$">
</DIV><P></P>
</LI>
</UL>

<P>
Then we say that a message is spam if
<!-- MATH
 \begin{displaymath}
similarity(f_{message}, f_{spam}) > similarity(f_{message}, f_{non-spam})
\end{displaymath}
 -->
<P></P>
<DIV ALIGN="CENTER" CLASS="mathdisplay">
<I>similarity</I>(<I>f</I><SUB>message</SUB>, <I>f</I><SUB>spam</SUB>) &gt; <I>similarity</I>(<I>f</I><SUB>message</SUB>, <I>f</I><SUB>non - spam</SUB>)
</DIV><P></P>

<P>

<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001001000000000000000">
Input</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>

<P>
The input file contains several sets (less than 10) of input. The description of each set is given
below.

<P>
The first line of each set contains three integers: <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>s</I></SPAN>(<SPAN CLASS="MATH">0 &lt; <I>s</I> &lt; 5</SPAN>) the number of sample spam messages
to follow; <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>n</I></SPAN>(<SPAN CLASS="MATH">0 &lt; <I>n</I> &lt; 5</SPAN>) the number of sample non-spam messages to follow; <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>c</I></SPAN>(<SPAN CLASS="MATH">0 &lt; <I>c</I> &lt; 10</SPAN>) the number
of messages to be classified as spam or non-spam, based on trigram the trigram frequencies of
the sample messages. Each message consists of several lines of text and is terminated by a line
containing `<TT>ENDMESSAGE</TT>'. This line will not appear elsewhere in the input, and is not
considered part of the message. No line has more than 1000 characters.

<P>
Input is terminated by a set where <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>s</I> = 0</SPAN>, <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>n</I> = 0</SPAN> and <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>c</I> = 0</SPAN>. This set should not be processed.

<P>

<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001002000000000000000">
Output</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>

<P>
For each set of input your program should output a single line to identify the serial of the input
set. The output specification for each set is given below:

<P>
For each of the <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>c</I></SPAN> messages, your program will output two lines. On the first line, output
<!-- MATH
 $similarity(f_{message}, f_{spam})$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>similarity</I>(<I>f</I><SUB>message</SUB>, <I>f</I><SUB>spam</SUB>)</SPAN> and <!-- MATH
 $similarity(f_{message}, f_{non-spam})$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>similarity</I>(<I>f</I><SUB>message</SUB>, <I>f</I><SUB>non - spam</SUB>)</SPAN>.
On the second line print the
classification of the message (`<TT>spam</TT>' or `<TT>non-spam</TT>'). Round the numbers to
five decimal digits.

<P>
For detailed description look at the output for sample input.

<P>
When forming trigrams, we never include a new line character. We don't include trigrams that
span multiple lines, either.

<P>

<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001003000000000000000">
Sample Input</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>
<PRE>
2 1 1
AAAA
BBBB CCCC
ENDMESSAGE
BBBB
ENDMESSAGE
AAAABBBB
ENDMESSAGE
AAABB
ENDMESSAGE
2 1 2
AAAA
BBBB CCCC
ENDMESSAGE
BBBB
ENDMESSAGE
AAAABBBB
ENDMESSAGE
AAABB
ENDMESSAGE
AAABB
ENDMESSAGE
0 0 0
</PRE>

<P>

<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001004000000000000000">
Sample Output</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>
<PRE>
Set 1:
0.22222 0.73030
non-spam
Set 2:
0.22222 0.73030
non-spam
0.22222 0.73030
non-spam
</PRE>

<P>


<P>
<BR><HR>
<ADDRESS>
Problem Setter: Gordon V. Cormack, University of Waterloo, Canada
</ADDRESS>
</BODY>
</HTML>
</HTML>

______________________________________________________
10477||||||false||||||

<!--Converted with LaTeX2HTML 2K.1beta (1.47)
original version by:  Nikos Drakos, CBLU, University of Leeds
* revised and updated by:  Marcus Hennecke, Ross Moore, Herb Swan
* with significant contributions from:
  Jens Lippmann, Marek Rouchal, Martin Wilck and others -->
<HTML>
<HEAD>
<TITLE>The Hybrid Knight</TITLE>
<META NAME="description" CONTENT="The Hybrid Knight">
<META NAME="keywords" CONTENT="htmlatex">
<META NAME="resource-type" CONTENT="document">
<META NAME="distribution" CONTENT="global">

<META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">
<META NAME="Generator" CONTENT="LaTeX2HTML v2K.1beta">
<META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Style-Type" CONTENT="text/css">

<LINK REL="STYLESHEET" HREF="htmlatex.css">

</HEAD>

<BODY LANG="EN" BGCOLOR=#FFFFFF>

<H1><BR CLEAR=ALL><CENTER><TABLE BGCOLOR=#0060F0><TR><TD><B><FONT SIZE=5 COLOR=#C0FFFF>&nbsp;<A NAME="SECTION0001000000000000000000">
The Hybrid Knight</A>&nbsp;</FONT></B></TABLE></CENTER>
</H1>

<P>
Hybridization is a very important concept in Biology, Chemistry and in many other fields. But is
not at all an important concept in chess. Today we shall introduce a new chess knight, which can
move like a normal knight, a mutant knight and like a mutant pawn in a chessboard.

<P>
The following figure illustrates the different types of moves of our hybrid knight. Please note
that the knight is never allowed to land outside the board.

<P>
<DIV ALIGN="CENTER">
<!-- MATH
 $\epsfbox{p10477a.eps}$
 -->
<IMG
 WIDTH="864" HEIGHT="476" ALIGN="BOTTOM" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/104/p10477a.gif" 
 ALT="\epsfbox{p10477a.eps}">
</DIV>

<P>
Unfortunately, the knight cannot move according to
his own will. It maintains the following cyclic order
when it chooses its movement. It means if the
knight's first movement is like a knight, the second
movement will be like a mutant knight, the third
movement will be like a mutant pawn, the fourth
movement will be again like a knight and so on. The
same cycle applies if the hybrid knight starts with the
mutant knight move or with the mutant pawn move.
The cycle to be followed is shown in the given
figure.

<P>
<DIV ALIGN="CENTER">
<!-- MATH
 $\epsfbox{p10477b.eps}$
 -->
<IMG
 WIDTH="404" HEIGHT="369" ALIGN="BOTTOM" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/104/p10477a.gif" 
 ALT="\epsfbox{p10477b.eps}">
</DIV>

<P>
Given the size of the square shaped board, your job is to find the minimum number of moves
required by the hybrid knight to reach from one board position to another. The board positions
are numbered in row major order from top to bottom. So in a (8<SPAN CLASS="MATH">&#215;</SPAN>8) chessboard the identifier of
the top-left corner is 1 and the identifier of the bottom right corner is 64.

<P>

<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001001000000000000000">
Input</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>
The input file contains at most 20 sets of input. Each set starts with two integers <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>N</I></SPAN>(<!-- MATH
 $4 \le N \le 20$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH">4<IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="30" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/104/p10477a.gif" 
 ALT="$ \le$"><I>N</I><IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="30" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/104/p10477a.gif" 
 ALT="$ \le$">20</SPAN>)
and <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>S</I></SPAN>(<!-- MATH
 $S \le 1000$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>S</I><IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="30" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/104/p10477a.gif" 
 ALT="$ \le$">1000</SPAN>). <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>N</I></SPAN> indicates that you have to work with a <!-- MATH
 $N \times N$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>N</I>&#215;<I>N</I></SPAN> board and <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>S</I></SPAN> is the total
number of queries in that set. Each of the next <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>S</I></SPAN> lines contains 1 query. Each query contains two
integers <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>B</I></SPAN> and <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>E</I></SPAN> (<!-- MATH
 $1 \le B, E \le N*N$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH">1<IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="30" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/104/p10477a.gif" 
 ALT="$ \le$"><I>B</I>, <I>E</I><IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="30" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/104/p10477a.gif" 
 ALT="$ \le$"><I>N</I>*<I>N</I></SPAN>). Here <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>B</I></SPAN> is the starting location of the knight and <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>E</I></SPAN> is the
destination location of the knight. Input is terminated with a set whose value of <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>N</I></SPAN> is zero. This
case should not be processed. You can assume that the hybrid knight takes 0 moves to go from
X to X, where X is a valid board position. However, there will be no such query where <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>B</I></SPAN> and <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>E</I></SPAN>
is equal.

<P>

<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001002000000000000000">
Output</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>
For each set of input you should output the serial of the set as shown in the output for sample
input. For each query in a set you should output the minimum number of moves required by the
hybrid knight to move from <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>B</I></SPAN> to <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>E</I></SPAN>. If the destination is unreachable from the source, print a `<TT>?</TT>'
without the quotes.

<P>

<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001003000000000000000">
Sample Input</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>
<PRE>
5 2
10 15
10 20
10 1
2 10
0 10
</PRE>

<P>

<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001004000000000000000">
Sample Output</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>
<PRE>
Set 1:
1
2
Set 2:
4
</PRE>

<P>

<P><P>
<BR>

<B>Note:</B> The illustration given below shows the movement required for set 2.
Here to go from 2 to 10 in a
10<SPAN CLASS="MATH">&#215;</SPAN>10 board the hybrid knight uses its mutant knight move first to go to cell number 15.
Then it uses the mutant pawn move to go one row down to cell number 25. The third move is like a
regular knight, it takes our knight to cell number 17. The fourth and final move is a mutant
knight move that takes our knight to the destination. We're showing the first 4 rows of the
10<SPAN CLASS="MATH">&#215;</SPAN>10 board here.

<P>
<DIV ALIGN="CENTER">
<!-- MATH
 $\epsfbox{p10477c.eps}$
 -->
<IMG
 WIDTH="776" HEIGHT="331" ALIGN="BOTTOM" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/104/p10477a.gif" 
 ALT="\epsfbox{p10477c.eps}">
</DIV>

<P>


<P>
<BR><HR>
<ADDRESS>
Problem-setters: Monirul Hasan Tomal (Implementation & Enhancement) & Shahriar
Manzoor (Basic Idea & Initial Problem Statement)
</ADDRESS>
</BODY>
</HTML>
</HTML>

______________________________________________________
10478||||||false||||||

<!--Converted with LaTeX2HTML 2K.1beta (1.47)
original version by:  Nikos Drakos, CBLU, University of Leeds
* revised and updated by:  Marcus Hennecke, Ross Moore, Herb Swan
* with significant contributions from:
  Jens Lippmann, Marek Rouchal, Martin Wilck and others -->
<HTML>
<HEAD>
<TITLE>The Falling Pillars</TITLE>
<META NAME="description" CONTENT="The Falling Pillars">
<META NAME="keywords" CONTENT="htmlatex">
<META NAME="resource-type" CONTENT="document">
<META NAME="distribution" CONTENT="global">

<META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">
<META NAME="Generator" CONTENT="LaTeX2HTML v2K.1beta">
<META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Style-Type" CONTENT="text/css">

<LINK REL="STYLESHEET" HREF="htmlatex.css">

</HEAD>

<BODY LANG="EN" BGCOLOR=#FFFFFF>

<H1><BR CLEAR=ALL><CENTER><TABLE BGCOLOR=#0060F0><TR><TD><B><FONT SIZE=5 COLOR=#C0FFFF>&nbsp;<A NAME="SECTION0001000000000000000000">
The Falling Pillars</A>&nbsp;</FONT></B></TABLE></CENTER>
</H1>

<P>
The problem we will now discuss is shown in the picture below. Initially, five pillars are
standing upright as shown in Figure 1. Here A is the rightmost point of the base of leftmost
pillar. B, C, D and E are similar points for pillar 2, 3, 4 and 5 respectively. The pillars are placed
at equal distance. So AB = BC = CD = DE = <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>d</I></SPAN>. The pillars are allowed to fall somewhat freely
from right to left. If the pillars are numbered 1, 2, 3, 4, 5 from left to right then 1 touches 2 at P,
2 touches 3 at Q, 3 touches 4 at R and 4 touches 5 at S. The widths of all the pillars are <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>w</I></SPAN> (as
shown in an inset in Figure 2) and heights of all the pillars are <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>h</I></SPAN>.

<P>
<DIV ALIGN="CENTER">
<!-- MATH
 $\epsfbox{p10478a.eps}$
 -->
<IMG
 WIDTH="674" HEIGHT="918" ALIGN="BOTTOM" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/104/p10478a.gif" 
 ALT="\epsfbox{p10478a.eps}">
</DIV>

<P>
<DIV ALIGN="CENTER">
<!-- MATH
 $\epsfbox{p10478b.eps}$
 -->
<IMG
 WIDTH="789" HEIGHT="382" ALIGN="BOTTOM" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/104/p10478a.gif" 
 ALT="\epsfbox{p10478b.eps}">
</DIV>

<P>
Note that Figure 1, Figure 2 and the Figure below are described as 2-D pictures, which is quite
OK for this problem. You must also assume that all the pillars are rectangular and no sliding or
lifting occurs when the pillars fall down. Your job is to find out the angles SDE, RCD, QBC,
PAB in Figure 2  or other such angles in similar scenario.

<P>
There is one additional problem, which is shown in the picture above. In the left configuration
the fallen pillar is stable but on the right configuration the fallen pillar is not stable. The cause is
explained in the figure itself. Of course, that cause is applicable only when the pillar stands on a
single point (In this case point C). <B>A situation is unstable only when a fallen pillar cannot
maintain that fallen position on it's own.  A fallen pillar means, the status of a pillar when it
falls towards right as much as it is allowed to by the given configuration</B>. You will have to
detect if such situation occurs in any of our pillars and report it in the output. Let's call this
situation ``<B>Unstable Situation.</B>".

<P>

<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001001000000000000000">
Input</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>
The first line of the input file contains a single integer <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>N</I></SPAN>(<SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>N</I><IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="30" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/104/p10478a.gif" 
 ALT="$ \le$">20</SPAN>) which indicates how many sets
of inputs are there. Each of the next <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>N</I></SPAN> lines contains one set of input. Each line contains four
integers <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>n</I></SPAN>, <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>d</I></SPAN>, <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>h</I></SPAN> and <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>w</I></SPAN> (<!-- MATH
 $1001>h, d, w>0$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH">1001 &gt; <I>h</I>, <I>d</I>, <I>w</I> &gt; 0</SPAN> and <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>h</I><IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="30" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/104/p10478a.gif" 
 ALT="$ \ge$"><I>w</I></SPAN>). These four integers actually describe a
scenario or configuration like the above picture completely. Here <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>n</I></SPAN> is the number of pillars
(<SPAN CLASS="MATH">0 &lt; <I>n</I><IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="30" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/104/p10478a.gif" 
 ALT="$ \le$">8</SPAN>), the meaning of <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>d</I></SPAN>, <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>h</I></SPAN> and <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>w</I></SPAN> are described in the problem statement above.

<P>

<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001002000000000000000">
Output</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>
For each set of input you need to output maximum of <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>n</I></SPAN> lines. The description of the output for
each set is given below:

<P>
The output for each set starts with the serial number of the set as shown in the output for sample
input. Note that there is no space just before the colon (<TT>:</TT>). If the situation is
unstable you should
first output the line `<TT>Unstable Situation.</TT>', without the quotes. The next <SPAN CLASS="MATH">(<I>n</I> - 1)</SPAN> lines will print
the angles of pillars (from right to left) rounded up-to three digits after the decimal point. But if
within the given constraints the input is impossible you should only output the line
`<TT>Impossible.</TT>', without the quotes. There will be no such input where a fallen pillar has to
occupy the floor where once there was the base of the pillar to it's right. Remember that you
should assume that all pillars should be in fallen status even if all pillars are unstable.

<P>

<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001003000000000000000">
Sample Input</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>
<PRE>
2
5 4 10 3
5 4 10 1
</PRE>

<P>

<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001004000000000000000">
Sample Output</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>
<PRE>
Case 1:
Unstable Situation.
84.261
78.637
73.349
68.575
Case 2:
72.542
56.188
42.753
32.876
</PRE>

<P>


<P>
<BR><HR>
<ADDRESS>
Problem-setter: Shahriar Manzoor, ACM Valladolid Online Judge
</ADDRESS>
</BODY>
</HTML>
</HTML>

______________________________________________________
10480||||||false||||||

<!--Converted with LaTeX2HTML 2K.1beta (1.47)
original version by:  Nikos Drakos, CBLU, University of Leeds
* revised and updated by:  Marcus Hennecke, Ross Moore, Herb Swan
* with significant contributions from:
  Jens Lippmann, Marek Rouchal, Martin Wilck and others -->
<HTML>
<HEAD>
<TITLE>Sabotage</TITLE>
<META NAME="description" CONTENT="Sabotage">
<META NAME="keywords" CONTENT="htmlatex">
<META NAME="resource-type" CONTENT="document">
<META NAME="distribution" CONTENT="global">

<META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">
<META NAME="Generator" CONTENT="LaTeX2HTML v2K.1beta">
<META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Style-Type" CONTENT="text/css">

<LINK REL="STYLESHEET" HREF="htmlatex.css">

</HEAD>

<BODY LANG="EN" BGCOLOR=#FFFFFF>

<H1><BR CLEAR=ALL><CENTER><TABLE BGCOLOR=#0060F0><TR><TD><B><FONT SIZE=5 COLOR=#C0FFFF>&nbsp;<A NAME="SECTION0001000000000000000000">
Sabotage</A>&nbsp;</FONT></B></TABLE></CENTER>
</H1>

<P>
The regime of a small but wealthy dictatorship has been abruptly overthrown by an unexpected
rebellion. Because of the enormous disturbances this is causing in world economy, an imperialist
military super power has decided to invade the country and reinstall the old regime.

<P>
For this operation to be successful, communication between the capital and the largest city must
be completely cut. This is a difficult task, since all cities in the country are connected by a
computer network using the Internet Protocol, which allows messages to take any path through
the network. Because of this, the network must be completely split in two parts, with the capital
in one part and the largest city in the other, and with no connections between the parts.

<P>
There are large differences in the costs of sabotaging different connections, since some are much
more easy to get to than others.

<P>
Write a program that, given a network specification and the costs of sabotaging each connection,
determines which connections to cut in order to separate the capital and the largest city to the
lowest possible cost.

<P>

<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001001000000000000000">
Input</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>

<P>
Input file contains several sets of input. The description of each set is given below.

<P>
The first line of each set has two integers, separated by a space: First one the number of cities, <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>n</I></SPAN>
in the network, which is at most 50. The second one is the total number of connections, <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>m</I></SPAN>, at
most 500.

<P>
The following <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>m</I></SPAN> lines specify the connections. Each line has three parts separated by spaces:
The first two are the cities tied together by that connection (numbers in the range <SPAN CLASS="MATH">1 - <I>n</I></SPAN>). Then
follows the cost of cutting the connection (an integer in the range 1 to 40000000). Each pair of
cites can appear at most once in this list.

<P>
Input is terminated by a case where values of <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>n</I></SPAN> and <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>m</I></SPAN> are zero. This case should not be
processed. For every input set the capital is city number 1, and the largest city is number 2.

<P>

<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001002000000000000000">
Output</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>

<P>
For each set of input you should produce several lines of output. The description of output for
each set of input is given below:

<P>
The output for each set should be the pairs of cities (i.e. numbers) between which the connection
should be cut (in any order), each pair on one line with the numbers separated by a space. If
there is more than one solution, any one of them will do.

<P>
Print a blank line after the output for each set of input.

<P>

<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001003000000000000000">
Sample Input</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>
<PRE>
5 8
1 4 30
1 3 70
5 3 20
4 3 5
4 5 15
5 2 10
3 2 25
2 4 50
5 8
1 4 30
1 3 70
5 3 20
4 3 5
4 5 15
5 2 10
3 2 25
2 4 50
0 0
</PRE>

<P>

<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001004000000000000000">
Sample Output</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>
<PRE>
4 1
3 4
3 5
3 2

4 1
3 4
3 5
3 2
</PRE>

<P>


<P>
<BR><HR>
<ADDRESS>
Problem setter: Jesper Larsson, Lund University, Sweden
</ADDRESS>
</BODY>
</HTML>
</HTML>

______________________________________________________
10481||||||false||||||

* with significant contributions from:
  Jens Lippmann, Marek Rouchal, Martin Wilck and others -->
<HTML>
<HEAD>
<TITLE>The Gift Wrappers of Hollywood</TITLE>
<META NAME="description" CONTENT="The Gift Wrappers of Hollywood">
<META NAME="keywords" CONTENT="htmlatex">
<META NAME="resource-type" CONTENT="document">
<META NAME="distribution" CONTENT="global">

<META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">
<META NAME="Generator" CONTENT="LaTeX2HTML v2K.1beta">
<META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Style-Type" CONTENT="text/css">

<LINK REL="STYLESHEET" HREF="htmlatex.css">

</HEAD>

<BODY LANG="EN" BGCOLOR=#FFFFFF>

<H1><BR CLEAR=ALL><CENTER><TABLE BGCOLOR=#0060F0><TR><TD><B><FONT SIZE=5 COLOR=#C0FFFF>&nbsp;<A NAME="SECTION0001000000000000000000">
The Gift Wrappers of Hollywood</A>&nbsp;</FONT></B></TABLE></CENTER>
</H1>

<P>
A group of gift wrappers were having a good time in Hollywood. They used to pack gifts for the
stars of Hollywood who only wanted the gift boxes to be attractive. But recently they are having
a bad time as a group of mathematicians, problem setters and programmers have come to
Hollywood. News has spread out in the air that they are trying to arrange a programming contest
(Just imagine a contest team consisting Jim Carrey, Mr. Bean and Bill Cosby. Are you looking
for a better trio? OOPS!!). The gift wrappers are given the responsibility of making the gift
boxes for the contestants but the conditions of making the gift boxes are not simple. They are
given below:

<P>
<DL COMPACT>
<DT>a)</DT>
<DD>The gift boxes are all circular.
</DD>
<DT>b)</DT>
<DD>The gifts are all triangular with all three sides equal to one another.
</DD>
<DT>c)</DT>
<DD>All the gifts are of same size.
</DD>
<DT>d)</DT>
<DD>The height of the gifts and the height of the boxes are same, so the gifts cannot be
put one upon another.
</DD>
<DT>e)</DT>
<DD>All gift boxes contain four or eleven gifts. Each of the top three teams gets boxes
 with eleven gifts and the each team occupying 4th to 10th position gets boxes with
four gifts in it.
</DD>
<DT>f)</DT>
<DD>The gifts have unit height and so do the boxes.
</DD>
<DT>g)</DT>
<DD>The circular boxes must have minimum possible radius.
</DD>
</DL>

<P>
The contest organizing committee has supplied them the volume of one gift <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>L</I></SPAN>. They will have
to design the gift boxes with minimum radius <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>r</I><SUB>4</SUB></SPAN> and <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>r</I><SUB>11</SUB></SPAN> that can hold all the gifts.
Here <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>r</I><SUB>4</SUB></SPAN> is the
minimum possible radius of the box with four gifts and <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>r</I><SUB>11</SUB></SPAN> is the minimum possible radius of the
box with eleven gifts. The figure below shows how the gift wrappers can put four and eleven
gifts optimally in the gift box. The figure with eleven gift boxes is symmetric along the line AB.
The helpless gift wrappers have got hold of you and they have requested you to find the
minimum possible radiuses for them.

<P>
<DIV ALIGN="CENTER">
<!-- MATH
 $\epsfbox{p10481.eps}$
 -->
<IMG
 WIDTH="877" HEIGHT="358" ALIGN="BOTTOM" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/104/p10481.gif" 
 ALT="\epsfbox{p10481.eps}">
</DIV>

<P>

<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001001000000000000000">
Input</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>
The first line of the input file contains a single integer <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>N</I></SPAN>(<!-- MATH
 $N \le 1000$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>N</I><IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="30" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/104/p10481.gif" 
 ALT="$ \le$">1000</SPAN>) that denotes how many
lines of input are there in the input file. Each of the next <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>N</I></SPAN> lines contains a floating-point
number <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>L</I></SPAN>(<!-- MATH
 $0 \le L \le 100000000$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH">0<IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="30" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/104/p10481.gif" 
 ALT="$ \le$"><I>L</I><IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="30" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/104/p10481.gif" 
 ALT="$ \le$">100000000</SPAN>) whose meaning is given in the problem statement.

<P>

<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001002000000000000000">
Output</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>
For each value of <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>L</I></SPAN> produce one line of output. At first print the case number of the problem as
shown in the sample output. Then there are two floating-point numbers <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>r</I><SUB>4</SUB></SPAN> and <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>r</I><SUB>11</SUB></SPAN> rounded up to
twelve digits after the decimal point. The meaning of <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>r</I><SUB>4</SUB></SPAN> and <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>r</I><SUB>11</SUB></SPAN> are described in the problem
statement. The least significant digits of the output for sample input are not shown to prevent
you problem taking unnecessary advantages. You don't need to worry too much about precision
errors. Errors less than <!-- MATH
 $\max(10^{-7}, 10^{-5} \%)$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH">max(10<SUP>-7</SUP>, 10<SUP>-5</SUP>%)</SPAN> will be ignored.

<P>

<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001003000000000000000">
Sample Input</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>
<PRE>
2
0
2.30940107
</PRE>

<P>

<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001004000000000000000">
Sample Output</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>
<PRE>
Case 1: 0.000????????? 0.000?????????
Case 2: 2.264????????? 3.428?????????
</PRE>

<P>


<P>
<BR><HR>
<ADDRESS>
Problem-setter: Shahriar Manzoor, ACM Valladolid Online Judge
</ADDRESS>
</BODY>
</HTML>
</HTML>

______________________________________________________
10482||||||false||||||

<!--Converted with LaTeX2HTML 2K.1beta (1.47)
original version by:  Nikos Drakos, CBLU, University of Leeds
* revised and updated by:  Marcus Hennecke, Ross Moore, Herb Swan
* with significant contributions from:
  Jens Lippmann, Marek Rouchal, Martin Wilck and others -->
<HTML>
<HEAD>
<TITLE>The Candyman Can</TITLE>
<META NAME="description" CONTENT="The Candyman Can">
<META NAME="keywords" CONTENT="htmlatex">
<META NAME="resource-type" CONTENT="document">
<META NAME="distribution" CONTENT="global">

<META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">
<META NAME="Generator" CONTENT="LaTeX2HTML v2K.1beta">
<META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Style-Type" CONTENT="text/css">

<LINK REL="STYLESHEET" HREF="htmlatex.css">

</HEAD>

<BODY LANG="EN" BGCOLOR=#FFFFFF>

<H1><BR CLEAR=ALL><CENTER><TABLE BGCOLOR=#0060F0><TR><TD><B><FONT SIZE=5 COLOR=#C0FFFF>&nbsp;<A NAME="SECTION0001000000000000000000">
The Candyman Can</A>&nbsp;</FONT></B></TABLE></CENTER>
</H1>

<P>
<DIV ALIGN="CENTER">
<EM>                                       ``Who can take a sunrise
</EM></DIV>
<P>
<DIV ALIGN="CENTER"><EM>Sprinkle it with dew
</EM></DIV>
<P>
<DIV ALIGN="CENTER"><EM>Cover it in chocolate and a miracle or two
</EM></DIV>
<P>
<DIV ALIGN="CENTER"><EM>The Candy Man
</EM></DIV>
<P>
<DIV ALIGN="CENTER"><EM>The Candy Man can
</EM></DIV>
<P>
<DIV ALIGN="CENTER"><EM>The Candy Man can 'cause he mixes it with love
</EM></DIV>
<P>
<DIV ALIGN="CENTER"><EM>And makes the world taste good"
</EM>
</DIV>
<P>
<DIV ALIGN="CENTER"></DIV>
<P>
<BR>
<DIV ALIGN="CENTER">             (taken from the movie "Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory", 1971)

</DIV>

<P>
The Candyman can. But can he really?

<P>

<P>
<BR>
It's the first of October, the day Willy Wonka opens the doors to his famous Chocolate Factory
for the five lucky kids that hold one of the golden tickets: Charlie, Augustus, Mike, Veruca and
Violet. The tour guided by Willy Wonka begins, and after Augustus falls into the river of
chocolate and Violet turns into a blueberry (but don't worry, they are going to be safe and
healthy at the end), there are three of the children left.

<P>
What a shock! To calm down the remaining three children, Willy Wonka wants to give some
candies to them. He has a couple of candies that are of different weight and wants to divide them
evenly between the children, so that they don't get jealous at each other.

<P>
He wants to know how bad the fairest distribution is, i.e. what is the minimum difference in the
candies weight, of the kid getting the candies of the most total weight and the kid getting the
least. For example, assume that he gives the three children candies of weight <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>a</I></SPAN>, <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>b</I></SPAN> and <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>c</I></SPAN>,
respectively. The badness of this distribution is the difference between the maximum of <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>a</I></SPAN>, <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>b</I></SPAN>, <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>c</I></SPAN>
and the minimum of <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>a</I></SPAN>, <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>b</I></SPAN>, <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>c</I></SPAN>. Unfortunately, Willy Wonka is not very good in mathematics, so he
needs your help.

<P>

<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001001000000000000000">
Input</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>

<P>
The first line of input contains a single integer (less than 130) indicating the number of testcases
that follow. Each testcase consists of two lines. The first line contains a number <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>n</I></SPAN>(<!-- MATH
 $0 < n \le 32$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH">0 &lt; <I>n</I><IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="30" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/104/10482img1.png" 
 ALT="$ \le$">32</SPAN>),
the number of candies to be distributed. The second line contains <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>n</I></SPAN> numbers <!-- MATH
 $a_1 \dots a_n$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>a</I><SUB>1</SUB>...<I>a</I><SUB>n</SUB></SPAN>
(<!-- MATH
 $0 <a_i \le 20$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH">0 &lt; <I>a</I><SUB>i</SUB><IMG
 WIDTH="18" HEIGHT="30" ALIGN="MIDDLE" BORDER="0"
 SRC="http://uva.onlinejudge.org/external/104/10482img1.png" 
 ALT="$ \le$">20</SPAN> for all <!-- MATH
 $i=1 \dots n$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>i</I> = 1...<I>n</I></SPAN>), the weight of the different candies.

<P>

<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001002000000000000000">
Output</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>
For each testcase, output a single line which contains the case number (as shown in the sample
output) and then the smallest badness that can be achieved when distributing all candies to the
children. There is only a single space between the colon and the smallest badness.

<P>

<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001003000000000000000">
Sample Input</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>
<PRE>
4
3
2 2 2
2
3 4
6
13 9 7 7 1 7
8
3 3 3 3 3 3 5 5
</PRE>

<P>

<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001004000000000000000">
Sample Output</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>
<PRE>
Case 1: 0
Case 2: 4
Case 3: 2
Case 4: 1
</PRE>

<P>


<P>
<BR><HR>
<ADDRESS>
Problem setter: Juergen Werner, Albert Einstein University Ulm, Germany
</ADDRESS>
</BODY>
</HTML>
</HTML>

______________________________________________________
10483||||||false||||||

<!--Converted with LaTeX2HTML 2K.1beta (1.47)
original version by:  Nikos Drakos, CBLU, University of Leeds
* revised and updated by:  Marcus Hennecke, Ross Moore, Herb Swan
* with significant contributions from:
  Jens Lippmann, Marek Rouchal, Martin Wilck and others -->
<HTML>
<HEAD>
<TITLE>The Sum Equals the Product</TITLE>
<META NAME="description" CONTENT="The Sum Equals the Product">
<META NAME="keywords" CONTENT="htmlatex">
<META NAME="resource-type" CONTENT="document">
<META NAME="distribution" CONTENT="global">

<META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Type" CONTENT="text/html; charset=iso-8859-1">
<META NAME="Generator" CONTENT="LaTeX2HTML v2K.1beta">
<META HTTP-EQUIV="Content-Style-Type" CONTENT="text/css">

<LINK REL="STYLESHEET" HREF="htmlatex.css">

</HEAD>

<BODY LANG="EN" BGCOLOR=#FFFFFF>

<H1><BR CLEAR=ALL><CENTER><TABLE BGCOLOR=#0060F0><TR><TD><B><FONT SIZE=5 COLOR=#C0FFFF>&nbsp;<A NAME="SECTION0001000000000000000000">
The Sum Equals the Product</A>&nbsp;</FONT></B></TABLE></CENTER>
</H1>

<P>
One day in a supermarket I witnessed the following scene. A young man put 3 items onto the
conveyor belt and watched the cashier entering the numbers. He noticed that the cashier did not
add the 3 prices but multiplied them! He of course was not willing to pay the final outcome
which appeared on the electronic display and asked for the manager to come. In the mean time
the young man took a piece of paper, wrote down the 3 prices and added them up. For some
strange reason the result was precisely the same. He paid the sum (which was also the product)
and left. This equality only appears with very special triplets of numbers. I remember the sum
(or product) beeing within a certain range (between $ 5.70 and $ 6.10). But, what were the 3
prices?

<P>

<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001001000000000000000">
Input</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>
The input contains two numbers specifying the range, separated by a space. The sum (or
product) is to be within this range. Both numbers are positive (<SPAN CLASS="MATH">&lt; 256.00</SPAN>) and have 2 digits after
the decimal point.

<P>

<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001002000000000000000">
Output</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>
For each special triplet found (with the sum of the 3 prices being the same as their product) with
sum (and product) within the range, the output contains one line in the format:

<P>

<P>
<BR>

<!-- MATH
 $sum = a + b + c = a * b * c$
 -->
<SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>sum</I> = <I>a</I> + <I>b</I> + <I>c</I> = <I>a</I>*<I>b</I>*<I>c</I></SPAN>

<P>

<P>
<BR>
Where  <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>a</I></SPAN>,  <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>b</I></SPAN> and <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>c</I></SPAN> are the 3 prices in ascending order. The output lines shall start with the
smallest sum (or product) within the range and also be in ascending order. In the special case of
multiple solutions for one and the same sum (or product), the first line shall be the one
containing the smallest price (<SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>a</I></SPAN>).

<P>
All numbers (<SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>sum</I></SPAN>, <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>a</I></SPAN>, <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>b</I></SPAN>, <SPAN CLASS="MATH"><I>c</I></SPAN>) are printed with 2 digits after the decimal point.

<P>

<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001003000000000000000">
Sample Input</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>
<PRE>
5.70 6.10
</PRE>

<P>

<H2><FONT COLOR=#0070E8><A NAME="SECTION0001004000000000000000">
Sample Output</A>&nbsp;</FONT>
</H2>
<PRE>
5.70 = 1.25 + 1.60 + 2.85 = 1.25 * 1.60 * 2.85
5.85 = 1.00 + 2.25 + 2.60 = 1.00 * 2.25 * 2.60
5.88 = 0.98 + 2.40 + 2.50 = 0.98 * 2.40 * 2.50
6.00 = 1.00 + 2.00 + 3.00 = 1.00 * 2.00 * 3.00
</PRE>

<P>

<P>
<BR><HR>
<ADDRESS>
Problem-setter: Eric Schmidt, Former student of Technical University of Vienna, Now working at BOSCH
</ADDRESS>
</BODY>
</HTML>
</HTML>

______________________________________________________

<!--[if gte mso 9]><xml>
 <o:shapedefaults v:ext="edit" spidmax="1027"/>
</xml><![endif]--><!--[if gte mso 9]><xml>
 <o:shapelayout v:ext="edit">
  <o:idmap v:ext="edit" data="1"/>
 </o:shapelayout></xml><![endif]--><o:SmartTagType name="place" namespaceuri="urn:schemas-microsoft-com:office:smarttags"></o:SmartTagType><o:SmartTagType name="PlaceName" namespaceuri="urn:schemas-microsoft-com:office:smarttags"></o:SmartTagType><o:SmartTagType name="PlaceType" namespaceuri="urn:schemas-microsoft-com:office:smarttags"></o:SmartTagType>

<body lang=EN-US style='tab-interval:.5in'>

<div class=Section1>

<p class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center'><b><span
style='font-size:18.0pt'>Problem A</span></b><br>
<b><span style='font-size:24.0pt'>Divisibility of Factors</span></b><br>
<b>Input:</b> standard input<br>
<b>Output:</b> standard output<br>
<b>Time Limit:</b> 7 seconds<br>
<b>Memory Limit:</b> 32 MB</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'>&nbsp;</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='color:black'>Given
two integers <b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>N</b> and <b
style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>D</b>, you will have to find how many of
the factors of <b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>N!</b> (factorial <b>N</b>)
are divisible by <b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>D</b>.<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'>&nbsp;</p>

<p class=MsoNormal><b><span style='font-size:18.0pt'>Input</span></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='color:black'>The
input file contains several lines of input. Each line contains two integers <b
style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>N (0&lt;=N&lt;=&nbsp;100)</b> and <b
style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>D(0&lt;|D|&lt;=2^31-1)</b>. Input is
terminated by a line containing two zeroes. This line should not be processed.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'>&nbsp;</p>

<p class=MsoNormal><b><span style='font-size:18.0pt'>Output</span></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='color:black;
mso-bidi-font-weight:bold'>For each line of input produce one line of output. This
line contains a single integer, which denotes of many different factors of <b>N!</b>
are divisible by <b>D</b>.<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'>&nbsp;</p>

<p class=MsoNormal><b><span style='font-size:18.0pt'>Sample Input</span></b><br>
<span style='font-size:11.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:12.0pt;font-family:"Courier New"'>10
2<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span style='font-size:11.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:12.0pt;
font-family:"Courier New"'>9 3<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='font-size:11.0pt;
mso-bidi-font-size:14.0pt;font-family:"Courier New"'>0 0</span><b><span
style='font-size:14.0pt'>&nbsp;<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'>&nbsp;</p>

<p class=MsoNormal><b><span style='font-size:18.0pt'>Sample Output</span></b><br>
<span style='font-size:11.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:12.0pt;font-family:"Courier New"'>240<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span style='font-size:11.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:12.0pt;
font-family:"Courier New"'>128</span></p>


<div class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center;tab-stops:45.8pt 91.6pt 137.4pt 183.2pt 229.0pt 274.8pt 320.6pt 366.4pt 412.2pt 458.0pt 503.8pt 549.6pt 595.4pt 641.2pt 687.0pt 732.8pt'>

<hr size=2 width="100%" align=center>

</div>


<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify;tab-stops:45.8pt 91.6pt 137.4pt 183.2pt 229.0pt 274.8pt 320.6pt 366.4pt 412.2pt 458.0pt 503.8pt 549.6pt 595.4pt 641.2pt 687.0pt 732.8pt'><b
style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>Shahriar Manzoor</b></p>

<pre>&nbsp;</pre><pre><span style='font-size:14.0pt;font-family:"Monotype Corsiva";
mso-bidi-font-family:"Times New Roman"'> <o:p></o:p></span></pre></div>

</body>

</html>

div.Section1
	{page:Section1;}
 /* List Definitions */
@list l0
	{mso-list-id:1997492232;
	mso-list-type:hybrid;
	mso-list-template-ids:469556442 1200763830 1309452790 -895036672 1287261824 -1107405652 -820343018 -1322644270 1017050258 144876998;}
@list l0:level1
	{mso-level-number-format:bullet;
	mso-level-text:\F0B7;
	mso-level-tab-stop:.5in;
	mso-level-number-position:left;
	text-indent:-.25in;
	mso-ansi-font-size:10.0pt;
	font-family:Symbol;}
@list l0:level2
	{mso-level-number-format:bullet;
	mso-level-text:o;
	mso-level-tab-stop:1.0in;
	mso-level-number-position:left;
	text-indent:-.25in;
	mso-ansi-font-size:10.0pt;
	font-family:"Courier New";
	mso-bidi-font-family:"Times New Roman";}
ol
	{margin-bottom:0in;}
ul
	{margin-bottom:0in;}
-->
</style>
<!--[if gte mso 9]><xml>
 <o:shapedefaults v:ext="edit" spidmax="1027"/>
</xml><![endif]--><!--[if gte mso 9]><xml>
 <o:shapelayout v:ext="edit">
  <o:idmap v:ext="edit" data="1"/>
 </o:shapelayout></xml><![endif]--><o:SmartTagType namespaceuri="urn:schemas-microsoft-com:office:smarttags" name="place"/><o:SmartTagType namespaceuri="urn:schemas-microsoft-com:office:smarttags" name="PlaceType"/><o:SmartTagType namespaceuri="urn:schemas-microsoft-com:office:smarttags" name="PlaceName"/>
</head>

<body lang=EN-US link="#6633cc" vlink=purple style='tab-interval:.5in'>

<div class=Section1>

<p class=MsoNormal align=center style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:.5in;
margin-bottom:0in;margin-left:.5in;margin-bottom:.0001pt;text-align:center'><b><span
style='font-size:18.0pt'>Problem B</span></b><br>
<b><span style='font-size:24.0pt'>Painting with CSE</span></b><br>
<b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'><span style='mso-bidi-font-size:12.0pt'>Input:
</span></b><span style='mso-bidi-font-size:12.0pt;mso-bidi-font-weight:bold'>standard
input</span><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'><span style='mso-bidi-font-size:
12.0pt'><br>
Output: </span></b><span style='mso-bidi-font-size:12.0pt;mso-bidi-font-weight:
bold'>standard output<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal align=center style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:.5in;
margin-bottom:0in;margin-left:.5in;margin-bottom:.0001pt;text-align:center'><b><span
style='mso-bidi-font-size:18.0pt'>Time Limit:</span></b><span style='mso-bidi-font-size:
18.0pt'> 4 seconds</span><span style='mso-bidi-font-size:12.0pt'><o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-top:0in;margin-right:.5in;margin-bottom:0in;
margin-left:.5in;margin-bottom:.0001pt;text-align:justify'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'><span style='mso-bidi-font-size:12.0pt'><br>
</span></b><span style='mso-ansi-language:EN'><span style="mso-spacerun:
yes"> </span><span lang=EN><o:p></o:p></span></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'>A software development company
near Polashi, Dhaka is famous for their product <u>B</u>itmap <u>U</u>pdate
&amp; <u>E</u>diting <u>T</u>ool (BUET). This software uses text commands to
draw objects. A subset of the text commands is used in drawing straight lines
and rectagles. This subset is known as <u>C</u>ompound <u>S</u>tring <u>E</u>xpression
for <u>D</u>rawing, <u>E</u>diting &amp; <u>P</u>lotting rec<u>T</u>angles (CSE
DEPT).<br>
&nbsp;<span style='mso-bidi-font-size:12.0pt;font-family:"Arial Unicode MS";
color:windowtext'><o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'>The CSE commands has the
following elements:</p>

<ul type=disc>
 <li class=MsoNormal style='mso-margin-top-alt:auto;mso-margin-bottom-alt:auto;
     text-align:justify;mso-list:l0 level1 lfo3;tab-stops:list .5in'>A point is
     represented by two integers x and y separated by comma (<span
     style='font-family:Courier'>','</span>) and surrounded by parentheses (<span
     style='font-family:Courier'>'('</span> and <span style='font-family:Courier'>')'</span>).
     </li>
 <li class=MsoNormal style='mso-margin-top-alt:auto;mso-margin-bottom-alt:auto;
     text-align:justify;mso-list:l0 level1 lfo3;tab-stops:list .5in'>An object
     consists of at least one point separated by commas (<span
     style='font-family:Courier'>','</span>) and surrounded by square brackets
     (<span style='font-family:Courier'>'['</span> and <span style='font-family:
     Courier'>']'</span>). Two consecutive points in an object must be the same
     or represent a horizontal or vertical line. The sequence of <i>n</i>
     points in an object represents a sequence of <i>n</i>-1 lines, found by
     joining each consecutive pair of points. </li>
 <li class=MsoNormal style='mso-margin-top-alt:auto;mso-margin-bottom-alt:auto;
     text-align:justify;mso-list:l0 level1 lfo3;tab-stops:list .5in'>Two
     objects can be added using the function <span style='font-family:Courier'>'A(
     obj1, obj2 )'</span>. These two object can be added if the last point of <span
     style='font-family:Courier'>obj1</span> is the same as the first point of <span
     style='font-family:Courier'>obj2</span>. The function returns another
     object having all the points of <span style='font-family:Courier'>obj1</span>
     and <span style='font-family:Courier'>obj2</span> in the same order (the
     common 'middle' point apears only once, however). </li>
 <li class=MsoNormal style='mso-margin-top-alt:auto;mso-margin-bottom-alt:auto;
     text-align:justify;mso-list:l0 level1 lfo3;tab-stops:list .5in'>A list of
     objects is either a single object or the result of one of the following
     functions: </li>
 <ul type=circle>
  <li class=MsoNormal style='mso-margin-top-alt:auto;mso-margin-bottom-alt:
      auto;text-align:justify;mso-list:l0 level2 lfo3;tab-stops:list 1.0in'><span
      style='font-family:Courier'>T( dx, dy, ListExpr )</span> returns a list
      with all points in all objects in the list expression (defined below)
      ListExpr translated towards (dx, dy) (i.e. all x's are increased by dx
      and all y's are increased by dy). </li>
  <li class=MsoNormal style='mso-margin-top-alt:auto;mso-margin-bottom-alt:
      auto;text-align:justify;mso-list:l0 level2 lfo3;tab-stops:list 1.0in'><span
      style='font-family:Courier'>S( fx, fy, ListExpr )</span> returns a list
      with all points in all objects in the expression ListExpr scaled by (fx,
      fy) (i.e. all x's are multiplied by fx and all y's are multiplied by fy).
      </li>
  <li class=MsoNormal style='mso-margin-top-alt:auto;mso-margin-bottom-alt:
      auto;text-align:justify;mso-list:l0 level2 lfo3;tab-stops:list 1.0in'><span
      style='font-family:Courier'>R( theta, ListExpr )</span> returns a list
      with all points in all objects in the expression ListExpr rotated counter
      clockwise by the angle theta. theta must a multiple of 90 and can be
      negative. </li>
 </ul>
 <li class=MsoNormal style='mso-margin-top-alt:auto;mso-margin-bottom-alt:auto;
     text-align:justify;mso-list:l0 level1 lfo3;tab-stops:list .5in'>A list
     expression is at least one list separated by lower case (<span
     style='font-family:Courier'>'u'</span>). It means a set-union of the
     lists. </li>
</ul>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'>&nbsp;</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'>Given a list expression, you are
to draw the bitmap in the format shown in the sample. Spaces are allowed in the
input. Pixels having x or y less than 0 or grater than 9 are to be ignored.
&nbsp;</p>

<h2><span lang=EN style='mso-ansi-language:EN'>Input<o:p></o:p></span></h2>

<p style='text-align:justify'>Input consists of several input strings, one in
each line. The end of input is marked with a line consisting of a single <span
style='font-family:Courier'>'#'</span> mark. Input may contain any character,
but all except the ones mentioned above indicates error. Input can be upto 120
characters long. Integers can be negative. You can assume that there will be at
most 20 points in any object, and at most 20 objects in any list.<span lang=EN
style='mso-ansi-language:EN'><o:p></o:p></span></p>

<h2><span lang=EN style='mso-ansi-language:EN'>Output<o:p></o:p></span></h2>

<p style='text-align:justify'>For each dataset, print the set number(1,2,...)
in a line followed by the 10*10 bitmap. Lower left corner is the pixel (0,0). A
blank is marked by a dot, while a dark pixel is marked by a hash sign. An error
in input should result in a bitmap having a question mark at the pixel (0,0).<span
lang=EN style='mso-ansi-language:EN'><o:p></o:p></span></p>

<h2><span lang=EN style='mso-ansi-language:EN'>Sample Input<o:p></o:p></span></h2>

<pre><![if !supportEmptyParas]>&nbsp;<![endif]><o:p></o:p></pre><pre>[(0,0),(1,0)] u R( 90, [(2,0),(5,0)] )</pre><pre>[(0,0),(1,0)] u T( 5,5, [(0,0)] u [(1,0)] u A([(2,0),(5,0)],[(5,0),(5,5)]) )</pre><pre>T( 5,5, S(2,2 2, [(0,0),(1,0)] ))</pre><pre>T( 5,5, R( 90, S(2,2, [(0,0),(1,0)] )) )</pre><pre>#<span
lang=EN style='font-size:11.0pt;mso-ansi-language:EN'><o:p></o:p></span></pre>

<h2 style='tab-stops:45.8pt 91.6pt 137.4pt 183.2pt 229.0pt 274.8pt 320.6pt 366.4pt 412.2pt 458.0pt 503.8pt 549.6pt 595.4pt 641.2pt 687.0pt 732.8pt'><span
lang=EN style='mso-ansi-language:EN'>Sample Output<o:p></o:p></span></h2>

<pre>Set #1</pre><pre>..........</pre><pre>..........</pre><pre>..........</pre><pre>..........</pre><pre>#.........</pre><pre>#.........</pre><pre>#.........</pre><pre>#.........</pre><pre>..........</pre><pre>##........</pre><pre>Set #2</pre><pre>..........</pre><pre>..........</pre><pre>..........</pre><pre>..........</pre><pre>.....#####</pre><pre>..........</pre><pre>..........</pre><pre>..........</pre><pre>..........</pre><pre>##........</pre><pre>Set #3</pre><pre>..........</pre><pre>..........</pre><pre>..........</pre><pre>..........</pre><pre>..........</pre><pre>..........</pre><pre>..........</pre><pre>..........</pre><pre>..........</pre><pre>?.........</pre><pre>Set #4</pre><pre>..........</pre><pre>..........</pre><pre>.....#....</pre><pre>.....#....</pre><pre>.....#....</pre><pre>..........</pre><pre>..........</pre><pre>..........</pre><pre>..........</pre><pre>..........</pre>

<p class=MsoNormal style='tab-stops:45.8pt 91.6pt 137.4pt 183.2pt 229.0pt 274.8pt 320.6pt 366.4pt 412.2pt 458.0pt 503.8pt 549.6pt 595.4pt 641.2pt 687.0pt 732.8pt'><![if !supportEmptyParas]>&nbsp;<![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>


<div class=MsoNormal style='tab-stops:45.8pt 91.6pt 137.4pt 183.2pt 229.0pt 274.8pt 320.6pt 366.4pt 412.2pt 458.0pt 503.8pt 549.6pt 595.4pt 641.2pt 687.0pt 732.8pt'>

<hr size=2 width="100%" align=left>

</div>


<p class=MsoNormal style='tab-stops:45.8pt 91.6pt 137.4pt 183.2pt 229.0pt 274.8pt 320.6pt 366.4pt 412.2pt 458.0pt 503.8pt 549.6pt 595.4pt 641.2pt 687.0pt 732.8pt'><b>Mustaq
Ahmed</b><b><span style='color:windowtext'><o:p></o:p></span></b></p>

</div>

</body>

<title>Problem C - Mountain Village</title>

<body lang=EN-US style='tab-interval:.5in'>

<div class=Section1>

<p class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center'><b><span
style='font-size:18.0pt;color:black'>Problem C</span></b><span
style='color:black'><br>
</span><b><span style='font-size:24.0pt;mso-font-kerning:18.0pt'>Mountain
Village</span></b><b><span style='font-size:24.0pt;color:black'><o:p></o:p></span></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center;mso-layout-grid-align:
none;text-autospace:none'><b><span style='color:black'>Input:</span></b><span
style='color:black'> standard input<br>
<b>Output:</b> standard output<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center;mso-layout-grid-align:
none;text-autospace:none'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'><span
style='color:black'>Time Limit: </span></b><span style='color:black;mso-bidi-font-weight:
bold'>7</span><span style='color:black'> seconds</span><span style='font-size:
1.0pt;font-family:Arial'><o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='mso-layout-grid-align:none;text-autospace:none'><b
style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'><span style='mso-bidi-font-size:18.0pt;
color:black'><![if !supportEmptyParas]>&nbsp;<![endif]><o:p></o:p></span></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify;mso-layout-grid-align:none;
text-autospace:none'>After a long summer's march through the rough terrain of
northern America, the indian tribe had found a place where they hopefully would
be left alone. The chief proclaimed that this would be the new place for their
village, despite the rocky nature of the landscape. They set a temporary camp
for the night, content with the piece of land they had discovered. The very
next day however, it stood clear that some effort planning the locations of the
Teepee tents had to be made. It was simply too great a difference in altitude
between the tents, making the walk along some paths extremely tiresome.
Therefore, the chief ordered his witty son, Fast Thought, to find a connected
area in their vicinity, large enough to host all tents of the tribe, having as
small difference between the highest and lowest point as possible.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify;mso-layout-grid-align:none;
text-autospace:none'><span style='mso-bidi-font-size:1.0pt'><![if !supportEmptyParas]>&nbsp;<![endif]><o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify;mso-layout-grid-align:none;
text-autospace:none'><span style='mso-bidi-font-size:1.0pt'>The task called for
some altitude measurements of their whereabouts, which caused no problem for
Fast Thought, since he was wise in the ways of trigonometry. He divided the
land into squares big enough to host a tent each and estimated the altitude of
each square. Now the problem was reduced to finding a connected region
containing at least as many squares as there were tents, having the smallest
difference between the highest and lowest altitude. He drew a rectangular
matrix A, representing the area, where the entry ai;j at row i and column j,
was the altitude of the square with coordinates (i; j). He considered an entry
ai;j adjacent to the entries </span>a<sub>i, j+1</sub>, a<sub>i+1,<span
style="mso-spacerun: yes">  </span>j</sub> ; a<sub>i, j-1 </sub>and a<sub>i-1,<span
style="mso-spacerun: yes">  </span></sub><sub><span style='mso-bidi-font-size:
1.0pt'>j</span></sub><span style='mso-bidi-font-size:1.0pt'> , and called a set
of entries connected if for every pair of entries in </span>the set, there was
a connecting path of adjacent entries in it. Since the size of the tribe
altered with time, Fast Thought decided to solve the problem for a general
number of tents. Thus the <span style='mso-bidi-font-size:1.0pt'>problem left
to solve for him was to find a set of at least k connected entries a<sub>ij</sub>
in the matrix A, such that the difference between the largest and the smallest
entry in the set was minimized.</span><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'><span
style='mso-bidi-font-size:18.0pt;color:black'><o:p></o:p></span></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='mso-layout-grid-align:none;text-autospace:none'><b
style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'><span style='font-size:18.0pt;color:black'><![if !supportEmptyParas]>&nbsp;<![endif]><o:p></o:p></span></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='mso-layout-grid-align:none;text-autospace:none'><b
style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'><span style='font-size:18.0pt;color:black'>Input<o:p></o:p></span></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify;mso-layout-grid-align:none;
text-autospace:none'>On the first line of input there are two integers, r; c
&lt;= 40, giving the dimension of the matrix A. The following r lines, each
containing c integers between 0 and 99, are the entries a <sub>i,j</sub> of the
matrix. The next line contains a single integer n _ 100, and is followed by n
lines each holding a <span style='mso-bidi-font-size:1.0pt'>single positive
integer k<sub>i</sub> &lt;= rc.</span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='mso-layout-grid-align:none;text-autospace:none'><b
style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'><span style='font-size:18.0pt;color:black'><![if !supportEmptyParas]>&nbsp;<![endif]><o:p></o:p></span></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='mso-layout-grid-align:none;text-autospace:none'><b
style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'><span style='font-size:18.0pt;color:black'>Output</span></b><b
style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'><span style='mso-bidi-font-size:18.0pt;
color:black'><o:p></o:p></span></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify;mso-layout-grid-align:none;
text-autospace:none'>For each k<sub>i</sub>, output one line containing the
minimum difference between the largest and the smallest entry for any connected
set of at least k<sub>i</sub> entries.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='mso-layout-grid-align:none;text-autospace:none'><![if !supportEmptyParas]>&nbsp;<![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='mso-layout-grid-align:none;text-autospace:none'><b
style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'><span style='font-size:18.0pt;color:black'><![if !supportEmptyParas]>&nbsp;<![endif]><o:p></o:p></span></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='mso-layout-grid-align:none;text-autospace:none'><b
style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'><span style='font-size:18.0pt;color:black'><![if !supportEmptyParas]>&nbsp;<![endif]><o:p></o:p></span></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='mso-layout-grid-align:none;text-autospace:none'><b
style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'><span style='font-size:18.0pt;color:black'>Sample
Input</span></b><span style='font-size:11.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:1.0pt;
font-family:"Courier New"'><o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='mso-layout-grid-align:none;text-autospace:none'><span
style='font-size:11.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:1.0pt;font-family:"Courier New"'>5
10<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='mso-layout-grid-align:none;text-autospace:none'><span
style='font-size:11.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:1.0pt;font-family:"Courier New"'>0 0
3 46 0 46 0 0 12 12<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='mso-layout-grid-align:none;text-autospace:none'><span
style='font-size:11.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:1.0pt;font-family:"Courier New"'>0 0
13 50 49 46 11 10 10 11<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='mso-layout-grid-align:none;text-autospace:none'><span
style='font-size:11.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:1.0pt;font-family:"Courier New"'>0
51 51 49 99 99 89 0 0 10<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='mso-layout-grid-align:none;text-autospace:none'><span
style='font-size:11.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:1.0pt;font-family:"Courier New"'>0 0
48 82 70 99 0 52 13 14<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='mso-layout-grid-align:none;text-autospace:none'><span
style='font-size:11.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:1.0pt;font-family:"Courier New"'>51
50 50 51 70 35 70 10 14 11<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='mso-layout-grid-align:none;text-autospace:none'><span
style='font-size:11.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:1.0pt;font-family:"Courier New"'>6<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='mso-layout-grid-align:none;text-autospace:none'><span
style='font-size:11.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:1.0pt;font-family:"Courier New"'>1<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='mso-layout-grid-align:none;text-autospace:none'><span
style='font-size:11.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:1.0pt;font-family:"Courier New"'>5<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='mso-layout-grid-align:none;text-autospace:none'><span
style='font-size:11.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:1.0pt;font-family:"Courier New"'>10<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='mso-layout-grid-align:none;text-autospace:none'><span
style='font-size:11.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:1.0pt;font-family:"Courier New"'>12<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='mso-layout-grid-align:none;text-autospace:none'><span
style='font-size:11.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:1.0pt;font-family:"Courier New"'>47<o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='tab-stops:45.8pt 91.6pt 137.4pt 183.2pt 229.0pt 274.8pt 320.6pt 366.4pt 412.2pt 458.0pt 503.8pt 549.6pt 595.4pt 641.2pt 687.0pt 732.8pt;
mso-layout-grid-align:none;text-autospace:none'><span style='font-size:11.0pt;
mso-bidi-font-size:1.0pt;font-family:"Courier New"'>50</span><span
style='font-size:11.0pt;font-family:"Courier New";color:black'><o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='tab-stops:45.8pt 91.6pt 137.4pt 183.2pt 229.0pt 274.8pt 320.6pt 366.4pt 412.2pt 458.0pt 503.8pt 549.6pt 595.4pt 641.2pt 687.0pt 732.8pt;
mso-layout-grid-align:none;text-autospace:none'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'><span style='font-size:11.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:18.0pt;font-family:
"Courier New";color:black'><![if !supportEmptyParas]>&nbsp;<![endif]><o:p></o:p></span></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='tab-stops:45.8pt 91.6pt 137.4pt 183.2pt 229.0pt 274.8pt 320.6pt 366.4pt 412.2pt 458.0pt 503.8pt 549.6pt 595.4pt 641.2pt 687.0pt 732.8pt;
mso-layout-grid-align:none;text-autospace:none'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:

<pre><span style='font-size:11.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt'>0<o:p></o:p></span></pre><pre><span
style='font-size:11.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt'>0<o:p></o:p></span></pre><pre><span
style='font-size:11.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt'>3<o:p></o:p></span></pre><pre><span
style='font-size:11.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt'>4<o:p></o:p></span></pre><pre><span
style='font-size:11.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt'>89<o:p></o:p></span></pre><pre><span
style='font-size:11.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt'>99</span></pre>

<div class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center;tab-stops:45.8pt 91.6pt 137.4pt 183.2pt 229.0pt 274.8pt 320.6pt 366.4pt 412.2pt 458.0pt 503.8pt 549.6pt 595.4pt 641.2pt 687.0pt 732.8pt'><span
style='color:black'>

<!--[if gte mso 9]><xml>
 <o:shapedefaults v:ext="edit" spidmax="1027"/>
</xml><![endif]--><!--[if gte mso 9]><xml>
 <o:shapelayout v:ext="edit">
